  • We conclude that , at the ansB promoters , AR1 is required when CRP binds upstream ( around -- 91 ) , whether functioning together with downstream FNR in a co-dependent manner , or with CRP downstream in a synergistic manner . [8748035]
  • At class II CRP-dependent promoters , CRP binds to a site centered near position 41.5 , and transcription is stimulated through interactions between CTD and AR1 of the upstream CRP monomer and between NTD and an additional surface , referred to as activating region 2 ( AR2 ; residues 19 , 21 , 96 , and 101 ) , on the downstream CRP monomer ( 11 , 24 , 76 ) . [19633076]

  • Cra is involved in regulation of the whole set of enzymes in central carbon metabolism ( 43 ) , while CRP regulates the genes for carbon source utilization outside the central metab-olism , including transport of various carbon sources , glycolysisgluconeogenesis switching , the tricarboxylic acid ( TCA ) cycle , the pyruvate dehydrogenase pathway , and aerobic respiration ( 35 ) .   • Results Search for the regulation targets of CRP by using Genomic SELEX screening : SELEX-clos analysis In order to get insight into the genome regulation by CRP for control of carbon source utilization in E. coli , we first tried to identify the whole set of target promoters , genes and operons under the control of CRP . [21673794]
  • In addition to the operon-specific regulation mediated by the PaaX repressor , the paa catabolic cluster of E. coli is subjected to control by the two global regulators , CRP ( 23 ) and IHF ( 22 ) . [10766858]
  • We have shown in this work that the specific PaaX-mediated control of the Pa and Pz promoters for PA degradation in E. coli is , in turn , subordinated to a superimposed regulation mediated by global regulators such as CRP and IHF , which connect the expression of the paa catabolic genes to the metabolic and energetic status of the cell . [10766858]

[17873038]
  • Examples of transcriptional control in which the action of ArgR occurs in combination with ( an ) other regulatory protein ( s ) and co-factors have been documented previously for CRP , NtrC , Lrp , and IHF .22,23,29,50 Furthermore , artP mRNA levels were found to be induced in the stationary phase by EσS , the general stress-specific RNA polymerase ,51 upregulated ( 1.9-fold ) by the superoxide generating agent paraquat , an inducer of the soxRS system , and by sodium salicylate ( NaSal ) , an inducer of the marRA system ( 2.5-fold ) ,52 and down-regulated by Lrp ( about sixfold ) .53 Genome-wide expression profiling studies in E. coli indicate that argT and hisJ transcription are activated by NtrC ( GlnG ) ,45 and that in anaerobiosis hisJ expression is strongly increased in fnr ( 25-fold ) and arcA ( 60-fold ) mutants .54,55 None of the underlying molecular mechanisms has been unraveled yet , but the induction of E. coli artP in the stationary phase appears to depend on several secondary promoters ,51 upstream of PartP . [17850814]

( 1998 ) ( ) . [17608696]
  • In E. coli , operons caiTABCDE and fixABCX are modulated positively by general regulators , such as the AMPc receptor protein ( CRP ) or the transcriptional-regulator responsible for anaerobic induction ( FNR ) , and negatively by the DNA-binding protein H-NS , glucose , or nitrate ( Eichler et al. , 1994a ; Unden and Trageser 1991 ) . [14595781]
  • CHR activity was always high because the cai operon ( responsible for the expression of carnitine metabolism ) was controlled by protein regulators such as FNR ( transcriptional-regulator under anaerobic conditions ) , catabolic repression via protein receptor ( CRP ) of AMPc , histones ( H-NS ) , and the transcriptional factor j 2 ( RpoS ) , which is expressed when the cell reaches the stationary phase of growth and inhibits carnitine metabolism ( Eichler et al. , 1996 ) . [14595781]
  • It is therefore tempting to speculate that MalT might activate transcription initiation by a mechanism different from that used by CI or CRP to activate PR or lacZp ( de Crombrugghe et al. , 1984 ; Ptashne , 1986 ) . [2524384]
  • Furthermore , FNR-AR1 is proposed to interact with the a-C-terminal domain ( a-CTD ) of RNAP to activate transcription as has been observed with CRP ( Ebright , 1993 ; Busby and Ebright , 1997 ; Williams et al. , 1997 ) . [11115116]
  • This is surprising because it was expected that tandem-bound FNR dimers would act synergistically to activate transcription , as has been reported for the closely related transcription factor CRP ( Savery et al. , 1996 ) . [11169114]
  • However , it is possible that the change in transcription activity of PguaB in a fis background occurs as a result of altered regulation of PguaB by a transcription factor other than CRP , for example H-NS or HU ( Claret & Rouviere-Yaniv , 1996 ; Falconi et al. , 1996 ) or by changes in supercoiling ( Schneider et al. , 1997 ; Weinstein-Fischer et al. , 2000 ) . [18524927]
  • Fis transcription is subject to a plethora of control mechanisms including , autoregulation , stringent control , the availability of its initiating NTP and the CRP transcription factor ( Ball et al. , 1992 ; Ninnemann et al. , 1992 ; Nasser et al. , 2001 ; Walker and Osuna , 2002 ; Mallik et al. , 2004 ; Walker et al. , 2004 ) . [17233826]
  • Results Our previous studies revealed that cells regulate acs transcription through the combined action of multiple proteins , including , but not limited to , IHF and CRP ( Kumari et al. , 2000a ; Browning et al. , 2002 ; 2004 ; 2005 ; 2006 ; Beatty et al. , 2003 ) . [17630973]
  • Expression of FlhDC is tightly regulated by multiple transcription factors , including CRP , H-NS and OmpR , and hence the genes of the ﬂagellar cascade are regulated in response to many different environmental inputs ( Shin and Park , 1995 ; Sout-ourina et al. , 1999 ) . [19843224]
  • More than ten transcription regulators including EvgA , YdeO , GadE , TorR , H-NS , PhoP , RpoS , CRP , MnmE , GadX , and GadW have been found to participate in the regulation of gadE during various circumstances of acid stresses through at least ﬁve different regulatory circuits ( Ma et al. , 2004 ; Sayed and Foster , 2009 ) . [23874328]
  • These results , in conjunction with those from footprint analysis , suggest that CRP and FIS can bind simultaneously to CRP II , FIS II and CRP I. IHF binds the acs regulatory region simultaneously with either CRP or FIS Previously , we showed that IHF in vitro binds to a DNA site ( IHF I ) that overlaps acsP1 and in vivo represses transcription from both acsP1 and pnrfA ( Browning et al. , 2002 ) . [14651625]
  • To achieve maximal transcription , however , a second dimer also must bind to CRP II , the distal , lower-affinity site ( Beatty et al. , 2003 ) . [17630973]
  • CRP binding upstream of aer was ﬁrst detected by Grainger et al. ( 2005 ) in a whole genome chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis , and it was subsequently shown that CRP activates transcription by binding to a single DNA site in the aer regulatory region ( Hollands et al. , 2007 ) . [19843224]
  • However , the position of the CRP site 1 , which is centred on position − 76.5 , is not expected to allow direct contacts with the polymerase : when acting alone , CRP indeed activates initiation of transcription by contacting the polymerase , but its ability to activate requires its binding site be located on the same face of the DNA helix as the polymerase binding site , i.e. at positions − 41.5 , − 61.5 , − 71.5 , − 82.5 or − 92.521 bp ( Gaston et al. , 1990 ; Ushida & Aiba , 1990 ; Valentin-Hansen et al. , 1991 ) . [9000616]
  • In a study by Gaston et al. ( 19 ) , CRP binding at the 83.5 center position did not lead to any CRP activation . [24509317]
  • We have also examined the reciprocal co-dependence of binding of CaiF and CRP , which are both absolutely required for the activation of transcription of the two operons ( Buchet et al. , 1998 ) . [10564497]
  • Regarding this sites we note that its location is suboptimal for CRP-mediated transcription activation ( Gaston et al. , 1990 ) and , furthermore , it contains suboptimal ﬂanking sequences for bending , and thus for binding of CRP ( Gar-tenberg and Crothers , 1988 ) . [22250746]
  • SELEX-clos allows the screening of DNA sequences with high afﬁnity to the test transcription factor , but it is not practical for identiﬁcation of the whole set of its binding targets because the number of isolated clones correlates with the binding afﬁnity as demonstrated for a variety of transcription factors such as Cra , CRP , and LeuO ( Shimada et al. 2009 , 2011a , b ) . [23233451]
  • In summary , during the early stages of exponential phase , FIS inhibits acs transcription by steric hindrance of CRP binding ( Browning et al. , 2004 ) . [17630973]
  • Mutants of CRP that bind to the target site on the DNA , but fail to activate transcription ( positive control or pc mutants ) , have been used to show that a particular region ( activating region I , ARI ) located at the surface of the known structure of the CRP dimer is responsible for activation at lac-type promoters ( Bell et al. , 1990 ; Eschenlauer & Reznikoff , 1991 ; Williams et al. , 1991 ; Zhou et al. , 1993 ) . [8952481]
  • A variety of evidence indicates that transcriptional activation by CRP at both Class I and II promoters involves direct contact with RNA polymerase , including the identification of amino acid substitutions in CRP which result in retention of DNA binding but which can not activate transcription ( reviewed by Ishihama , 1992 ; Ebright , 1993 ; Busby and Ebright , 1994 ; Busby et al. , 1995 ) . [8748035]
  • Despite the loose distance requirement , activation of transcription can take place only when CRP and RNA polymerase bind to the same face of the DNA helix ( Gaston et al. , 1990 ; Ushida and Aiba , 1990 ) . [8895588]
  • Our in vitro studies have shown that MelR alone binds to site 1 cents , site 1 and site 2 , but that occupation of site 2 cents , which is essential for transcription activation , requires the presence of melibiose and CRP ( Williams et al. , 1994 ; Belyaeva et al. , 2000 ) . [12675795]
  • These results verify that activation of acsP2 transcription requires CRP I ( Beatty et al. , 2003 ) and shows that IHF-dependent inhibition requires CRP II . [17630973]
  • In vivo studies have clearly established that both CRP and CaiF are required for the activation of transcription of the cai and ® x operons ( Eichler et al. , 1995 ; 1996 ) . [10564497]
  • Similarly , activation of transcription in vivo required CRP , its AR1 surface and an intact CRP I. On the basis of these observations , we proposed that CRP ` focused ' RNAP to acsP2 ( Beatty et al. , 2003 ) . [17630973]
  • This is consistent with previous observations ( West et aL , 1993 ) that these substitutions suppress at Class II promoters where CRP is bound around - 4 1 , but not at Class I promoters where CRP is bound further upstream . [8748035]
  • This is in contrast to the situation at previously studied Class I and Class II CRP-dependent promoters where the optimal locations for activation by CRP are positions -61.5 and -41.5 respectively , and where CRP activates only very weakly when bound to a site centred near position -50 ( Gaston et al. , 1990 ) . [19843224]
  • In conclusion , the structure of the cdd promoter supports and extends the idea that CytR and CRP are rivals and , consequently , that bound CytR repressor inhibits RNA synthesis by antagonizing CRP activation -LCB- Martinussen et al. . [2575702]
  • In support of this model , Dethiollaz et al. ( 1996 ) have recently detected such DNA ± RNAP interactions in the transcriptional activation process mediated by CRP at the malT promoter . [9512708]
  • In the case of the lac promoter , a surface-exposed loop around amino acids 158-161 of CRP constitutes an activating region ( ARI ) essential for transcriptional activation ( Bell et al. , 1990 ; Eschenlauer and Reznikoff , 1991 ; Zhou et al. , 1993 ) . [8895588]
  • Binding reactions contained 5 ml of each DNA template ( 20 nM ) in buffer B ( without DTT ) and 5 ml of 400 nM CRP or buffer A and were kept at room temperature for 15 min ( this CRP concentration was previously found to be optimal for activation of the csiD promoter ; Marschall et al. , 1998 ) . [11532138]

  • At the divergently transcribed malE , malK promoter , the active form of the CRP protein is also required for transcriptional activation ( Raibaud et al. , 1989 ) . [9822819]
  • IHF has the ability to bend DNA to a similar degree as does CRP ( Kosturko et al. , 1988 ) and thus allowed us to analyse the respective contributions of protein-protein contacts and DNA curvature to the mechanism of transcriptional activation by CRP . [8895588]
  • The latter would be consistent with the ® nding that EsS can also support CRP activation ( albeit less ef ® ciently than Es70 ) of the galp1 and lac promo-ters , where CRP boxes are centered around ÿ41 .5 and ÿ61 .5 , respectively ( Kolb et al. , 1995 ; Tanaka et al. , 1995 ) . [9512707]
  • The H1 59L mutation in ARI drastically affects transcriptional activation by CRP ( Bell et al. , 1990 ; Zhou et al. , 1993 ) . [8895588]
  • Elegant studies by Raibaud , Richet and colleagues have shown that CRP serves to reposition MalT to an alternative set of T boxes that results in activation ( Richet et al. , 1991 ; Richet and Sogaard , 1994 ) . [9822819]
  • Peaks of maximal transcriptional activation occur in ViVo when CRP is bound at positions -60.5 , -71.5 and -81.5 ( Déthiollaz et al. , 1996 ) . [8952481]
  • Merkel et al. ( 17 ) found that CRP AR1 substitutions were not defective for uhpT activation , suggesting that CRP activation of uhpT does not depend on the previously deﬁned a-CTD -- AR1 interactions . [10852886]
  • Their activation depends on the synergistic action of MalT , the activator of the maltose regulon ( Schwartz , 1987 ) , and CRP , a global regulator controlling the utilization of carbon sources ( Kolb et al. , 1993 ) . [9000616]
  • Activation by CRP is strongest at the positions corresponding to the natural promoters lac and malT Comparison of the -81.5 activation peak with natural promoters is difficult because such promoters are generally activated by CRP only in conjunction with a secondary activator ( Kolb et al. , 1993a ) . [8895588]

  • CyaR is positively regulated by cyclic AMP and CRP , while Spot 42 is negatively regulated ( Møller et al. , 2002 ; Johansen et al. , 2008 ; Papenfort et al. , 2008 ; De Lay and Gottesman , 2009 ) . [22040174]
  • Furthermore , the ACS enzyme is positively regulated by CRP ( generating acetyl-CoA ) , high levels of AMP , and FNR ( at low oxygen partial pressure ) , whereas it is negatively regulated by the j2 factor ( Kumari et al. , 2000 ) . [14595781]
  • These sites are designated CRP-S sites because although CRP can still bind to these sites with low affinity , CRP alone is not sufficient to induce expression from promoters containing CRP-S sites , but also requires Sxy ( Redﬁeld et al. , 2005 ; Cameron and Redﬁeld , 2006 ; 2008 ) . [25491382]
  • In contrast to other maltose operon promoters , which are regulated only by MalT : malEp and malKp are also positively controlled by CRP , a pleiotropic regulator involved in the control of carbon source utilization ( De Crombrugghe et al. , 1984 ; Chapon , 1982 ; Richet & Raibaud , 1987 ) . [2538630]
  • This simultaneous CRP control is not unique to the mhp pathway , since it has been also described for the genes for propionate catabolism in E. coli and Salmonella enterica ( Lee et al. , 2005 ) and for some regulons from E. coli such as those for L-rhamnose ( Holcroft & Egan , 2000 ; Wickstrum et al. , 2005 ) , melibiose ( Webster et al. , 1988 ; Belyaeva et al. , 2000 ) and maltose ( Chapon & Kolb , 1983 ; Richet & Sogaard-Andersen , 1994 ; Richet , 2000 ) . [20966094]
  • Results Two global regulators , CRP and Cra , of E. coli recognize and regulate as many as 378 and 164 promoters , respectively , of the genes for carbon source utilization ( Shimada et al. , 2005 , 2011a , 2011b ) . [24814025]
  • CRP activates transcription from over 150 different promoters in E. coli ( Kolb et al. , 1993 ; Zheng et al. , 2004 ) and this CRP regulon includes several operons mainly involved in catabolism of carbon sources other than glucose ( Kolb et al. , 1993 ) . [20966094]
  • Involvement of EvgA , YdeO , H-NS , CRP , GadX , as well as a small RNA DsrA in the regulation of the mdtEF gene in the same operon has also been reported ( Nishino and Yamaguchi , 2002 , 2004 ; Oshima et al. , 2006 ; Nishino et al. , 2008a , b , 2009 , 2011 ) . [23874328]
  • INVOLVEMENT OF DIFFERENT REGULATORS IN THE ANAEROBIC EXPRESSION OF mdtEF FROM THAT OF AEROBIC CONDITION Previous studies focusing on the expression of gadE-mdtEF operon during acid resistance have revealed that several regulators , such as EvgA , YdeO , MnmE , GadE , GadX , CRP , and H-NS , are involved in the regulation of gadE-mdtEF operon ( Gong et al. , 2004 ; Ma et al. , 2004 ; Hirakawa et al. , 2006 ; Tramonti et al. , 2008 ) . [23874328]
  • FruR ( Cra ) is a transcriptional-regulator which , together with CRP , controls the expression of genes involved in C metabolism , particularly with respect to the direction of metabolic flow , glycolysis being repressed whereas gluconeogenesis is activated ( Ramseier et al. , 1993 ; Saier & Ramseier , 1996 ) . [9421904]
  • M o r e recently , studies with lac2 fusions have shown that sdh gene expression is anaerobically repressed some 70-fold by the combined effects of ArcA and FNR , a n d repressed up to threefold by glucose in a CRP - ( and FruR - ) independent manner ( Iuchi et al. , 1994 ; Park et al. , 1995 ) . [9720032]
  • For example , the oxidative acid resistance system is regulated by rs and CRP ( Foster 2004 ) , and rs regulates both gene expression for osmotic stress ( Hengge-Aronis 1996 ) and regulates many acid resistance genes including the uncharacterized ygiW and yodD genes ( Weber et al. 2005 ) identiﬁed in this study . [19919618]
  • With increasing acetate formation , expression of many genes known to be differentially expressed in glucose-grown and acetate-grown cells ( Oh et al. 2002 ) or in cells lacking CRP ( Gosset et al. 2004 ) decreased . [17273855]
  • For example , the PEP carboxykinase gene pckA , the tryptophanase gene tnaA , and the aspartase gene aspA showed lower expression when acetate is formed in overflow metabolism ( Fig. 1 ) and their expression is lower in glucose-grown cells than in acetate-grown cells ( Oh et al. 2002 ) and it is lower in cells lacking CRP ( Gosset et al. 2004 ) .   • Conclusions Members of the LacI -- GalR family of transcriptional-repressors are usually functional as dimers , although in some cases , repression depends on the dimerization of dimers or interactions with other proteins , such as CRP ( Weickert & Adhya , 1992 ; Valentin-Hansen et al. , 1996 ) . [20141531]
  • CRP regulation There are experimental data showing that the expression of gntKU and gntT from the GntR regulon and uxuAB from the UxuR/ExuR regulon is under catabolite repression by CRP ( Izu et al. , 1997 ; Peekhaus and Conway , 1998b ) . [11115104]
  • In E. coli , CRP is the global regulator of catabolite repression and previously was shown to negatively regulate Spot 42 RNA and positively regulate CyaR RNA expression ( De Lay & Gottesman , 2009 , Johansen et al. , 2008 , Polayes et al. , 1988 , Papenfort et al. , 2008 ) . [22289118]
  • In the previous paper , we showed that the intracellular CRP level is markedly reduced by glucose and that this reduction in CRP level is an important determinant of catabolite repression ( Ishizuka et al. , 1993 ) . [7518773]
  • Gosset et al completed a similar in vivo transcriptomic study of CRP and identiﬁed 39 operons under CRP-dependent glucose repression and 19 operons under CRP-dependent glucose activation . [15520470]
  • One-third of operons subject to CRP-dependent glucose repression ( 13/39 ) in Gosset et al. were activated by CRP in ROMA experiment . [15520470]

  • Keywords : CRP -- FNR protein superfamily , iron -- sulphur proteins , transcriptional regulation , nitrogen starvation , stationary phase INTRODUCTION The CRP -- FNR family of transcription regulators contains at least 70 members that respond to a variety of metabolic and environmental signals to control a diverse range of physiological functions in an equally diverse range of bacteria ( Spiro , 1994 ; Guest et al. , 1996 ; Vollack et al. , 1999 ) . [11101674]
  • The inability of CRP to activate malEp on its own is most likely due to the fact that none of the CRP sites is located at a permissive position ( Figure 1 ; Gaston et al. , 1990 ; Ushida & Aiba , 1990 ; Valentin-Hansen et al. , 1991 ) . [9000616]
  • The role of IHF has remained less clear : while in vitro it is known to-bind simultaneously with CRP and to cause inhibition of acsP2 transcription , in vivo the upstream sequence containing the three IHF sites has a positive effect on transcription ( Browning et al. , 2004 ) . [17630973]

[1848302]
  • The position of these sites and the involvement of certain CRP and RNAP surfaces support a mechanism by which tandem CRP proteins synergistically activate acsP2 transcription ( Beatty et al. , 2003 ) . [14651625]
  • The major effect of CRP at the gal promoter is acceleration of the rate of isomerization to the open complex ( increase in k2 ) ( Herbert et al. , 1986 ) . [8952481]

  • It has been shown previously that , in the presence of an UP-element immediately downstream of the CRP box , CC promoter activity obtained with Es is approximately 70 ﬁvefold higher when the CRP box was located at 269.5 than at 272.5 or even 261.5 , i.e. the presence of a full UP-element shifted the optimum for CRP box location to 269.5 ( Law et al. , 1999 ) . [11532138]
  • It has been shown that relief of H-NS-mediated hlyE silencing by SlyA is much less efficient in the absence of CRP as the hlyE promoter normally needs CRP or FNR to be activated to higher levels ( Westermark et al. , 2000 ; Wyborn et al. , 2004b ) . [17892462]

[17273855]

  • This promoter is controlled by a number of global regulators such as CRP ( Yokota and Gots , 1970 ; Silverman and Simon , 1974 ) , heat-shock proteins DnaK , DnaJ and GrpE ( Shi et al. , 1992 ) and H-NS ( Bertin et al. , 1994 ; Kutsukake , 1997 ; Yanagihara et al. , 1999 ) , as well as by several environmental signals such as temperature control ( Qualding and Stocker , 1962 ; Adler and Templeton , 1967 ) , high concentrations of inorganic salts , carbohydrates or alcohols ( Li et al. , 1993 ; Shi et al. , 1993 ) , growth-phase ( Nishimura and Hirota , 1989 ) , DNA supercoiling ( Li et al. , 1993 ; Shi et al. , 1993 ; Kutsukake , 1997 ; Das et al. , 1998 ) , phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylglycerol synthesis ( Shi et al. , 1993 ; Mizushima et al. , 1995 ) , cell cycle control ( Morgan et al. , 1995 ; Prüß and Matsumura , 1996 ; Mizushima et al. , 1997 ) and quorum sensing ( Sperandio et al. , 2002 ) . [11929534]
  • In those bacteria that possess more than one member of the DNR/FLP subgroup , problems due to cross-talk may not arise because the regulators appear to be expressed in response to different environmental stimuli ( Vollack et al. , 1999 ) and their active forms may therefore never coexist Despite possessing the same structural framework , differences in primary structure between CRP and FNR within , and probably outside , the DNA-recognition helix may sufficiently alter DNA-target recognition such that CRP and FNR are able to regulate distinct modulons whilst sharing the same cytoplasm . [11407111]
  • Concerning the regulation of CRP synthesis in vivo , early immunological studies suggested that the levels of CRP in cells do not vary under different genetic and nutritional conditions ( Guiso and Blazy , 1980 ; Guiso et ai , 1982 ) , However , the existence of the complex autoregulatory mechanisms of the crp gene suggests that CRP synthesis should be controlled and the levels of CRP may vary according to growth conditions . [1328816]

  • Thus , it is concluded that ArcA , CRP , Fis , FNR , H-NS , IHF and Lrp are truly global regulators , at least as far as the response to oxygen availability is concerned , in the sense that their outputs create the transcriptional framework upon which local regulators operate in response to specific unstable environments Table 1 . [22870390]
  • Such is the case for complex II in E. coli , with the complex II bio-synthetic operon ( sdhCDAB ) being negatively regulated by ArcAB and FNR in response to oxygen conditions ( i.e. anaerobic ) and positively regulated by CRP in the absence of glucose [ 108 -- 110 ] . [22985599]
  • Transcriptional monocopy lacZ fusion studies showed that both operons are coexpressed during anaerobic-growth in the presence of carnitine , respond to common environmental stimuli ( like glucose and nitrate ) , and are modulated positively by the same general regulators , CRP and FNR , and negatively by H-NS .   • However , when using a CTD deletion mutant RNAP ( 1 -- 235 ) , CRP neither activated lacP1-6 nor repressed lacP1-6S1 ( lanes 5 -- 8 ) , suggesting that CRP - CTD interaction is also needed for CRP repression at lacP1-6S1 . [15385551]
  • An CTD-deleted mutant RNAP abolished not only the enhancement of transcription from the pa-rental lacP1-6 promoter but also CRP-mediated repression of transcription at lacP1-6S1 , suggesting that an CRP - CTD interaction is also the basis of repression at lacP1-6S1 . [15385551]

  • Factors required for motility and full flhDC expression include cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) and cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ; Kutsukake , 1997 ; Soutourina et al. , 1999 ) , histone-like nucleoid-structuring ( H-NS ) protein ( Bertin et al. , 1994 ) , the heat-shock response network proteins DnaK , DnaJ and GrpE ( Shi et al. , 1992 ) , Pss and Psd , which are involved in the synthesis of phosphatidy-lethanolamine in cell membranes ( Shi et al. , 1993 ) , and inorganic polyphosphate ( Rashid et al. , 2000 ) . [11298291]
  • In addition to the transcription activators RhaS and RhaR , the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) is also required for the full activation of all three of the rha operons ( Egan and Schleif , 1993 ; Holcroft and Egan , 2000 ; Via et al. , 1996 ) . [18366439]
  • In the absence of glucose and/or other PTS sugars , the phosphorylated form of Crr may be accumulated in the cell , and , in connection , it is suggested that the phosphorylated Crr activates adenylate cyclase to raise the synthesis rate of cAMP ( Postma et al. , 1993 ) , which is needed for CRP to activate the transcription of many other transport protein genes . [8729576]
  • Furthermore , cAMP -- CRP is reported to be a repressor of its own transcription ( Aiba , 1983 ; Cossart and Gicquel-Sanzey , 1985 ; Okamoto and Freundlich , 1986 ; Hanamura and Aiba , 1991 ) , of genes for adenylate cyclase ( Majerfeld et al. , 1981 ; Mori and Aiba , 1985 ) , of genes encoding enzymes participating in glutamine metabolism ( Prusiner et al. , 1972 ) and of genes for the outer membrane protein III ( Mallick and Herrlich , 1979 ) . [9582281]
  • These include the transcription factor FNR that mediates anaerobic regulation ( Unden and Schirawski , 1997 ) , the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , which activates transcription of catabolic operons ( Kolb et al. , 1993 ) , and the nucleoid-associated protein H-NS ( Atlung and Ingmer , 1997 ) . [10564497]
  • In enteric bacteria , it acts as an allosteric-effector of the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) and is essential for the regulation of the transcription of a large number of genes ( reviewed by Botsford and Harman 1992 ; Kolb et al. 1993 ) . [9003304]
  • The cAMP receptor protein , CRP , is required for activation of ptsG transcription ( De Reuse and Danchin , 1988 ; Fox et al. , 1992 ) , whereas the negative regulatory protein Mlc represses ptsG transcription in the absence of glucose ( Kimata et al. , 1998 ; Plumbridge , 1998 ) . [15522088]
  • The ptsG transcription is regulated simultaneously by two global transcription factors , CRP ( cAMP receptor protein ) -- cAMP and Mlc , in response to glucose availability ( Kimata et al. 1997 , 1998 ) . [15650111]
  • The cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) - AMPc complex activates transcription of many gluconeogenic genes such as acs , actP , aceBAK and maeB [ Gosset et al. , 2004 ] . [18679018]
  • For induction , all three operons require ( a ) the L-arabinose-specific positive regulatory protein , AraC ( b ) the catabolite gene activator protein ( CAP ; also referred to as the cAMP receptor protein , CRP ) , ( c ) and cAMP ( Greenblatt and Schleif 1971 ; Englesberg and Wil-cox 1974 ; Lee et al. 1974 ; Kolodrubetz and Schleif 1981 ) . [2997582]
  • Although the precise mechanism of transcriptional regulation has yet to be elucidated , it has been established that the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , integration host factor and two proteins , termed TdcR and TdcA , are necessary for positive regulation ( Wu et al. , 1992 ; Hagewood et al. , 1994 ) . [11251844]
  • Transcription of the gcv operon is under the control of three global regulatory proteins [ Lrp , PurR and cAMP-receptor protein ( CRP ) ] and two gcv-speciﬁc transcriptional-regulatory proteins ( GcvA and GcvR ) ( Ghrist & Stauffer , 1995 ; Lin et al. , 1992 ; Stauffer & Stauffer , 1994 ; Wilson et al. , 1993a ; Wilson & Stauffer , 1994 ; Wonderling & Stauffer , 1999 ) . [12101307]
  • Known regulators involved in the control of acs expression in E. coli are cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , factor for inversion stimulation ( Fis ) , integration host factor ( IHF ) ( Wolfe 2005 ) and possibly the dual transcriptional-regulator for an-oxic redox control ( ArcA ) ( Covert et al. 2004 ) . [24633370]
  • The E. coli cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) is a global transcriptional-regulator that can serve as an activator , repressor , coactivator , and corepressor ( Kallipolitis et al. 1997 ; Busby and Ebright 1999 ) . [12101127]
  • Introduction cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) is the best characterized global transcriptional-regulator in Escherichia coli ( Kolb et al. , 1993 ; Busby & Ebright , 1999 ; Harman , 2001 ) . [24814025]
  • The cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) also plays a role in this RpoS-GadX pathway by tempering expression of RpoS during growth under conditions that result in high cAMP levels ( Ma et al. , 2003b ) . [19220752]
  • ftnA -- lacZ expression is dependent on the growth-phase , iron and Fur The cAMP-receptor protein ( CRP ) does not control ftnA or fur expression It was previously reported that the fur gene is induced approximately fourfold during post-exponential-growth in rich medium in a manner that is largely dependent on the cAMP -- CRP ( cAMP-receptor protein ) complex ( de Lorenzo et al. , 1988 ) . [20015147]
  • In enteric bacteria , expression of the pts operon increases during growth-on-glucose and requires an intact cAMP ± cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) system , although growth-on-glucose reduces the concentration of cAMP and CRP in the cell ( Postma et al. , 1993 ) . [11157755]
  • In this paper , we report that a sequence-specific binding protein , the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , whose primary function is to control transcription as a function of catabolite conditions ( de Crombrugghe et al. 1984 ; Kolb et al. 1993 ) , can also function as an osmoregulator of gene expression . [10601034]
  • We had shown previously that the Pa and Pz promoters of the two PA catabolic operons in E. coli were under control of global regulators such as the cyclic adenosine monophosphate ( cAMP ) receptor protein ( CRP ) , that accounts for the catabolite repression control mediated by glucose , and the integration host factor ( IHF ) ( Ferrández et al. , 2000 ) . [24983528]
  • Superimposed in the specific PaaX-mediated repression , two global regulators , the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) and the integration host factor protein ( IHF ) , act as activators of the gene expression driven by Pa and Pz promoters . [10766858]
  • Cra mediates catabolite repression or catabolite activation depending on the target gene era controls gene expression in vivo Expression of the negatively Cra-regulated pykF gene and the positively Cra-regulated ppsA gene was recently studied as a function of carbon source Beta-galactosidase activity measurement of singlecopy , chromosomal fusions of these genes to lacZ in E. coli strains wild-type for or lacking the Cra protein showed that Cra controls the response to carbon source independently of the cAMP-cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) complex ( Bledig et al. , 1996 ; T.M. Ramseier and M.H. Saier , Jr. , unpublished results ) . [9084760]
  • Because the glucose repression effect is usually mediated by the cAMP -- CRP complex in enteric bacteria ( Kolb et al. , 1993 ; Saier et al. , 1996 ) , we checked whether CRP was required for mhpR expression by using an E. coli strain lacking CRP protein . [20966094]
  • Expression of Pa promoter is also influenced by the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , which allows expression of the mhp catabolic genes when the preferred carbon source ( glucose ) is not available but 3HPP is present in the medium ( Fig. 1A ) . [19520845]

  • 32 , No. 19 doi :10.1093 / nar/gkh908 Identification of the CRP regulon using in vitro and in vivo transcriptional profiling Dongling Zheng , Chrystala Constantinidou * , Jon L. Hobman and Stephen D. Minchin School of Biosciences , University of Birmingham , Birmingham B15 2TT , UK Received July 2 , 2004 ; Revised September 3 , 2004 ; Accepted October 7 , 2004 ABSTRACT The Escherichia coli cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) is a global regulator that controls transcription initiation from more than 100 promoters by binding to a specific DNA sequence within cognate promoters . [15520470]
  • INTRODUCTION The cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP or CAP ) of Escherichia coli is a sequence-specific DNA binding protein which regulates transcription of a number of genes in response to the carbon source ( 1-3 ) . [1715982]
  • The effects of 11 mutations within the DNA region thought to-bind the cyclic AMP receptor protein correlate well with the CRP consensus binding sequence and confirm that this region is responsible for cyclic AMP regulation . [1400237]
  • The acceleration of Fur proteolysis in the presence of metal is analogous to the behavior of the E. coli CRP protein : cyclic AMP binding to the N-terminal domain of CRP induces protease sensitivity in the C-terminal DNA-binding domain ( Heyduk & Lee , 1989 ) . [1868094]
  • Its expression is also dependent on the global regulatory proteins mediating catabolic repression via cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , or anaerobiosis via fumarate nitrate reduction ( FNR ) transcriptional-regulator , and the nucleoid-associated DNA-binding protein H-NS . [8631699]
  • It is structurally-related to CRP ( the cyclic AMP receptor protein ) except for the presence of a cysteine-rich / V-terminat extension , which may form part of an iron-binding , redox-sensing domain in FNR . [8497198]
  • Transcription of the glp operons is subject to multiple controls , including catabolite repression mediated by cyclic AMP-CRP and respiratory control mediated by the FNR and ArcA/ArcB systems ( 19 , 28 ) . [8955387]
  • Expression of the gal operon is regulated by cellular levels of CAMP and the CAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) through the mechanism of catabolite repression ( for review , see de Crumbrugghe and Pastan , 1978 ) . [7023696]
  • The synthesis of PM1 is probably subject to catabolite repression mediated by CAMP and the CAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) . [6397402]
  • The dcuB gene is strongly activated anaerobically by FNR , repressed in the presence of nitrate by NarL , and subject to cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) - mediated catabolite repression . [9852003]
  • Regulation studies with a dctA-lacZ ( f428-lacZ ) transcriptional fusion showed that dctA is subject to cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) - dependent catabolite repression and ArcA-mediated anaerobic repression and is weakly induced by the DcuS-DcuR system in response to C4-dicarboxylates and citrate . [10482502]
  • Growth with glucose causes catabolite repression , one manifestation of which is lowered CRP protein activity ( due to lowered cyclic AMP [ for a review , see reference 21 ] ) . [1629153]
  • Transcription of these operons is sensitive to catabolite repression and requires cyclic AMP and the catabolite repressor protein CRP . [10094697]

  • Based on these results , we propose the following model for transcriptional regulation of crp and divergent promoters -LCB- Fig. 9 ) , Three extreme states are characterized by the concentrations of CRP and cAMP , In the absence of the CRP-cAMP complex -LCB- A ) , only the crp promoter is functional and RNA polymerase transcribes crp at a basal level .   • Thus , the divergent promoter is activated and the crp promoter is inhibited , since RNA polymerase occupancies at two promoters are mutually exclusive -LCB- Hanamura and Aiba , 1991 ) , At higher concentrations of CRP-cAMP ( C ) , the complex also binds to CRP site II . [1328816]
  • In the presence of CRP-cAMP , the complex first binds to CRP site I to direct RNA polymerase to the divergent promoter , At this stage the divergent gene is activated and the crp gene is repressed ( B ) , In the presence of higher concentrations ot CRP-cAMP , CRP site II becomes occupied by CRP-cAMP , This causes again repositioning of RNA polymerase resulting in the activation of crp transcription ( C ) , RNA polymetase CRP site I B Experimental procedures Proteins and chemicais RNA polymerase was purified from E co/f strain W3350 essentially according to the method of Fukuda etai .   • In the absence of cAMP , no specific peaks were identified for CRP ( Fig. 1 , open circles ; but note that open circles are hidden behind closed circles ) , indicating that the peaks thus identified represent specific binding of cAMP-bound CRP . [21673794]
  • In the presence of both CRP and cAMP , we could observe CRP-bound complexes ( Fig. 3b ) , but the CRP-DNA complexes could not be observed in the absence of cAMP ( Fig. 3a ) . [24814025]
  • In the absence of CytR , cAMP-CRP interacts at one set of sites ( CRP-1 and CRP-2 ) and both of these binding sites are required for full promoter activation . [1327747]
  • In the absence of the CytR repressor , cAMP-CRP binds to two targets ( CRP-1 and CRP-2 ; Figure 1 ) and it is evident from our analysis of deletion mutants that the high affinity site , CRP-1 , is the essential site for promoter activation ( Table IA ) . [1327747]

[1649947]
  • In this context it should be noted that the dependence of CytR on cAMP-CRP is in striking contrast to the action of the classical bacterial repressors , which appear to regulate promoter activity in the absence of additional regulator proteins ( for reviews , see Adhya 1989 ; Gralla 1989 ) . [1661372]

  • Binding of cAMP - CRP and CytR to wild-type and mutant promoters In order to investigate the interaction of cAMP-CRP and CytR with cddP and to define the role of the different protein binding sites , we performed DNase I footprinting experiments on 32P-end-labelled fragments in the presence of purified proteins . [1327747]
  • These observations are not easily explained by current models for the action of pro-karyotic repressors ; instead we favour a model in which the interaction of CytR with deoP2 depends on the presence of tandem DNA-bound cAMP-CRP complexes . [1962841]
  • Hence , CytR relies on interactions with DNA-bound cAMP-CRP complexes in order to-bind strongly to deoP2 , and cAMP-CRP may be viewed as an adaptor that allows CytR to associate with deoP2 ( 10 ) . [1647022]
  • 1989 ; L. Sogaard-Andersen and P. Valentin-Hansen , in prepar-ation ) , strongly indicate that the structure recognized by CytR includes tandem DNA-bound cAMP-CRP complexes . [1962841]
  • The region protected from DNase I by formation of the CRP -- CytR -- DNA complex corresponds to the combined footprint of cAMP -- CRP and CytR . [9466254]
  • The inducer for the CytR repressor , cytidine , does not prevent in vitro DNA binding of CytR , but releases the repressor from the nucleoprotein complex and leaves the cAMP-CRP activator bound to its two DNA targets . [1715855]
  • In this paper , we show that the cAMP-CRP complex is indeed a crucial component of fhe CytR repression apparatus , and that CyfR relies on interactions with DNA-bound activator proteins in order to-bind at deoP2 . [1649947]
  • Detailed investigation of the deo operon has shown that cAMP-CRP and CytR bind cooperatively to the deoP2 promoter forming a nucleoprotein complex in which CytR is sandwiched between two DNA-bound cAMP-CRP complexes . [1327747]
  • Summary Repression by CytR depends on the formation of nucleoprotein complexes in which the CytR repressor and the cAMP-CRP activator complex bind cooperatively to the DNA . [8596434]
  • Therefore , in the mobility shift assay , CytR and one cAMP-CRP complex still bind co-operatively to the DNA . [8596434]
  • CytR simultaneously makes specific DNA contacts as well as protein-protein contacts to cAMP-CRP in the repression complexes ( Pedersen et ai , 1991 ; Sogaard-Andersen and ValentinHansen . [7715459]
  • It has consistently been shown that CytR and cAMP-CRP bind cooperatively to deoP2 forming a nucleoprotein complex in which the repressor protein bridges the tandem DNA-bound cAMP-CRP ( Pedersen et al. , et complexes 1991 ; S0gaard-Andersen al. , The 1991a , b ) . [1327747]
  • These results are similar to those reported for deoP2 ( Pedersen et al. , 1991 ) and the in vitro analyses strongly indicate that the same type of repression complex , consisting of CytR sandwiched between tandem DNA-bound cAMP-CRP complexes , is involved in negative regulation of these two promoters . [1327747]
  • Taken together , these data point to a strong coupling between D N A binding of cAMP-CRP and the extent of CytR regulation in deoP2 , and , thus , strongly corroborate the conclusion obtained from in vitro experiments that CytR relies on interaction with tandem DNA-bound cAMP-CRP complexes in order to-bind to deoP2 D N A ( Sogaard-Andersen et al. 1991 ) . [1661372]

  • Binding of cAMP-CRP is , however , enhanced by the CytR extract ( Fig. 2 , right panel ; compare lanes 4-6 with lanes 7-9 ; see also Fig. 4 , right panel ) . [1649947]

  • Initiation of transcription from deoP2 is negatively controlled by two repressors , DeoR and CytR , and is also dependent on the cAMP/CRP complex Location of transcription terminators in the 3 ' - end of the deo operon In order to locate termination signals , we inserted restriction fragments from the 3 ' - end of the deo operon between the deoP2 promoter and the lacZ gene of pJEL144 . [3299264]
  • Unlike the other members of this protein family , CytR binds with only modest afﬁnity to its operators and transcription repression thus relies on the formation of nucleoprotein complexes with the cAMP -- CRP complex . [9466254]
  • Thus , CytR does not regulate transcription from deoP2 in cells depleted for the cAMP-CRP complex ( Acya or Acrp strains ) , even when the level of the repressor in the cells is high ( Sogaard-Andersen et a / . [1649947]
  • As shown in Table 1 , initiation of transcription is regulated strongly both by the CytR repressor ( 40-fold ) and by the cAMP / CRP complex ( 100-fold ) . [2575702]
  • Release of CytR from the nucleoprotein complex in response to cytidine leaves the cAMP-CRP activator complex bound to tSx-p2 , which will allow immediate stimulation of transcription . [1715855]
  • Speciﬁcally , CytR has a relaxed spacing requirement between operator half-sites and can , in concert with cAMP -- CRP , repress transcription in vivo from octamer boxes separated with centre distances up to three helical turns . [9466254]
  • At P1 and P2 transcription is repressed by the DeoR repressor and induced by deoxyribo-se-5-P ; at P2 transcription is also repressed by the CytR repressor ( the inducer being cytidine or adenosine ) and depends on cAMP and CRP . [2994018]
  • Addition of increasing amounts of CytR to transcription assays containing cAMP ± CRP gradually decreased transcription ( Figure 5 , middle panel ) . [11574471]
  • Thus , it appears that CytR ± CRP communication at deoP2 also affected the cAMP ± CRP-independent transcription . [11574471]
  • In the absence of cAMP ± CRP , addition of CytR had no effect on deoP2 transcription ( Figure 5 , left panel ) . [11574471]
  • In the presence of the cAMP-CRP complex , initiation of transcription from deoCp2 was repressed 10-fold by CytR . [2170326]
  • Furthermore , CytR only regulates initiations of transcription from deoP2 in the presence of cAMP-CRP ( 7-9 ) . [1647022]
  • Consistently , CytR represses transcription in vivo only in the presence of the cAMP-CRP complex ( 30 , 32 ) . [1715855]
  • CytR ± CRP-mediated repression at deoP2 To assess CytR regulation at deoP2 in vitro , we ® rst examined transcription with intact RNP in the presence of CytR , CytR and cAMP ± CRP , and CytR , cAMP ± CRP and cytidine . [11574471]
  • In an attempt to determine the role of a-CTD in CytR / CRP-mediated repression at deoP2 , we next investigated transcription by the reconstituted RNP derivatives in the presence of a constant concentration of cAMP ± CRP and varying amounts of CytR . [11574471]
  • In the presence of cAMP-CRP , however , the affinity of CytR for this sequence is greatly increased ( 100-fold ) and , moreover , the two proteins bind cooperatively to deoP2 . [1647022]
  • In the presence of CytR , however , the two regulators bind cooperatively to cddP forming a nucleoprotein complex in which cAMP - CRP binds to CRP-1 and CRP-3 and CytR occupies the sequence between these sites . [1327747]
  • In the presence of cAMP-CRP , however , the affinity of CytR for this sequence is increased dramatically ( approximately 1,000-fold ) , and CytR and cAMP-CRP bind cooperatively to deo-p2 , forming a nucleoprotein complex in which CytR is sandwiched between two DNA-bound cAMP-CRP complexes . [1715855]
  • These data indicate that the CytR repressor relies on the presence of the cAMP-CRP activator complex to regulate tsr-p2 promoter activity and that the formation of an active repression complex requires the combined interactions of cAMP-CRP and CytR at tsX-p2 . [1715855]

  • In contrast , the binding of cGMP , of which guanine ring possess the 6-keto group replacing the 6-amino group of cAMP , does not induce proper allosteric change and fails to activate the protein , even though it binds to CRP with comparable afﬁnity as cAMP [ 5 -- 8 ] . [19439203]
  • By introducing CRP proteins that exhibit an altered DNA binding specificity into a strain containing a mutant deoP2 promoter in which cAMP-CRP activation was decreased and CytR regulation completely abolished , we show that CytR regulation of this promoter can be reestablished by restored the DNA binding of the cAMP-CRP complex . [1661372]
  • These findings support a general model for CytR binding and CytR regulation , in which ( i ) CytR and the CRP/cAMP complex bind to similar or Identical targets , ( ii ) two or more targets are necessary for proper binding of CytR to a promoter region , and ( iii ) CytR represses transcription by antagonizing cAMP/CRP activation . [2575702]
  • By introducing point mutations in the CRP sites , which strongly reduce binding of the cAMP-CRP activator complex , activation of transcription was severely reduced and CytR regulation was completely abolished , even when CytR was overproduced . [1661372]
  • Our results support the model in which repression normally involves the binding of CytR to cAMP-CRP to form a complex which binds to speciﬁc sites in the udp promoter , without direct interaction between CytR protein and a speciﬁc operator DNA sequence , and in which induction by speciﬁc inducer cytidine involves dissociation of CytR from cAMP-CRP and then RNA polymerase interaction with cAMP-CRP bound to a site upstream of the transcription start point . [8626289]
  • A model for the mode of action of CytR must account for the observations in this study that CytR only inhibits cAMP-CRP-dependent initiation of transcription and that tandem , intact CRP binding sites are required for repression . [2170326]
  • Structural ﬂexibility and induced ﬁt While it is not surprising that transcription factors can exhibit promiscuous DNA-binding characteristics , or undergo induced ﬁt when interacting with other molecules , it is remarkable that CytR can assume multiple conformations of about equal stability when co-binding with cAMP -- CRP ( Figure 6 ) . [9155036]
  • Taking together the results presented in this study , we propose a simple mechanism to account for the repression by CytR : the cAMP ± CRP complex at the CRP1 site , upon interaction with CytR , undergoes allosteric changes such that its binding to the DNA site is improved but its interaction with a-NTD is no longer productive , but rather destructive , leading to transcription repression ( Figure 8 ) . [11574471]

  • Indeed , if the CRP binding sites are only partially occupied in vivo , their destruction is expected to have greater consequences under growth conditions in which the cAMP concentration is high and which consequently favor the occupancy of the sites . [1824723]
  • It has been demonstrated that cAMP-CRP binds to many sites with an 8-bp spacer in vitro ( 3 , 4 , 9 , 49 ) , although we have found no reports showing such CRP binding sites are functional in vivo . [15743955]

  • The relative extents of inhibition and activation of crp transcription by CRP-cAMP are determined primarily by the concentrations of CRP and cAMP , The data which led us to these conclusions can be summarized as follows , ( i ) The activation of crp transcription was observed with increasing concentrations of CRP and/or cAMP when a DNA fragment containing the crp promoterregulatory region was transcribed in vitro in certain conditions , -LCB- ii ) The activation of crp transcription by CRP-cAMP was demonstrated more clearly when the fragment lacking downstream CRP site I was used for in vitro transcription , -LCB- iii -RCB- The concentrations needed for activation of the crp promoter were significantly higher than those required for activation of the divergent promoter , ( iv ) CRP-cAMP was shown to-bind to the CRP site II with a lower affinity compared with the CRP site I by a DNase I footprinting assay , -LCB- v ) The mutation in the CRP site II was detrimental for the binding of CRP-cAMP and for the activation of crp by CRP-cAMP , -LCB- vi ) The positive and negative autoreguiation of crp was shown , by SI analysis , to be operating in vivo .   • The factor for inversion stimulation ( FIS ) regulates transcription by binding to highly degenerate 15 bp DNA Abbreviations : CRP , cAMP receptor protein ; EMSA , electromobility shift assay ; FIS , factor for inversion stimulation ; GRDC , growth rate-dependent control ; RNAP , RNA polymerase .   • However , despite the presence of putative DNA binding sites for the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) ( 472 ) , it appears that cAMP-CRP does no control sdh-suc transcription directly ( 339 ) . [15755952]
  • cAMP-regulatory protein ( CRP ) Many cellular signalling pathways operate through the production of cAMP , which can regulate DNA transcription by binding to cAMP-regulatory protein ( CRP ; also known as catabolite gene activator protein , CAP ) . [16814929]
  • Often the binding of the cAMP-CRP complex to specific sequences in the DNA results in the stimulation of transcription ; however , the expression of several genes has been shown to be negatively regulated , apparently by the inhibition of transcription initiation ( 1 , 2 , 12 , 17 , 23 , 27 , 28 ) . [2454912]

[17630975]

  • However , Fis and CRP-cAMP together activate transcription synergistically .29 Even though the CRP-binding site is located unusually far upstream from the transcriptional start site , co-acti-vation is dependent on both the correct helical phasing of the CRP site and activation region 1 ( AR1 ) on CRP , a patch shown to contact the aCTD at other promoters .30 The presence of CRP promotes the binding of an aCTD peptide on its pro-moter-proximal side ( nucleotides ÿ97 to ÿ105 ) , providing further evidence that CRP activates proP P2 transcription through interactions with the aCTD .29 Here , we further investigate the nature of the Fis-aCTD interaction by identifying the residues on aCTD that are important for Fis-dependent activation . [11866515]

  • Mutations in the upstream CRP binding site in the crp promoter region abolish the effect of glucose One simple explanation for the requirement for the crp promoter and CRP-cAMP for the effect of glucose on crp expression would be to propose that the activation of crp transcription by CRP-cAMP is reduced in the presence of glucose while the positive autoregulation of crp transcription is efficiently operating in the absence of glucose . [7518773]
  • If this were the case , the disruption of the CRP binding site II , which is located upstream of the crp promoter and responsible for the activation of crp transcription by CRP-cAMP ( Hanamura and Aiba , 1992 ) , should lower the expression of crp in the absence of glucose and eliminate the down-regulation of crp by glucose . [7518773]

  • In vitro transcription studies effectively demonstrated this , whereby no CRP-dependent transcription activation was observed on a linear template ; however , use of a supercoiled template permitted transcription activation to occur , presumably through providing sufficient helical twist in the DNA to align cAMP ± CRP and RNAP correctly . [11251844]

  • It is known that cAMP forms a complex with CRP ( cAMP-CRP complex ) that binds to a speciﬁc promoter region of genes to either activate or inhibit transcription depending upon the position bound by the complex relative to the promoter ( 3 ) . [21840983]
  • In the absence of glucose , cAMP binds to CRP and forms a complex that regulates transcription by binding to the promoter regions of cAMP-regulated genes ( 24 ) . [16597943]

  • Expression of the psiE9-9cat fusions ( pKE135 , pKE136 , and pKE137 ) was reduced in DphoB strain transformants when transformants were grown in the presence of cAMP in both Tris-glucose LP and HP media ( Table 1 ) , suggesting that expression of these constructs is also negatively regulated by cAMP-CRP . [10986267]
  • Whereas Mlc is responsible for induction of ptsG ( and several other genes ) in the presence of glucose , the catabolite activator complex cAMP-CRP is also absolutely necessary for ptsG expression ( 15 , 26 , 32 , 48 ) . [16855233]
  • Glucose is known to affect gene expression through the cAMP-CRP complex , and the presence of glucose in the growth medium results in decreased levels of cAMP and CRP ( 26 , 36 ) . [15743955]
  • Interestingly , we found that the expression of pfs was reduced by the presence of glucose , but not through the cAMP-CRP complex . [15743955]
  • Exogenous cAMP partially compensates for the repressed level of SecB in the presence of glucose , and the compensatory recovery by the addition of cAMP is lost in cells lacking functional production of CRP from a cya and crp mutant strain . [10074084]
  • As shown in Fig. 4b and c , the level of cAMP was higher when cells were cultured in the presence of 0.04 % glucose compared to 0.4 % glucose , while the level of CRP was nearly equal in cells cultured in the presence of either 0.4 or 0.04 % glucose . [23719730]
  • CRP and cAMP levels are at maximum cellular levels in bacteria growing in media lacking glucose as a carbon source and decrease about 2.5 - to 5-fold in bacteria in the presence of glucose ( 26 , 27 , 47 ) . [9171388]
  • In this experiment , the 301 bp T'aq ` l-H/ndlll fragment carrying crp and divergent promoters ( Fig. 1 ) was transcribed in the presence of 100 pM of cAMP and various concentrations of CRP . [1328816]
  • In contrast to CRP -- cAMP , the Lac repressor functioned effectively at K + glutamate concentrations up to 0.6 M ( Fig. 3B ) ; transcript levels obtained with 0.1 or 0.6 M K + glutamate in the presence of repressor were # 10 % of the no-repressor control . [10601034]
  • In contrast , substituting the P3hfq promoter with a lacZ promoter ( that is positively regulated by cAMP-CRP ) increased the stability of the ompA mRNA in the presence of glucose . [21840983]
  • In order to determine whether the increased activity of the crp promoter in ﬁs cells is the result of a reduced cAMP level such that no active cAMP -- CRP complexes are formed , we grew the cultures in the presence of 1 mM cAMP . [9582281]
  • In vitro kinetic measurements suggest that the stimulation of P1 is due to the product KB X kf being five times greater in the presence of cAMP CRP than in the absence of the complex ( 12 ) . [2537823]
  • In the case of SecB , the cAMP-CRP complex appears to function as an activator since its presence leads to an increase in SecB levels in glucose medium . [9023186]
  • In these conditions , we observed the disappearance of the hyper-reactive C ( 234 ) that is formed in the presence of the cAMP -- CRP complex alone . [20966094]
  • In the presence of catabolite-repressing sugars such as D-glucose and D-gluconate , cAMP and CRP levels are low and transcription of the idn genes is not induced . [14973046]
  • In the presence of CRP , expression of glpD and glpE increased 5 - and 3-fold upon the addition of cAMP , respectively ( data not shown ) . [1846566]
  • In the presence of glucose , the cAMP level is expected to be decreased , and hence the cAMP CRP level , thus the CRP-dependent regulation is repressed . [15520470]
  • In the presence of glucose , CyaA does not catalyze the conversion of ATP to cAMP and CRP is not activated . [20211899]
  • In the presence of excess glucose , cAMP levels are low and cAMP-CRP thus is unavailable . [17273855]
  • In the presence of CRP -- cAMP , overexpression of nifA from pMJ220 resulted in equally high level expression of glnAp2 . [11532153]
  • In a previous study ( 50 ) , we showed that the presence of glucose strongly inhibits expression of the lsr operon through control of cAMP-CRP . [16321939]
  • In the presence of glucose , low levels of cAMP and CRP result in almost no expression of the lsr operon . [15743955]
  • We conclude that , at the csiD promoter , H-NS generates high stringency with respect to the position of the activator cAMP-CRP and thereby contributes to maximal expression in the presence of cAMP-CRP ( when bound to its wild-type position at 268.5 ) . [11532138]

  • Here we show that ( i ) CytR selectively regulated cAMP-CRP-dependent initiations , although transcription started from the same site in deoCp2 in the absence or presence of cAMP-CRP ; ( ii ) deletion of the uppermost cAMP-CRP target ( CRP-2 ) resulted in loss of CytR regulation , but had only a minor effect on positive control by the cAMP-CRP complex ; ( iui ) introduction of point mutations in either CRP target resulted in loss of CytR regulation ; and ( iv ) regulation by CytR of deletion mutants lacking CRP-2 could be specifically reestablished by increasing the intracellular concentration of CytR . [20966094]
  • In the presence of cAMP , the cAMP-CRP complex ( hereinafter called CRP ) will bind to a 22 bp 2-fold-symmetric recognition site located within or near target promoters ( Berg and von Hippel , 1988 ) , and thereby activate transcription from these promoters . [8895588]
  • Synthesis of the araC transcript from the wild-type promoter was stimulated 1.6-fold by the addition of cAMP and CRP ; the addition of araC protein ( repressor form ) reduced by 60 % the amount of araC transcription , even in the presence of the cAMP-CRP complex ( data not shown ) . [6377308]

  • At the beginning of the addition of gluconate , a relatively weakly bound GntR at HRI or HRIII may be released as a complex with gluconate , and it is replaced by the cAMP-CRP complex as cAMP is accumulated , which in turn interacts with GntR bound at HRII ( the GntR may still be free from gluconate ) and activates transcriptions to some extent from the gntV and idnD promoters to produce some amount of GntII proteins including IdnD , IdnO and GntH proteins .   • These in vivo results clearly indicate that both proteins , FIS and cAMP -- CRP , are required for crp repression , since the lack of either transcriptional-regulator leads to a derepressed crp promoter . [9582281]
  • Employing crp promoter -- lacZ fusions , we demonstrate that both FIS and cAMP -- CRP are required to keep the crp promoter in a repressed state . [9582281]
  • These results are consistent with the Northern analyses and indicate that both FIS and cAMP -- CRP are required throughout the growth-phase to keep the crp promoter in a repressed state . [9582281]
  • Synergistic regulation of bgl by BglJ -- RcsB and CRP -- cAMP BglJ -- RcsB and CRP synergistically activate the bgl P2 promoter and relief repression by HNS and StpA . [24335284]
  • At high cAMP -- CRP concentrations , the repression of the crp1 promoter was relieved ( Figure 6 , lane 5 ) . [9582281]
  • Addition of cAMP -- CRP in combination with FIS slightly alleviated the repression of the crp1 promoter , but not of the divergent promoter , indicating that the divergent promoter is repressed by FIS even more efﬁciently than is the crp1 promoter . [9582281]
  • Transcription from the promoter would be blocked by cAMP-CRP under low-glucose and HP conditions , because of a high concentration of cAMP-CRP and low concentration of PhoB . [10986267]
  • cAMP - CRP enhances-the-activity of P1 , possibly by enhancing the isomerization of RNA polymerase at this promoter . [2537823]
  • lacZP acted as a control promoter , which is activated by cAMP ± CRP only when transcribed by RNP carrying an intact a-subunit ( Igarashi and Ishihama , 1991 ) . [11574471]
  • Binding of CRP -- cAMP to the galP1D4 promoter is also osmotically sensitive , but this promoter is not significantly derepressed by an osmotic upshift . [10601034]
  • Transcription levels were normalized to the divergent p82 promoter , which does not respond to RhaR , CRP , L-rhamnose , or cAMP . [16166533]
  • Activation by cAMP -- CRP is not expected to inﬂuence tsp selection ; it increases promoter strength without affecting the tsp in the P1galE promoter ( Lewis and Adhya , 2004 ) . [17630975]
  • To test for the roles of CRP and cAMP on gapB P0 promoter activity , we looked for the amount of gapB transcripts in E. coli POP4129Dcrp , which is deﬁcient in CRP production , and in the E. coli TP2006cya mutant strain , defective in cAMP production ( 32 ) . [9851989]

  • The cAMP/CRP complex is a positive transcriptional-regulator of a number of catabolic operons , and as such , plays a role in catabolite repression , whereby secondary carbon sources are not catabolized in the presence of glucose . [21029047]
  • The sdaB gene is expressed only in rich medium in the absence of glucose , under the control of the cAMP/CRP catabolite repression system [ 37 ] . [12706508]

  • The speciﬁc activator ( NtrC-phosphate ) is not essential for CRP -- cAMP-mediated inhibition of glnAp2 At high concentration , NtrC-phosphate can activate glnAp2 in a binding site-independent fashion ( Reitzer and Magasanik , 1986 ; see also above ) , suggesting that the CRP -- cAMP complex might somehow modulate the quantity or activity of NtrC-phosphate through the complicated Ntr system which , in turn , results in the repressive downregulation of glnAp2 lacking NtrC-binding sites .   • The activation process of CRP upon binding to cAMP involves unique features of allostery distinguished from those of other enzymes and membrane receptors . [19439203]
  • The larger , N-terminal domain ( NTD ) , which is predominantly β-stranded , is basically responsible for CRP dimerization ( see Fig. 1 ) , and the cAMP binding to this domain results in the functional activation of CRP . [19439203]
  • The strong CRP binding site is correctly positioned to function in aspA transcriptional activation by the cAMP-CRP complex . [9852003]

  • The normal osmotic control by the CRP * mutant also rules out the possibility that changes in cAMP levels are responsible for the osmotically sensitive binding . [10601034]
  • The activity of CRP is triggered by binding of the second messenger cAMP , whose conversion from ATP is catalyzed by the adenylate cyclase enzyme CyaA in response to glucose-starvation and other stresses ( references 20 and 35 and references therein ) . [20211899]

  • The greater sensitivity of CRP -- cAMP binding to increases in medium osmolarity in minimal media correlates with the greater induction at lower osmolarity in minimal as compared to complex media . [10601034]

  • DISCUSSION The cAMP CRP complex binds to the promoters of many operons , e.g. , lac , srl , etc. , and dramatically stimulates their rate of transcription . [2537823]
  • The cAMP-CRP complex binds the fadL , fadD and fadH promoters . [23029459]
  • The complex of cAMP and CRP binds to a region of the DNA near the beginning of a regulated gene and enhances transcription of the gene . [6329724]
  • The cAMP-CRP complex thus seems to-bind to the putative sequence and to enhance gntT transcription ( see below ) . [9358057]
  • The transcription of cyaA is negatively regulated by the cAMP-CRP complex ; thus , a large increase in cAMP synthesis occurs in a crp mutant [ 43 ] . [18560382]
  • The CRP -- cAMP complex inhibits s - dependent glnAp2 strongly , by 54 21-fold ( see Results obtained from glnAp1 ` dead ' construct various contributions in vivo . [11532153]
  • The results are consistent with our previous studies on a heterologous system , in E. coli are all downregulated by the CRP -- cAMP complex ( glnAp2 , this work ; glnHp2 , unpublished observations ; glnK , unpublished observations ) . [11532153]
  • The genes encoding enzymes involved in glycogen metabo-lism ( glycogen synthase and glycogen phosphorylase ) are linked on a single operon that is regulated by the cAMP CRP z complex . [9334229]
  • The regulation by the cAMP-CRP complex was investigated by comparing the strains cultured in LB and in LB supplemented-with-glucose . [9367749]
  • The positive effect of the cAMP-CRP complex , however , is seen only in concert with DsdC . [7592420]
  • The cAMP-CRP complex stimulates the expression of lsrR and the lsr operon , while LsrR represses their expression [ 14 , 15 ] , suggesting that cAMP , the CRP , or both may be affected by sdiA-ydiV double mutation . [18560382]
  • The GntH molecule bound to HRII strongly recruits cAMP-CRP complexes to activate the expression of the gntV and idnD genes . [14593252]
  • The expression of tnaA is under cAMP and CRP regulation ( 78 ) and is also inducible by high pH ( 75 ) . [17293424]
  • The mel locus is induced by several a-D-galactosides ( 2,3 ) and its expression is controlled by the cAMP-CRP regulatory circuit ( 4 ) . [3031590]
  • The expression of fMet-Gln , the amino-terminal dipeptide of gigA was enhanced 2.4 - to 2.8-fold by cAMP and CRP . [2468650]
  • The synthesis of fMet-Val directed by the HpaI fragment was enhanced 2.5-fold by cAMP and CRP , versus the 7 - to 10-fold effect with plasmid pOP12 ; however , cAMP and CRP no longer enhanced the synthesis of fMetGln from this fragment . [2468650]

  • Two hypotheses could account for these results : ( i ) osmoregulation of osmY requires yet another unidentified regulatory mechanism that is totally independent of as , Lrp , cAMP-CRP , and IHF ; or ( ii ) osmotic induction could be mediated by several independently and additively acting components , some of which could be those identified in the present study as being involved in the regulation of osmY . [8253679]
  • Stationary-phase induction of osmY in rich medium is mediated by the combined action of as , Lrp , cAMP-CRP , and IHF , with the latter three proteins acting as transition state regulators . [8253679]
  • None of the several regulatory genes mentioned above seems to be essential for hyperosmotic induction of osmY , which could still be observed in mutants deficient in as , Lrp , cAMP-CRP , or IHF and even in strains carrying rpoS lrp or rpoS hip double mutations . [8253679]

  • We found that the degree of overproduction of cAMP in crp ~ cells is reduced to 50-fold , suggesting that the negative regulation of cya transcription is indeed involved in the downregulation of cAMP production by CRP , while the major regulation of cAMP production by CRP is exerted at the posttranscriptional level . [9003304]

  • Key words Adenylate cyclase · cAMP synthesis · CRP · Transcriptional regulation · Posttranscriptional regulation Introduction Cyclic AMP is an important regulatory molecule involved in various cellular activities in many organisms . [9003304]

  • This negative regulation of cAMP level by CRP could be crucial to cell physiology although the biological signiﬁcance of this regulation is not fully understood . [9003304]
  • Among these regulators , it is likely that the observed up-regulation in acetate and glycerol was mediated by cAMP-CRP , as cAMP level should be increased in nonglucose media . [10753455]
  • Thus , the level of cAMP present in GM medium appears to be sufﬁcient for regulation by CRP . [10074087]
  • Quantitative analysis of cya mRNA , cya protein , and cAMP establishes that transcriptional control is partly responsible for the down-regulation of cAMP levels by CRP , although the major regulation is exerted at posttranscriptional level . [9003304]
  • Our data indicate that elimination of transcriptional regulation of cya by CRP reduces the extent of overproduction of cAMP in a crp ~ background from 200-fold to 50-fold . [9003304]
  • To assess the role o transcriptional regulation of cya in mediating the strong downregulation of cAMP production by CRP , the cAMP levels of cells harboring pSE3 were determined . [9003304]
  • This means that transcriptional inhibition of cya by CRP is indeed involved in the regulation of cAMP levels . [9003304]
  • So far , no experiment has been done to test directly whether the transcriptional regulation of cya contrib-utes to the repression of cAMP level by CRP . [9003304]
  • Alternatively , transcriptional inhibition of cya by CRP may play little part in the regulation of cAMP level . [9003304]
  • We conclude that transcriptional regulation of cya does indeed play a role in the down-regulation of cAMP production by CRP , although the major regulation is exerted at the posttranscriptional level . [9003304]
  • We investigated the quantitative contributions to the cAMP level of transcriptional and posttranscriptional regulation of adenylate cyclase by CRP . [9003304]

  • It has been proposed that transcription activation of class II CRP-dependent promoters is established by positioning a-CTD to the DNA site immediately upstream of the cAMP ± CRP site in addition to direct activation ( Attey et al. , 1994 ; Belyaeva et al. , 1996 , 1998 ; Niu et al. , 1996 ; Busby and Ebright , 1999 ) . [11574471]
  • Direct activation is through an interaction of a-NTD with AR2 of cAMP ± CRP ( see Figure 1B ) ( Attey , 1994 ; Belyaeva et al. , 1996 ; Murakami et al. , 1997 ; Rhodius et al. , 1997 ; Savery , 1998 ; Busby and Ebright , 1999 ) . [11574471]
  • This DNA sequence-independent interaction between the DNA adjacent to cAMP ± CRP and a-CTD of RNP has been implicated as playing a role in class II cAMP ± CRP-dependent activation ( Savery et al. , 1995 , 1998 ; Lloyd et al. , 1998 ) . [11574471]
  • This model also offers a plausible explanation for the recent findings that CytR does not regulate transcription from deoP2 in Icya or Acrp strains , although transcription occurs from the same site in deoP2 in the absence and presence of cAMP-CRP ( L. Sogaard-Andersen et al. . [1962841]
  • Thus , in the presence of both cAMP-CRP and CytR , a nucleoprotein complex is formed that most probably contains cAMP-CRP at each CRP site and CytR bound in the intervening region ( Sogaard-Ander-sen et al. 1991 ) . [1661372]

  • Firstly , cAMP-CRP activation of deoP2 is mediated by the CRP-1 site , whereas proper regulation of this promoter by CytR requires tandem intact CRP binding sites ( Martinussen et al. 1989 ; Sogaard-Andersen et al. 1990a , b ; Valentin-Hansen 1985 ) . [1661372]
  • In CytR regulated promoters , cAMP-CRP constitutes an essential part of the repression apparatus and the available data suggest that two appropriately positioned CRP binding sites are a prerequisite for negative regulation by CytR ( S0gaard-Andersen et al. , 1990a , b ) . [1327747]
  • cddPD79 bears a single target for CytR and cAMP -- CRP , respectively , and is repressed ﬁvefold by the co-operative binding of the two regulators ( see Fig. 1 and Table 1 ; Holst et al. , 1992 ) . [9466254]
  • In vitro , CytR exhibits a low affinity for the sequence located between the two CRP sites ; however , its binding to deoP2 can be stimulated as much as 1000-fold by cAMP-CRP ( Sogaard-Andersen et al. , 1991b ; Pedersen et al. , 1991 ) . [1327747]
  • Repression of deoP2 Repression of deoP2 by CytR was only observed in the presence of cAMP ± CRP , in agreement with the in vivo observation that CytR binding requires cAMP ± CRP ( Sùgaard-Andersen et al. , 1990a , b ) . [11574471]
  • In vitro , CRP-3 is only occupied in the presence of CytR and is located at a position relative to CRP-1 that has been shown to be optimal for the cooperative binding of cAMP-CRP and CytR in deoP2 ( S0gaard-Andersen et al. , 1991b ) . [1327747]
  • Based on these observations , it has been suggested that CytR and RNP are rivals that compete for binding with CRP to deoP2 , and that CytR acts as an anti-activator , nullifying the activation by cAMP ± CRP ( Sùgaard-Andersen et al. , 1990a , b ; Mùllegaard et al. , 1993 ; Kristensen et al. , 1997 ; Meibom et al. , 2000 ) . [11574471]
  • This ability of cAMP - CRP to stimulate the binding of CytR cooperatively requires a set of amino acids that are located in a specific region on the surface of cAMP-CRP ( Pedersen et al. , 1991 ; Sogaard-Andersen et al. , 1991a ) . [1327747]
  • CytR binds to its cognate promoters in concert with cAMP-CRP in a highly co-operative fashion torming repression complex that generally consists of two mol-ecules of cAMP-CRP separated by 52 or 53 bp and CytR ioound in between ( Sogaard-Andersen et ai , 1991b ; Gerlach etai , 1991 ; Holsi etai . [7715459]
  • The synergy in the system is prominent ; depending on which promoter is examined , the cAMP -- CRP activator complex strengthens binding of CytR from 100 - to several thousandfold in vitro ( Gerlach et al. , 1991 ; Pedersen et al. , 1991 , 1992 , 1995 ; Holst et al. , 1992 ) . [9155036]
  • Therefore , the cAMP-CRP complex strengthens binding of CytR to its operators up to 1000-fold ( Pedersen et aL , 1991 ) , increasing the affinity of the repressor for the promoters to a level adequate for repression . [8596434]
  • H Discussion Recent studies have indicated that repression of the deoP2 promoter by the CytR repressor requires the cAMP-CRP complex and that there is a coupling between cAMP-CRP binding to tandem CRP targets and the interaction of the CytR repressor ( Sogaard-Andersen et aL , 1990a , b ) . [1649947]
  • On the one hand , the recent isolation of CRP mutants that can not activate transcription but still bend the DNA like wt CRP point to the importance of direct interactions between cAMP-CRP and RNA polymerase ( Bell et al. , 1990 ; Eschenlauer and Reznikoff , 1991 ) . [1327747]
  • Binding of the cAMP -- CRP complex to its target sites is known to bend DNA ( Schultz et al. , 1991 ) . [14731281]
  • On the other hand , the observation that the CRP sites in gal and lac can be replaced by properly phased intrinsically bent DNA sequences points to the importance of the cAMP - CRP induced DNA bend in the activation process ( Bracco et al. , 1989 ; Gartenberg and Crothers , 1991 ) . [1327747]
  • At its site of interaction , cAMP -- CRP induces sharp bends in DNA ranging from 90 to 180 ° ( Wu and Crothers , 1984 ; Liu-Johnson et al. , 1986 ) . [9582281]
  • In these complexes , the DNA bends strongly around cAMP -- CRP , bringing the DNA-bound regulators into close proximity ( Søgaard-Andersen et al. , 1991b ; Crothers and Steitz , 1992 ) . [9155036]
  • When bound with cAMP , CRP is converted into a functional form and recognizes a spe-ciﬁc DNA sequence , referred to CRP box , with the consensus sequence of a 22-bp inverted repeat sequence , 50-AAATGTGATCTAGATCACATTT-30 [ underlines are highly conserved ] ( De Crombrugghe et al. , 1984 ; Berg & von Hippel , 1988 ; Gunaskerra et al. , 1992 ) .   • The gntR gene is constitutively expressed , whereas the gntKU genes are positively regulated by the cAMP -- CRP complex and negatively by GntR , and gntU expression is further repressed by attenuation , which occurs after gntK ( Izu et al. , 1997 ) . [9358057]
  • The dual regulation by GntR and GntH in addition to that by cAMP-CRP is proposed to be important for expressional control of the GntII genes and also for switching of the GntI to GntII systems along with cell growth as demonstrated [ Tsunedomi et al. , 2003 ] . [14593252]

  • Accessory components are acetyl phosphate , which contributes to RssB and perhaps also to ArcA phosphorylation ( Bouché et al. 1998 ; Pena-Sandoval et al. 2005 ) , as well as cAMP-CRP , which in log-phase cells has an indirect inhibitory effect on rpoS transcription ( Lange and Hengge-Aronis 1994 ; F.   • For example , glucose lowers the rate of transcription of the lac operon by reducing both intracellular cAMP and CRP levels when added to cells growing on other carbon sources ( Ishizuka et al. 1993 , 1994 ; Tagami et al. 1995 ) . [9003304]
  • A striking ﬁnding is that a large increase ( about 100-fold ) in cAMP synthesis occurs when the crp gene is defective : in other words , the synthesis of cAMP is strictly down-regulated by CRP ( reviewed by Botsford and Harman 1992 ; Postma et al. 1993 ) . [9003304]
  • Moreover , work on the galactose operon has revealed that the cAMP -- CRP complex , directly or indirectly , influences synthesis of the products of this operon differentially ( Ullmann et al. 1979 ; Joseph et al. 1981 ; Adhya 1987 ) . [12101127]
  • As glucose is consumed , cAMP and CRP levels increase and the cAMP -- CRP complex activates a set of operons whose products are necessary for the recruitment and metabolism of alternative carbon sources ( Ullmann and Danchin , 1983 ; Ishizuka et al. , 1993 ; Kolb et al. , 1993 ) . [9582281]
  • However , Reznikoff et al. ( 1982 ) observed an extremely weak transcript initiated at about -45 in an in vitro reaction containing 25 % glycerol , but it was inhibited by cAMP + CRP . [2582140]
  • To study the effect of CRP -- cAMP ( Dumay et al. , 1996 ) , 0.4 % w/v of glycerol was used as the sole carbon source instead of glucose . [11532153]
  • Because of its cAMP-CRP dependency , csiDp is activated exclusively under carbon starvation conditions and stationary phase in LB ( Weichart et al. , 1993 ; Marschall et al. , 1998 ; Germer et al. , 2001 ) . [14731280]
  • CRP was puriﬁed as described by Savery et al. ( 1998 ) using the method of Ghosaini et al. ( 1988 ) and was activated by the addition of 200 mM cAMP . [12675795]
