  • RESULTS Influence of glucose on mhpR expression As mentioned above , it has been demonstrated that the transcription of the mhp cluster from the Pa promoter is activated by the cAMP -- CRP complex ( Torres et al. , 2003 ) . [20966094]
  • Expression of the deoCA genes from the P-2 promoter is known to be controlled positively by cAMP/CRP and negatively by the cytR repressor , the inducer being cytidine ( J0rgensen et al. , 1977 ; Valentin-Hansen et al. , 1978 ) . [6329724]
  • Transcription from the main promoter , PsdhC , is thought to be activated by cAMP-CRP and was shown to be activated by reduced FNR and phosphorylated ArcA ( Park et al. 1997 ; Shen and Gunsalus 1997 ; Cunningham and Guest 1998 ) . [17273855]

  • A protein which is related to both FNR and CRP may be assigned to the FNR family on the basis of : - an ability to complement anfnr mutation in E. coli , or its equivalent in another organism ; - a greater degree of sequence identity to FNR than to CRP ; - h a v i n g the predicted DNA-binding specificity of FNR rather than that of CRP ; - failing to respond to cAMP , or lacking amino acids which are involved in liganding cAMP ; - responding to the same physiological signal as FNR , namely oxygen limitation or - retaining some or all of the cysteine residues of FNR which are thought to be involved in its response to oxygen limitation , and which are absent from CRP . [7747934]

  • INTRODUCTION The structural genes encoding the ~ ystems for nucleoside uptake and metabolism in E. coli are organized in a regulon that is controlled positively by the cAMP/CRP activator complex and negatively by the DeoR and CytR repressors . [2265760]

  • In deoCp1 , promoter control is mediated by the DeoR repressor , whereas deoCp2 is subject to negative regulation by the DeoR and CytR repressors and activation by the cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) - cAMP receptor protein ( cAMP-CRP ) complex ( 29 , 34 ) . [2170326]
  • In CytR regulated promoters , including the udpP promoter , the cAMP -- CRP complex acts as a transcriptional-activator as well as a co-repressor for the CytR protein [ 5,23,25 ] . [14499937]
  • In this system , the global activator protein cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ; also referred to as the catabolite gene activator protein , CAP ) , guides another DNA-binding protein , the CytR repressor , to a number of binding sites that share minimal sequence homology . [9155036]
  • Single amino acid substitutions in the cAMP receptor prote ABSTRACT Promoters in Escherichia coli that are negatively regulated by the CytR repressor are also activated by the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) complexed to cAMP ; as a characteristic , these promoters encode tandem binding sites for cAMP-CRP . [1647022]
  • Heterologous Cooperativityin Escherichia coli Promoters in Escherichiacoli that arenegatively regulated by the CytR repressor are alsoactivated by the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) complexedto CAMP ; as a characteristic , these promotersencodetwo binding sites for the cAMP * CRP complex . [1655726]
  • Protein-protein interactions between CytR and cAMP-CRP mediate this co-operative binding ( S ~ gaard-Andersen et aL , 1991a ; Pedersen et aL , 1991 ; S ~ gaard-Andersen and Valentin-Hansen , 1993 ) . [8596434]
  • As the cooperative binding of cAMP-CRP and CytR relies on both protein-DNA and protein-protein interactions and is dramatically reduced by mutations that affect these parameters ( Sogaard-Andersen al. , 1990a , b , et 1991a ; S0gaard-Andersen and Valentin-Hansen , 1991 ) , this regulatory difference might be explained by the relative affinity of cAMP-CRP for its binding sites in the two promoters . [1327747]
  • We have investigated in vivo the coupling between CytR regulation of the deoP2 promoter in Escherichia coli and the DNA-binding specificity of the cAMP-CRP ( cAMP receptor protein ) complex in order to obtain a more detailed picture of the role played by cAMP-CRP in CytR regulation . [1661372]

  • Furthermore , E. coli CytR proteins deleted from the DNA binding domain are able to repress transcription from CytR-regulated promoters , implying that the protein -- protein interactions between CytR and cAMP -- CRP play a key role in specifying the site of action of CytR . [14499937]
  • The inducer of CytR perturbs protein-protein interactions to cAMP-CRP Cytidine , the inducer of the CytR regulon , does not affect individual CytR-DNA interactions . [8596434]
  • The physiological importance of the cooperative DNA binding of cAMP-CRP and CytR to tSx-p2 is emphasized by the observation that cytidine , the inducer of CytR , does not interfere with independent DNA binding of the repressor protein ; rather , the cooperative binding of cAMP-CRP and CytR is interrupted . [1715855]
  • three possibilities can be envisaged for how CytR interacts with deoP2 : ( i ) CytR binds to the DNA and directly contacts cAMP-CRP , i.e. the dependence of CytR on cAMP-CRP is mediated through protein-protein interactions ; ( ii ) cAMP-CRP binding to DNA induces a conformational change in the DNA which is specifically recognized by CytR , i.e. the dependence of CytR on cAMP-CRP is mediated through changes in DNA structure/conformation ; ( iii ) CytR does not contact DNA but sits on top of cAMP-CRP , i.e. a system closely resembling the Gal4/Gal80 system in yeast -LCB- Johnston etai . [1962841]
  • Although CytR is a sequence-specific DNA-binding protein , it requires cAMP-CRP for effective binding to its cognate promoters . [8596434]
  • These results strongly indicate that cooperative DNA binding of CytR and cAMP-CRP is achieved through protein-protein interactions . [1647022]
  • Two mechanisms can be envisaged to participate in this heterologous cooperativity : changes in DNA conformation induced by DNA binding of the two proteins and/or protein-protein interactions between CytR and cAMP-CRP . [1647022]

  • The interaction between CRP and DNA induces DNA bending by up to 90 ° ( Schultz et al. , 1991 ; Plate 1 ) . [11407111]
  • CRP and IHF have been studied in detail and shown to bend DNA by 90 and - 1400 , respectively ( Wu and Crothers , 1984 ; Liu-Johnson et al. , 1986 ; Robertson and Nash , 1988 ; Thompson and Landy , 1988 ; Schultz et al. , 1991 ) . [8508774]

  • While X-repressor binds through close contacts to the major groove of the DNA , the binding of CRP is relying more on surface-surface interactions analogous to those presentin nucleosomes between DNA and the histones ( Richmond et al. , 1984 ) . [8394345]
  • This model is compatible with the known properties of CRP , since the direction of the bend induced by the binding of CRP to its recognition site ( Liu-Johnson et al. , 1986 ) is the same as the one resulting from DNA wrapping around MalT . [2538630]

  • Fis can also affect DNA supercoiling indirectly , because of its roles in repressing transcription of gyrA and gyrB to reduce the DNA gyrase activity ( Schneider et al. , 1999 ) , increasing topA transcription to enhance topoisomerase I activity ( WeinsteinFischer et al. , 2000 ) , and regulating the expression of other DNA-binding proteins such as H-NS , HU and CRP ( Claret & Rouviere-Yaniv , 1996 ; Falconi et al. , 1996 ; Gonzalez-Gil et al. , 1998 ) that also affect DNA supercoiling directly or indirectly ( Broyles & Pettijohn , 1986 ; Gomez-Gomez et al. , 1996 ; Tupper et al. , 1994 ) .   • We propose that CRP decreases energetic barriers to RNA polymerase binding , isomerization , and abortive RNA synthesis but stabilizes the abortive RNA initiating complex , which results in increasing the activation energy of the transition state before the elongation complex . [15385551]
  • We hypothesize that by stabilizing the corresponding transition states , the CRP - CTD interaction ( s ) decreases the energetic barrier to closed , open , and initiating complex formation and helps increased RNAP binding , open complex formation , and abortive RNA synthesis . [15385551]

  • The absence of any cooperativity in the binding of MalT and CRP to sites 1/2 and 1 , respectively , as revealed by the in vivo footprinting experiments makes it unlikely that contact with MalT bound to site 2 mediates this stimulatory effect of CRP , and lends support to the hypothesis of an interaction with the polymerase . [9000616]
  • The mechanism of activation by CRP is clearly different from that occurring at the divergent malEp-malKp promoters , which are simultaneously controlled by an array of three binding sites for CRP , all located at distal positions in between ( 36 ) , and forming a high-order structure responsible for activation , assisting direct activation by the MalT primary regulator . [9573142]

  • Characterization of open complex formation Because disruption of the lower-affinity CRP binding site , CRP II , increased in vivo promoter activity from pacs236 , we predicted that within this context , low concentrations of CRP would favour transcription , while high concentrations would inhibit it .   • However , a degree of reciprocity of binding-site recognition can be inferred from the observation that FNR can activate transcription from a promoter containing a consensus CRP site , but only in a crp mutant , and CRP can likewise activate an FNR-dependent promoter in the absence of FNR ( Sawers et aL , 1997 ) . [11407111]
  • Taken together , these results strongly suggest that TcbC activates transcription of tdc by altering the local topological status of the tdc promoter and that , in the wild-type tdc promoter , the CRP binding site is misaligned to allow transcription to occur only under optimal conditions . [11251844]
  • However , the position of the CRP binding site for manA relative to the promoter for & m4 suggests that it may control transcription of both genes during catabolite repression . [6397402]
  • Since the CRP binding site located in the cya promoter region is responsible for the negative regulation of the cya transcription by CRP ( Aiba 1985 ) , the removal of this CRP site should eliminate the effect of CRP . [9003304]
  • Third , certain promoter structures result in a situation where CRP can activate transcription by binding to an upstream site but can also repress transcription by binding to a downstream site , e.g. the crp promoter ( 27 ) . [15520470]

  • The pairwise interaction between CytR and CRP bound to CRP1 is greatly reduced , but because CRP2 is the weaker site and as such is rarely occupied by itself , the reduction in pairwise CytR-CRP2 has a negligible effect . [20000490]
  • Not only is the relative affinity of CRP higher for CRP1 than for CRP2 , but also the absolute affinity of CRP for CRP1 is unusually high . [20000490]
  • CRP binds separately to CRP1 and to CRP2 . [10347150]
  • This concentration of CRP yields 0.98 and .0.99 fractional saturation of CRP1 and CRP2 , respectively . [10347150]
  • Affinity for CRP2 is higher than for CRP1 as evidenced by the CRP concentration dependence of the protection . [8969182]
  • A large effect is observed in the case when CRP is bound to CRP2 but not to CRP1 ( reduced-valence CRP1 cddP ) , suggesting a substantial-Δ decrease in pairwise cooperativity , G23 . [20000490]
  • In contrast , there is essentially no effect when CRP is bound to CRP1 but not to CRP2 ( reduced-valence CRP2 cddP ) and only a small effect when CRP-is bound to both sites ( wild-type cddP ) . [20000490]

  • In contrast , it has a negligible effect on pairwise cooperativity between CytR and CRP bound to CRP2 . [10347150]

  • Table 2 summarizes the expression data and show that the ability of the different CRP proteins to activate deoP2-wt varied in parallel with the efficiency of regulation by CytR . [1661372]
  • In summary , this work conﬁrms previous reports on CRP and CytR regulation which show that bacteria use activating and repressing modules in different stoichiometric and structural arrangements to differentially adjust the expression of genes belonging to the same regulon [ 32 ] . [14499937]
  • These results , therefore , confirm our location of the cdd-promoter and suggest that all sequences necessary for proper regulation of this promoter by CytR and CRP are present in the Hga \ fragment . [2575702]
  • Most importantly , our results clearly showed that CytR regulation of the mutant deoP2 promoter was reestablished in the presence of either of the altered CRP proteins . [1661372]
  • Thus , the strong reduction in promoter activity observed upon replacement of CRP-wt protein with either of the altered CRP proteins was parallelled by a reduction in the degree of CytR regulation . [1661372]
  • This decrease in efficiency of CytR regulation is not simply a consequence of the reduced promoter activ ity , as the promoter activity in the cytR ÷ strain was higher ( 1.0 ) in presence of the altered CRP proteins than in presence of CRP-wt protein ( 0.6 ) . [1661372]

  • Arrows in panel C indicate sites of IS insertions and the new transcriptional start in ins1 ( position 264 , the same as in del18 ) ; newly created 235 and 210 regions are underlined DISCUSSION We used biochemical and mutational tests to better understand how CRP and CytR repressor interact with each other and target DNA to result in the regulation of transcription of the udp gene . [8626289]
  • An important feature of the regulation mediated by CytR and CRP is that extents of activation , repression , and induction vary among the promoters , even among those with a similar arrangement of regulatory elements and similar binding affinities for the two proteins ( 4-6 ) . [12667072]
  • This is achieved by nesting levels of local repression , mediated by DeoR and CytR , on a more global regulation mediated by CRP . [8969182]
  • Coordinate gene regulation is achieved by nesting local repression by the LacI family member , CytR , on the global activation mediated by CRP . [20000490]
  • Second , while mutant deoP2 with only CRP1 functional ( i.e. CRP22 ) displays nearly the same extent of CRP activation ( presumably class II-mediated ) as wild type , it is not effectively repressed by CytR ( 20 ) . [8969182]
  • This effect occurs first at CRP2 due to the higher affinity of CytR for its competing site ( s ) , thus helping to facilitate the switch from class I to class II CRP activation . [8969182]
  • Increasing the distance between CRP - 1 and CRP-2 by 2 bp in the wt promoter and in the promoter containing the point mutation at position -60 would be expected to result in decreased activation and increased CytR regulation . [1327747]
  • Although we can not yet account for the effect of this amino acid substitution on activation , the salient point here is that amino acid substitutions in CRP can abolish CytR regulation . [1647022]
  • In this view the state of CRP activation is as important as occupancy by CytR . [8969182]
  • As such , CytR would act initially as a switch from one kinetic mode of CRP activation to another . [8969182]
  • In this model , induction of expression by cytidine was shown to involve dissociation of CytR from CRP complexes , which results in transcription activation , possibly through effects on DNA topology or direct interaction with RNA polymerase . [8626289]
  • In this model , CytR ± CRP and CytR ± DNA interactions block transcription activation by CRP , by sterically blocking the functional AR1 of CRP and by sterically preventing a-CTD from interacting with the DNA segment immediately upstream of the CRP dimer at the CRP1 site . [11574471]

  • A prediction of the ® rst model is that the formation of CytR ± CRP promoter complexes should not result in repression if transcription is conducted by RNP derivatives lacking a-CTD ( Igarashi and Ishihama , 1991 ) . [11574471]
  • We found that constitutive CRP-independent udp expression in many of the isolated mutants was caused by loss of part or all of CRP1 , indicating that it is important in CRP activation and CytR repression of udp transcription . [8626289]
  • To test these hypotheses and to assess how linkage might be involved in differential regulation of transcription , we have investigated cooperative and competitive CytR and CRP binding to the udp promoter . [10347150]
  • CytR has no effect on basal level transcription but instead requires CRP binding to mediate repression ( 16 , 18 ) . [8969182]
  • CRP directly interacts with CytR , thereby shifting its binding mode for activation or repression of transcription of its targets . [24814025]
  • This is unlike the protein -- protein contact-mediated repression by CytR , which involves antiactivation by contact 39 between CytR repressor and CRP activator at promoters . [15533432]
  • These results indicate that CytR is highly adaptable to different arrangements of CytR and CRP sites in the absence of cytidine in order to form the three-protein repression complex . [10347150]

  • First , CytR and CRP bind cooperatively to form a three-protein complex on the DNA . [10347150]
  • Together , CytR and CRP bind co-opera-tively to their respective targets , and a nucleoprotein complex with protein stoichiometries of 1:2 is formed . [9767576]
  • Chahla , M. , Wooll , J. , Laue , T. M. , Nguyen , N. , and Senear , D. F. ( 2003 ) Role of protein-protein bridging interactions on cooperative assembly of DNA-bound CRP-CytR-CRP complex and regulation of the Escherichia coli CytR regulon . [20000490]
  • Thus , protein-protein communication between DNA-bound CytR and CRP underlies repression , co-activation , and induction . [10347150]
  • This was interpreted to indicate that CytR mutants associate via bridging protein-protein interactions alone to form a functional , DNA-bound CRP-CytR-CRP repression complex . [12667072]
  • ACKNOWLEDGMENTS We thank Steven A. Short for the gift of puriﬁed CytR protein , Sankar Adhya for sending us the CRP overproducer strain SA500 , and Kalpana Srivastava for technical assistance . [8626289]
  • However , there is a small but significant decrease in cooperative free energy for the three-protein complex CRP-CytR-CRP when bound to udp as compared with that seen when bound to deoP2 . [10347150]
  • Despite only weak association between CytR and CRP in solution , our results demonstrate the formation of a relatively stable complex in which the Core domain forms a protein bridge between tandem CRP dimers when bound to either udpP or deoP2 . [12667072]
  • A direct way to evaluate the linkage would be to compare association of operator-oligonucleotide-bound CRP and CytR to association of free CRP and CytR ( 26 , 43 ) . [12667072]
  • CytR forms a protein bridge between the bound CRP dimers . [10347150]
  • This would suggest that CytR is primarily a protein-protein bridge , dependent on its interactions with CRP bound to the flanking CRP sites for association with its operator . [8969182]
  • Recently , it was shown by DNase I footprinting in vitro that therepression complex most likely consists of one molecule CytR and two molecules of CRP , i.e. that the activatorprotein CRP is also required for repression ( S ~ gaard-Andersen eatl . [8394345]
  • Consistent with the expectation that cooperativity should enhance-the-activity of CytR as an RCTD antagonist , the three protein , CRP-CytR-CRP complex is required for repression ; CytR alone does not repress basal level transcription ( 1 ) . [12667072]
  • The three-protein CRP-CytR-CRP complex was shown not only to reverse CRP-mediated activation but also to actively block basal level activity , reducing transcription to a level significantly below that in the absence of CRP . [12667072]
  • In this complex , CytR binds to an operator site ( usually referred to as CytO ) that is flanked by tandem CRP operators , CRP1 and CRP2 , as are found in most CytR-regulated promoters . [10347150]
  • Implicit in this model is that CytR binds co-operatively to tandem , properly spaced CRP targets , since only a small set of CRP-activated promoters are repressed by CytR . [1962841]

  • The direction arrows below the helix indicate the phosphodiester bonds in the CytR-binding site that are cleaved in the DNAase I protection experiments in the presence of CAMP-CRP and CytR-wt or CytRA9-48 24 - + Glu , or CytRA9-48 to reactions containing CAMP-CRP gives rise to a single new band with a lower mobility ( Figure 4C , lanes 3-l 3 ) . [8221894]
  • In the first type of binding experiment , each protein , either CRP or CytR , is ti-trated alone ; in the second , each protein , either CRP or CytR , is titrated in the presence of a constant , near the saturating concentration of the other protein ( Fig. 4 ) . [10347150]
  • Second , binding of each protein ( CytR and CRP ) to each promoter is analyzed in the presence of a fixed and saturating concentration of the other protein ( CRP and CytR , respectively ) . [20000490]
  • For a system in which only intrinsic binding and cooperativity contribute , the difference between ΔGLoad , i 's obtained for binding of either protein ( CytR or CRP ) in the presence versus absence of the other yields the cooperativity . [20000490]
  • In principle , the same value should be obtained by summing the Δ ( ΔGLoad , i ) values for CRP binding to CRP1 and to CRP2 in the presence versus absence of saturating CytR . [20000490]
  • Competition contributes differently to ΔG1 and ΔG2 for CRP binding to CRP1 and to CRP2 in the presence of fixed CytR concentration than it does to ΔG3 for CytR binding to CytO in the presence of fixed CRP concentration . [20000490]
  • In Fig. 2B the binding of the two CRP proteins is compared in the presence of various amounts of partially purified CytR repressor . [1647022]
  • To test this prediction quantitatively , we conducted parallel titrations of CRP binding in the presence of saturating cytidine , with and without fixed but now subsaturating CytR ( Fig. 9 ) . [8969182]
  • The free energy change for the association of CytR Core domain binding with the CRP2-promoter complex ( ∆ Gbridge ) was determined from paired experiments in which the promoter was titrated with CRP in the presence or absence of a fixed concentration of CytR Core domain ( 0.5-15 µM ) . [12667072]
  • Since this association favors promoter complexes with two CRP dimers bound , thus mimicking cooperative CRP binding , ∆ Gbridge can be evaluated by comparing CRP binding in the presence and absence of fixed concentrations of CytR Core domain . [12667072]
  • Figure 6 depicts CRP binding to deoP2 in the presence and absence of 4.0 µM CytR ∆ 2-62 dimer ( left-hand panels ) and 13.1 µM CytR ∆ 2-63 dimer ( right-hand panels ) . [12667072]
  • To address this question experimentally , matched CRP binding titrations of both deoP2 and udpP were conducted with and without CytR Core domain , as before ( Figure 6 ) , but now also comparing the presence and absence of 1 mM cytidine . [12667072]
  • Individual-site binding isotherms were generated by footprint titration of CRP binding in the presence ( panels B and D ) and absence ( panels A and C ) of fixed concentrations of CytR Core domain . [12667072]
  • Parallel experiments of individual-site binding of CRP to the deoP2 promoter in the presence ( panels B and D ) and absence ( panels A and C ) of 13.1 µM CytR ∆ 2-63 . [12667072]
  • This simplification has a small but still observable effect on the accuracy of the fits to the titrations when CytR and CRP bind DNA together , with one protein in the presence of a near saturating concentration of the other . [10347150]
  • However , the result of this pattern of effects is that the free energy change for formation of the ternary protein complex of CRP-CytR-CRP bound to DNA is only slightly smaller in the presence of cytidine than in its absence ( Table I ) . [10347150]
  • In the presence of CAMP-CRP and CytRA9-48 , a complex with the same borders as the CytR-wt protein is formed ; however , CytRA9-48 only results in modest changes in the DNAase I digestion pattern ( see Figure 4A , lane 5 ; Figure 4B , lane 4 ) . [8221894]
  • When the same experiment is performed using CRP ( Pro-110 - * Ser ) only the fastest moving CRP/CytR/deoP2 complex appears ( lane 7 ) , and this complex is formed with a significantly lower efficiency in than the presence of CRP-wt . [1647022]
  • In the presence of both CytR and CRP , a third retarded complex with a lower mobility is observed ( lane 5 ) . [9767576]
  • A direct connection between CytR regulation and the presence of intact tandem CRP targets in deoCp2 ( Fig. 1 ) was evident from analyses of deletion and point mutations . [2170326]
  • This was done by comparing the energetics of CytR-CRP association to the energetics of cooperativity when CytR and CRP bind to deoP2 and to udpP both in the presence and in the absence of cytidine . [12667072]
  • Second , the region between the CRP targets is strongly protected in the presence of both proteins , which suggests that this region is occupied by CytR . [1649947]
  • ( C ) Binding of the three CytR proteins to deoP2 in the presence of CAMP-CRP . [8221894]
  • Figure 5 presents a footprint autoradiogram from a representative experiment in which deoP2 was titrated with CRP in the presence of 4.0 µM CytR ∆ 2-62 dimer . [12667072]
  • It seems fairly evident that this difference , accounting for only about a 3-fold effect on affinity , is insufficient to account for induction simply on the basis of reduced CytO occupancy Our cddP data demonstrate yet a third pattern of effects on cooperativity , in which the pairwise interaction between CytR and CRP bound to CRP1 is completely unaffected while the pairwise interaction between CytR and CRP bound to CRP1 is greatly reduced . [20000490]
  • These results also a Free energy changes for intrinsic binding of CRP to operator sites CRP1 and CRP2 of the E. coli udp and deoP2 promoters and for subsequent binding of CytR Core domain to form the DNA-bound CRP-Core domain-CRP bridged complex . [12667072]
  • CytR Core domain associates when CRP is bound to both CRP1 and CRP2 as a result of favorably oriented protein-protein contacts , despite no interaction between Core domain and DNA . [12667072]
  • Even with its DNA-binding domain deleted , CytR will associate to form a protein bridge between CRP dimers bound to CRP1 and to CRP2 , thus indicating that direct interaction between the DNA-bound proteins is the mechanism for the cooperativity ( 20 ) . [20000490]
  • Additionally , while cytidine binding to CytR nearly eliminates the pairwise interactions between CytR and CRP bound at CRP1 , it has little effect on pairwise cooperativity between CytR and CRP bound at CRP2 or as a consequence on the overall cooperativity of the three-protein complex in which CRP is bound to both sites . [20000490]
  • Whereas at deoP2 cytidine binding to CytR essentially eliminates cooperativity in the three-protein complex , at udpP it serves to eliminate cooperativity only between CytR and CRP bound to CRP1 . [20000490]
  • Interaction of CytR with these sites provides a complex pattern of both competitive and cooperative interactions between CytR and CRP bound to CRP1 and CRP2 . [8969182]
  • As a result of this cooperativity CytR is recruited to CytO when CRP binds to the flanking sites , CRP1 and CRP2 , to yield a three-protein , DNA-bound complex , CRP-CytR-CRP . [20000490]
  • Thus , it appears that CytR not only occludes interactions involving RNAP RCTD as a result of bridging interactions but also modulates the activity of CRP1-bound CRP . [12667072]
  • Second , it may also be significant that the three-way cooperativity , i.e. with both CRP sites filled and CytR bound in between , equals the additive sum of free energy changes for these pairwise interactions . [8969182]
  • Whereas the effect of cytidine on pairwise cooperativity between CytR and CRP bound to CRP2 is modest , similar to that for wild type udp , pairwise cooperativity between CytR and CRP bound to CRP1 is nearly eliminated , similar to that for deoP2 ( 3 ) . [10347150]
  • This model assumes no significant association of CytR Core domain when CRP is bound to either , but not both , CRP1 or CRP2 . [12667072]
  • This suggests that CytR bound to the intervening site simultaneously contacts CRP bound to both CRP1 and CRP2 and with no influence of either pairwise interaction on the other . [8969182]
  • Since CytR and CRP bind in a cooperative manner , the separate interactions between CytR and CytO , and between CytR and both CRP1-bound and CRP2-bound CRP , must combine to yield a net free energy change that is more favorable than for any of these individual interactions . [12667072]
  • A second surprise uncovered by our analysis of udpP is that the inducer cytidine does not eliminate all CytR-CRP cooperativity , as it does at deoP2 , but instead eliminates only the pairwise interaction between CRP bound to CRP1 and CytR bound to CytO ( 22 ) . [20000490]
  • Second , the free energy changes for pairwise cooperativity between CytR and CRP are the same whether CRP is bound to CRP1 or to CRP2 and are the same for udp as for deoP2 . [10347150]
  • An important result of our study is that whereas cytidine is an effector of CytR interactions with CRP bound to udp-CRP1 , cytidine is not an effector of CytR interactions with CRP bound to udp-CRP2 . [10347150]
  • At udpP , however , the pairwise interaction between CytR and CRP bound to CRP2 is essentially unaffected ( 22 ) . [20000490]
  • '' How can CytR can make the same interaction with CRP bound to CRP1 and CRP2 given spacers of 15 and 8 bps ? [8969182]
  • At cddP , cooperativity between CytR and CRP bound to CRP1 is largely retained , while cooperativity between CytR and CRP bound to CRP2 is largely eliminated . [20000490]
  • Presumably , either the spacing between the CytR and CRP sites or something inherent in the CytR site , such as the spacing between recognition motifs , is responsible for controlling whether interactions between CytR and CRP are still possible when cytidine is bound . [10347150]
  • CRP bound to this duplicate site seemed not to interact with CytR . [8626289]
  • By contrast , at high CRP concentration , favorable interactions with CRP bound to CRP1 and CRP2 would increase apparent affinity of CytR for its intervening site , and this would not be offset by unfavorable competitive interactions . [8969182]
  • If direct protein-protein interactions provide the driving force for cooperativity , as has been presumed ( 23 58 ) , then CytR bound to the intervening site must make substantially identical interactions with CRP , whether bound to CRP1 or to CRP2 . [8969182]
  • These results strongly indicate that CytR can be directed to deoP2 in the absence of specific CytR-DNA interactions and , by implication , that the protein-protein interactions between CytR and CAMP-CRP play a key role in specifying the site of action of CytR . [8221894]
  • In contrast to the low affinity for solution assembly of CytR and CRP , these two CytR Core domain constructs show appreciable affinity for bridging between tandem , DNA-bound CRP dimers . [12667072]
  • Thus , DNA-bound CRP molecules engaged in nucleoprotein formation by CytR are no longer accessible for RNA polymerase , andsterichindrance could account for negative regulation of deoP2 by CytR . [8394345]
  • Either competition between CytR and RNAP for interaction with CRP is the main mechanism of repression , with RNAP-DNA interactions being essentially ancillary , or cytidine-liganded CytR remains bound to the DNA in a conformation which prevents CytR from acting as an allosteric antiactivator of either or both of the flanking CRP molecules . [20000490]

  • Repression by the cooperative CRP-CytR-CRP complex results from competition between CytR and RNAP , both of which are recruited by CRP to-bind to the DNA sequence flanked by CRP1 and CRP2 ( 10 ) . [10347150]
  • n i induced DNA bends in the circular permutation restriction nuclease cleavag CAMP-CRP causes the largest variations in complex mobilities and , therefore , induces a greater DNA bend than CytR ( Thompson & Landy , 1988 ) . [1328649]
  • For CytR to bridge the gap between promoter-bound CRP dimers and juxtapose the interacting surfaces of CytR and CRP as delineated by mutagenesis experiments ( 39 ) , the promoter DNA must be bent substantially . [12667072]
  • But a three way cooperative complex also forms in which CytR forms a protein bridge between tandem , DNA-bound CRP dimers . [12667072]

  • One can imagine scenarios in which CytR remains bound to DNA , if not to CRP , under inducing conditions . [10347150]

  • The effective affinity of CytR for CytO ( in the presence of CRP ) is only 1.2 times higher than cytidine-liganded CytR , yet induction is fairly robust , accounting for a roughly 20-fold increase in transcription according to reporter gene assays ( 21 ) . [20000490]
  • Cooperative and Competitive Interactions of CytR -- The initial indication and one functional consequence of these interactions is that while saturation of CRP1 and CRP2 greatly increases the apparent affinity of CytR for its putative operator located between these , saturation by CytR has a much lesser effect on the apparent affinity of CRP for CRP1 and CRP2 ( Table I ) ( 21 ) . [8969182]
  • The total effect of cooperativity with both CRP sites on CytR affinity is 100-1000-fold in different promoters and conditions ( cf. Table I and Refs . [8969182]
  • DISCUSSION The most significant aspect of the CytR regulon is that a complex pattern of coordinate and differential regulation of a large number of unlinked transcriptional units is provided by interactions between CRP , CytR , and the DNA sequences of the various promoters . [8969182]
  • Binding in vitro of CytR and CRP to spacing variants The relative afﬁnity of the promoter variants for CytR and CRP , alone and in combination , was measured in a simple competition assay . [9466254]
  • The apparent afﬁnity of CytR for selected DNA sequences and deoP2-wt , -- 9 in the absence ( black bars ) or presence ( gray bars ) of 6310 M CRP , was determined by the mobility shift assay ( see Materials and methods ) . [9155036]
  • The interaction of CytR with udpP DNA ( full protection ) required the presence of CRP and CRP2 . [8626289]
  • The formation of these complexes involves both CytR ± DNA interaction and CytR ± CRP interaction . [11574471]
  • Role of Competition and Cooperativity in deoP2 Regulation -- The important question remaining is how these multiple competitive and cooperative interactions between CytR and CRP regulate transcription . [8969182]

  • The free energy change we obtain for this interaction , ∆ Gobridge ) -7.8 kcal/mol , is essentially double what we estimate for solution assembly of CytR and CRP to form a heterotetramer . [12667072]
  • The deoC , nupG and tsx operons that are under CytR regulation were activated by CRP in our study . [15520470]
  • The central importance of CAMP-CRP in CytR repression is illustrated by several observations . [8221894]
  • The stimulation by CytR also required CRP in the cases of dup1 and dup361 but apparently not in the cases of del224 and del364 . [8626289]
  • The structure of nupG is an inversion of deoP2 , and similar interactions between CytR and CRP , no doubt , explain the apparent one-way stimulation ( 11 ) . [8969182]
  • The ∆ G obtained for this reaction accounts for only a small fraction of CytR and CRP dimers associated as a tetramer . [12667072]
  • The latter is stabilized by cooperative interactions between CRP and CytR . [8969182]
  • Additionally , puriﬁed E. coli CytR and CRP proteins were used in in vitro assays ( gel retardation ) to determine their ability to-bind heterologous promoters . [14499937]
  • However , in strains containing altered CRP proteins that bind to the mutated CRP sites with a higher affinity than CRP-wt protein , CytR regulation was reestabl-ished . [1661372]
  • For example , CRP depends on direct protein -- protein interactions with MelR and CytR to-bind low-afﬁnity CRP sites in the melA and deoC promoters , respectively ( 58 -- 60 ) Figure 8 . [17068078]
  • CRP requires cooperativity with MelR and CytR to-bind to low affinity sites in the melAB and deoCABD promoters , among others . [17068078]
  • CRP alone activates transcription , whereas the CRP-CytR cooperatively bound to OCRP and OCYTR , respectively , represses transcription . [23028500]
  • Our results support and extend a model in which transcription is repressed when CRP moieties are bound to two appropriately positioned sites in the udpP and are themselves bound and stabilized by CytR . [8626289]
  • CRP and CytR designated filled sites according to the transcription factor bound ; O designates empty sites . [20000490]
  • Upon repression , the CytR repressor binds between the two bound CRP molecules , inactivating them and causing repression . [1943993]
  • A summary of the protection experiments ( Figures 5C and 5D ) demonstrates that the overall structure of the two repression complexes is identical ; i.e. , CAMP-CRP is bound at the tandem CRP sites , and CytR is located in between . [8221894]
  • Figure 3 also shows the effect when CytR ∆ 2-63 was added to reaction mixtures containing CRP dimer at a concentration of 13 nM . [12667072]
  • Strikingly , the effect on CytR regulation varies in the four promoters tested ( Table 2 ) : all CRP mutants almost completely abolish CytR regulation in tsx , whereas a low residual CytR regulation is still present in deoP2 and cdd . [1647022]
  • When 0.2 mM cytidine-liganded CytR was subsequently added , CRP affinity for CRP1 and CRP2 dropped by over 2-fold , giving DGCRP1 5 211.3 6 0.1 kcal/mol and DGCRP2 5 212.9 6 0.2 kcal/mol . [8969182]
  • However , we do observe an additional few-fold decrease in apparent CRP affinity when the CytR concentration is increased to 0.4 mM , consistent with a simple competitive model . [8969182]
  • Configuration 5 pertains to the complex formed by association of CytR Core domain in which ∆ G represents the free energy change for bridging CytR-CRP bridge interaction . [12667072]
  • On the basis of ∆ Gbridge ≈ -8 kcal/mol , ∆ G of the order -3 to -4 kcal/mol might be anticipated for a 1:1 association between CytR and CRP to form a hetero-tetrameric complex . [12667072]
  • In the well-characterized case of the CytR regulon , CRP expresses positive or negative inﬂuences in collaboration with CytR ( Pedersen & Valentin-Hansen , 1997 ; Holt & Senear , 2013 ) . [24814025]
  • In this context , the suggestion that the primary competition between CytR and RNAP is for interaction with CRP ( 31 ) is attractive . [10347150]
  • In this model , the association of the z-average molecular weight monomer corresponds to assocation of CytR and CRP . [12667072]
  • These results support our hypothesis that cytidine is an allosteric-effector of CytR conformations that constrain its simultaneous association with CytO and the flanking CRP dimers . [12667072]
  • These findings indicate that both CRP targets are required for efficient CytR repression of deoCp2 . [2170326]
  • These results clearly show the importance of the tandem CRP targets for CytR repression of deoCp2 . [2170326]
  • RESULTS Our goal is to understand how CytR and CRP mediate differential regulation of CytR-regulated promoters . [10347150]
  • Senear , D. F. , Perini , L. T. , and Gavigan , S. A. ( 1998 ) Analysis of interactions between CytR and CRP at CytR-regulated promoters . [20000490]
  • Thus , in addition to the tandem CRP targets , the distance between the two targets seems to be an important factor for CytR regulation . [2170326]
  • A key to CytR-mediated regulation is that despite roles as functional antagonists , CytR and CRP bind with positive cooperativity to their respective operators ( 8 , 9 ) . [12667072]
  • These studies have also identified competition between CytR and CRP as an additional contributor to differential regulation . [20000490]
  • Central to this process and to the differential regulation of expression are the interactions between CytR and CRP . [10347150]
  • To analyze the mechanism ( s ) involved in this combinatorial regulation , we endeavored to isolate CRP mutants that could not support CytR regulation . [1647022]
  • Hence , both CRP targets are involved in and required for efficient CytR regulation . [2170326]
  • Indeed , the effect of competition at deoP2 is to largely eliminate recruitment of CRP by CytR , thereby negating the role of CytR as a co-activator . [10347150]
  • However , cooperativity also means that CytR can recruit CRP and , by doing so , can act as a co-activa-tor . [10347150]
  • Because cytidine is an effector of CytR-CRP cooperativity , its effect should also be linked to how CytR binds at the various promoters . [10347150]
  • This suggests that the separate interactions between CytR and each CRP dimer are additive , yielding a connection free energy of zero for bridging . [12667072]
  • On the other hand , the free energy changes for cooperativity between CytR and CRP are independent of the particular model and so appear to provide accurate descriptions of these interactions . [8969182]
  • It is ironic , given the results we report here , that until relatively recently CRP and CytR were believed to compete to-bind to the same sites ( cf. Ref . [8969182]
  • Only when CRP occupies the two sites can CytR bind and repress . [1943993]
  • But simple recruitment of this sort makes little functional sense , as it would yield only two significantly populated states , i.e. CRP and CytR sites empty or CRP and CytR sites filled . [8969182]
  • Alternatively , CytR may adopt a conformation at these sites that is incompatible with positive CRP -- CytR interactions . [9155036]
  • There seem to be rather strict rules for the position of the L and R CytR half-sites relative to the ﬂanking CRP sites . [9155036]
  • Binding sites for regulatory proteins CRP , CytR and DnaA are indicated . [17185540]
  • As practical approximations to the limit of saturating concentrations , 0.1 mM CRP ( total dimer ) and 75 nM CytR were used here . [10347150]
  • Given the relatively low solubility limit for CytR , a high CRP concentration was used to drive the assembly and maximize sensitivity to hetero-oligomers . [12667072]
  • As a practical limit to saturating concentration , 0.1 μM dimer was used for both CRP and CytR . [20000490]
  • We propose instead that the CytR-CRP interactions themselves are critical to CytR-mediated repression . [20000490]
  • We evaluated the cooperative interactions and competition between CytR and CRP as described previously ( 19 , 22 ) . [20000490]

  • This phenomenology is consistent with recent reports of `` unidirectional stimulation '' in CRP and CytR interaction with nupG ( 11 ) . [8969182]
  • Third , the truncated CytR proteins still have the ability to interact with CAMP-CRP , to respond to inducer , and to oligomerize . [8221894]
  • Simple cooperativity is of course a two-way street , and as such , CytR would be a net recruiter of CRP as well as the reverse . [8969182]

  • Model for Cooperative and Competitive Binding of CytR and cAMP-CRP -- To determine whether such interactions of CytR with DNA sequences overlapping and thereby occluding or competing with CRP binding to CRP1 and CRP2 can account quantitatively for both the loading free energy changes in Table I and apparent free energy changes in Fig. 6 , two models that incorporate two additional CytR binding sites and which constitute opposing possibilities were evaluated . [8969182]
  • The inducer of CytR , cytidine : perturbs the cooperative t ) KA binding of CAMP-CRP and CytR by disrupting the protein-protein contacts between t , hr two proteins ( Pedersen et al. , 1991 ; Gertach rf nl . [1328649]
  • The co-operative binding of CytR and CRP relies on direct protein -- protein interactions ( Søgaard-Andersen and Valentin-Hansen , 1993 ) . [9466254]
  • The results of these experiments ( summarized in Figure 3 ) strongly point to the conclusions that CytRAS-48-mediated repression does not rely on the exact sequence in the CytR-binding site and that the specificity of CytR can be achieved solely through the protein-protein interactions to CAMP-CRP , whereas the CytR-DNA interactions may primarily serve to increase the stability of the repression complex . [8221894]
  • These data thus provide a picture of the CytRlcAMP-CRP regulatory system in which the site of action of CytR can be specified by the protein-protein interactions to CAMP-CRP and in which the CytR-DNA interactions may primarily contribute to CytR binding and repression by stabilizing the CytRl CAMP-CRPIDNA repression complex . [8221894]
  • Second , CytR and CRP are reported to mutually antagonize each other 's protein binding induced bends in the cytRP sequence ( 10 ) . [8969182]
  • CRP , CytR and DnaA protein binding region is indicated . [19076234]
  • The cooperative binding of CytR and CAMP-CRP is mediated by protein-protein interactions between the proteins . [8221894]
  • The CytR protein stabilized binding of CRP to the CRP sites in udpP . [8626289]
  • CytR is a co-activator when it recruits CRP to its DNA binding site ( s ) via cooperative binding to DNA , and it is a repressor when it is part of a three-protein complex that is stabilized by CytR-CRP cooperativity . [10347150]
  • Therefore , it is probable that it is the CytR core protein , not the DNA-binding domains of CytR , that interacts with CRP . [8596434]
  • Whereas inducer or co-repressor binding to other family members controls a switch between DNA-binding protein and non-DNA-binding protein conformations , cytidine binding to CytR affects only cooperative interactions between CytR and CRP . [10347150]
  • This special mode of protein-DNA interaction in which CytR can either enhance CRP binding or compete for CRP binding affects both repression and activation . [10347150]
  • It has been suggested that the significant competition underlying CytR-mediated repression is between CytR and RNAP for making protein-protein contacts with CRP , rather than competition between CytR and RNAP for binding DNA ( 31 ) . [10347150]
  • The current view is that transcription from these promoters involves CRP binding to CRP1 and that repression involves the binding of CytR protein to CRPs that are , in turn , bound to both CRP1 and CRP2 in the promoter region . [8626289]
  • The unusual location of the CytR operator in the deoP-2 regulatory region suggests that this repressor inhibits transcription by preventing the binding of the CRP protein or by changing the DNA conformation in such a way that CRP fails to function . [3515317]
  • The cAMP.CRP / CytR regulatory case has a remarkable functional relationship to several eukaryotic systems , e.g. in yeast the activator protein GRM is required for efficient DNA binding of the repressor protein a2 , and GRM can by itself bind toDNA and activate transcription ( Benderand Sprague , 1987 ; Keleher etal . [1655726]
  • Only a small set of CRP-regulated promoters are repressed by CytR , however , as at least two properly spaced CRP binding sites seem to be required for efficient binding of this repressor . [2575702]
  • Altogether the binding experiments demonstrate that CytR and CRP bind synergistically to rpoH forming a nucleoprotein complex , which in analogy to the repression complexes formed at most CytR-regulated promoters , appears to consist of one molecule of CytR bound in between two molecules of CRP . [9767576]
  • This band was interpreted to contain a bound complex of CytR and CRP bound to one of the two CRP sites at a low CRP concentration ( 0.25 ng/ml ) ; no band attributable to the binding of only CRP was seen . [8626289]

[20000490]
  • Consistent with the suggestion that the additional CytR-DNA interactions provide differential modulation of CRP-mediated activation , our results indicate that CytR competes for CRP binding to udp-CRP2 but does not compete for CRP binding to CRP1 . [10347150]
  • We proposed that different patterns of competition between CytR and CRP for binding to CRP1 and CRP2 at different promoters could provide differential modulation of CRP-mediated activation . [10347150]
  • We suggest that cooperative CytR binding has very different effects on class I CRP activation mediated by CRP2 versus class II activation mediated by CRP1 . [8969182]
  • We start with the premise that CytR is a modulator of CRP activation rather than a repressor per se , a view consistent with the fact that CytR is ineffective in the absence of CRP binding . [8969182]
  • Cytidine binding to CytR releases the latter from the complex , hence the activation by CRP resumes and the gene is derepressed [ 33,34 ] . [23028500]
  • However , with so little bridged complex formed at these CytR ∆ 2-63 concentrations ( 13-15 µM ) , the stabilizing effect on CRP binding is small , and a lower affinity limit for CytR ∆ 2-63 association is not precisely determined . [12667072]
  • Under the conditions used in the gel mobility shift assay , CRP stimulates binding of CytR < 20-fold ( compare the intensities of the bands containing CytR in lanes 2 and 7 ) . [9767576]
  • When we analyzed CytR and CRP binding to the deoP2 promoter ( 5 ) , we also considered an alternative explanation for the competition between CytR and CRP for CRP1 and CRP2 . [10347150]
  • But when CRP is added to this same CytR concentration , cooperative binding of CytR and CRP produces a footprint that extends beyond CRP1 to the 210 region of the promoter . [8969182]
  • Subsequently , global analysis of the individual site CRP and CytR binding data was conducted using equations that describe cooperative and competitive binding of CRP and CytR according to the model defined by the promoter configurations specified in Table II . [10347150]
  • Ratios of variances were also separately calculated considering the data obtained for each binding site and set of effectors , e.g. , for binding of CytR to CytO of the wild-type promoter in the presence of CRP and cytidine . [20000490]
  • To investigate the chemical and structural basis for these effects , we investigated how cytidine binding affects association between CytR and CRP in solution and how it affects the binding of CytR deletion mutants lacking the DNA binding HTH domain , with tandem CRP dimers bound to either udpP or deoP2 . [12667072]
  • To assess these effects and their linkage to cytidine binding , we investigated the assembly of CytR and CRP in solution and compared this to the association of the Core domain dimer with tandem , promoter-bound CRP . [12667072]
  • If so , elimination of CytR-CRP interactions in response to cytidine binding might allow the CRP-RNAP interaction necessary for full activation even in the presence of DNA-bound CytR . [10347150]
  • Thus , defining these sites thermodynamically , by their effect on th coupled energetics for binding of CytR and CRP to their primary operators , but without regard to any particular sequence of DNA , generates parameter values that are indistinguishable from those obtained from the protection actually observed . [20000490]
  • A critical component of the regulation is that CytR and CRP bind DNA cooperatively , meaning that CRP binding to CRP1 and CRP2 enhanced the affinity of CytR for CytO and vice versa ( 18 , 19 ) . [20000490]
  • Two nanomolar DNA was used for binding with CRP and CytR proteins in concentrations shown in the ﬁgure legends , using the same as for gel retardation binding buffer . [8626289]
  • The challenge then is to explain both the very broad specificity of CytR for DNA binding and for CytR-CRP cooperativity when cytidine is not bound , together with the control of cooperative interactions when cytidine is bound . [10347150]
  • CytR is unique among LacI/GalR family members in that binding of its regulatory ligand , cytidine , is linked not to DNA-binding affinity but instead to the cooperative interactions between CytR bound at CytO and CRP bound to CRP1 and CRP2 . [20000490]
  • This indicates that cytidine binding to CytR and bridging of CytR between pairs of DNA-bound CRP dimers are thermodynamically couple processes . [12667072]
  • Analysis of Heterologous Cooperative Interaction between deoP2-bound CRP and CytR -- To evaluate cooperative interactions between different proteins binding to DNA , we considered the thermodynamic cycle for their simultaneous binding ( cf. Ref . [8969182]
  • We speculate that these different conformational modes restrict interactions between bound DNA-bound CytR and DNA-bound CRP in ways that are reflected in the different effects of cytidine binding to CytR in CytR-CRP cooperativity . [20000490]
  • Perhaps the simplest explanation to-tie together these various effects is to suggest that cytidine binding results in conformational changes that reorient the interactions between CytR , CRP , and DNA . [12667072]
  • What then is the significance of multiple CytR-DNA interactions and competition between CytR and CRP , and presumably also between CytR and RNAP , for binding DNA ? [10347150]
  • Inhibition of CRP Binding by Cytidine-liganded CytR -- A second testable prediction of our model is based on the unusual mechanism of induction in which cytidine is an effector of heterologous cooperative interaction between CytR and CRP ( 6 ) 2 rather than of intrinsic binding of CytR to DNA . [8969182]
  • To address this question requires CytR Core domain in which the interaction between CytR and DNA is eliminated but other CytR functions ( i.e. , dimerization , cytidine binding , and CRP association ) are unperturbed . [12667072]
  • Alternatively , CytR , CRP , and/or the DNA would have to be distorted from the symmetric arrangement proposed in the model to accommodate off-center binding by CytR to CytO . [10347150]
  • However , one can not rule out possible CytR interaction with the DNA after binding to CRP . [8626289]

  • The molecular model defined by the promoter configurations listed in Table 3 accounts for CRP binding to CRP1 and to CRP2 and for CytR binding to CytO , with both pairwise and three-way CytR-CRP cooperativity . [20000490]
  • The results also confirm the expectation that CytR and CRP compete for binding to CRP2 but not for binding to CRP1 . [10347150]
  • The reason for this is that competition between CRP for binding to CRP1 and CRP2 and CytR for binding to satellite sites that occlude CRP1 and CRP2 complicates this simple analysis . [20000490]
  • The net effect on CytR binding is substantial while the net effect on CRP binding to CRP2 is slight . [8969182]

  • The values in Table I demonstrate a similar behavior , although with a different pattern of effects , for CytR and CRP binding to udp . [10347150]
  • The central role of cooperativity in regulation is highlighted by the fact that binding of the inducer , cyt-idine , to CytR is coupled to CytR-CRP cooperativity ; this underlies the mechanism for induction . [10347150]
  • The significance of CytR-CRP cooperativity to this competition is underscored by the fact that binding of cytidine ( the inducer ligand ) to CytR is coupled to CytR-CRP cooperativity ( 19 , 21 ) , a feature that is unique among LacI family repressors . [20000490]
  • Yet , regulation of cytRP , in which there is only one CRP site , also depends on cooperative CytR and CRP binding ( 10 ) . [8969182]
  • For binding experiments in which both CytR and CRP are present , analysis according to Equation 1 provides an accurate estimate of the individual site loading free energy change , DGl , i ( 25 ) , and its confidence limits ( 26 , 27 ) . [10347150]
  • Fitting to Equation 1 was also used to estimate individual site loading free energy changes DGl , i ( 38 ) for binding experiments in which both CytR and CRP were present . [8969182]
  • Thus , differential and coordinate gene regulation must depend on different dispositions of CRP and CytR binding sites , different protein binding affinities , and/or different levels of site-site interaction or cooperativity . [8969182]
  • Also , point mutations in either CRP site reduce or abolish CytR titration ; however , no co-operativity is observed in the interaction of CytR with the two CRP binding sites . [1962841]

  • In this view , CytR is presumed to be an ineffective inhibitor of transcription in the absence of CRP binding only because its free concentration is insufficient to fill the site . [8969182]
  • In addition , it was recently observed ( 11 , 21 ) that the apparent cooperativity , when assessed by the effect of saturating CRP concentration on CytR affinity , is substantially greater than when cooperativity is assessed by the effect of saturating CytR concentration on CRP binding . [8969182]

  • In contrast , the interaction between CytR and CRP bound to CRP2 of udpP is virtually unaffected by cytidine ( 11 ) resulting in only a small decrease in overall CytR binding affinity . [12667072]
  • In addition , concomitant with CRP binding to CRP1 , CytR will tend binding to CytO , due to its recruitment by the strong threeway cooperative interactions . [20000490]
  • In this situation , CytR competes directly for CRP binding to CRP1 and CRP2 . [10347150]
  • In contrast , whereas CytR is a net recruiter for CRP binding to CRP1 , it is not a net recruiter for CRP binding to CRP2 . [10347150]
  • In this model , binding of CytR at the sites overlapping CRP1 and CRP2 and of CRP binding to CRP1 and CRP2 is mutually exclusive . [20000490]
  • In addition , it is only by including competition between CytR and CRP for binding to CRP2 in the global analysis of the footprint data that we can accurately account for the experimentally determined loading free energy changes ( Table I ) . [10347150]
  • In energetic terms , if most of the loss of translational , vibrational , and rotational energy that accompanies macromolecular association is paid by the first interaction , the result can be a free energy change for binding of an oligomer , such as CytR-CRP heterotetramer , that is more favorable than the sum of free energy changes for separate binding of the individual proteins . [12667072]
  • To assess these effects together with competition between CytR and CRP for binding CRP2 , we extended the model defined in Table II to include terms to describe the effects of cytidine on cooperativity . [10347150]
  • Finally , how does pairwise cooperativity between CytR binding to CytO and CRP binding to CRP2 of udpP survive cytidine binding , particularly when pairwise cooperative interactions with CRP bound to CRP1 of udpP or either CRP site of deoP2 does not ? [12667072]
  • DG13 and DG23 , which pertain to pairwise cooperative interactions between CytR binding and CRP bound to either CRP1 or CRP2 , were similarly evaluated using reduced valency mutants in which specific binding to either CRP1 ( CRP12 ) or CRP2 ( CRP22 ) was eliminated . [8969182]
  • One effect of competition between CytR and CRP for binding to CRP1 and CRP2 of deoP2 is that whereas CRP , whether bound to CRP1 alone , to CRP2 alone , or to both together , is a net recruiter of CytR to CytO ; the reverse is not so . [10347150]
  • First , the relative affinities for CRP binding to CRP1 and CRP2 and for CytR binding to CytO are very similar in udp and deoP . [10347150]
  • By eliminating cooperativity between CytR and CRP bound to flanking sites , cytidine should make CytR into a simple competitor for CRP binding to CRP1 and CRP2 . [8969182]
  • Cytidine binding to CytR largely eliminates pairwise cooperativity between CytR and CRP bound to CRP1 of udp . [10347150]
  • Here too , CRP bound to either CRP1 or CRP2 or both is a net recruiter for CytR binding . [10347150]
  • Although CytR binds to an additional site located just downstream from the transcription start site as noted above , there is no interaction between CytR binding to this site and CytR/CRP binding to CRP2 , CytO , and CRP1 . [20000490]
  • First , the relative affinities of CRP for binding to CRP1 and to CRP2 are reversed as compared to other CytR-regulated promoters ; at cddP , the CRP1 site is the higher affinity site . [20000490]

  • Despite this role of CytR as a functional antagonist of CRP , the two proteins interact cooperatively , resulting in substantially increased CytR binding af-finity when CRP is present ( 6 ) . [8969182]
  • On the basis of the view that the thermodynamic driving force for cooperativity is CytR-CRP association , the presumption was that cytidine binding induces a concerted change in the conformation of the CytR dimer , the result of which is to decrease greatly its affinity for association with CRP . [12667072]

  • Third , by binding to the CytR operator with high affinity , CytR acts as an antiactivator at lower CytR concentrations and recruits CRP at lower CRP concentrations . [20000490]

  • Analysis of Cooperative and Competitive Binding of CytR and CRP -- Cooperative interactions between CytR and CRP and competition between CytR and CRP for binding to CRP2 were evaluated by considering the thermodynamic cycles for simultaneous binding of both proteins . [10347150]
  • This result confirms that competition between CRP and CytR for binding CRP2 is a significant feature of the interaction of these proteins with udp , just as it is for deoP2 . [10347150]
  • Equations to describe CRP binding to CRP1 and to CRP2 were derived by considering the relative probability of each promoter ∆ Gs is the sum of free energy contributions for configuration s , ( Table 1 ) ; i and j are the stoichiometries of bound CRP complexes ( 0 , 1 , or 2 ) and Core domain dimers ( 0 or 1 ) in configuration s. Summation of the relative probabilities for the configurations with protein bound to any given site yields the binding equation for that site . [12667072]
  • Following the lead provided by the electrophoretic mobility-shift results , we evaluated Core domain binding to the CRP2-deoP2 and CRP2-udpP complexes by considering the thermodynamic linkage between this reaction and binding of CRP to CRP1 and CRP2 , as depicted in Figure 4 . [12667072]

  • ∆ G1 and ∆ G2 denote the free energy changes for intrinsic ( and noncooperative ) binding of CRP to CRP1 and CRP2 , respectively . [12667072]
  • In deoP2 the upstream CRP target ( CRP-2 ; Fig. 1 ) is required for repression , as shown in a series of experiments in vivo -LCB- Valentin-Hansen , 1985 ; Martinussen ef al. . [1962841]
  • Regulation of the gcv operon by GcvA and GcvR is part of a growing number of prokaryotic regulatory systems involving an activator -RCB- antiactivator complex , including TraR -RCB- TraM regulation of conjugal transfer of the Ti plasmid in Agrobacterium tumefaciens ( Hwang et al. , 1999 ) , NifA -RCB- NifL regulation of nitrogen ﬁxation in Klebsiella pneumoniae ( Narberhaus et al. , 1995 ) , ComK -RCB- MecA -RCB- ClpC regulation of competence in Ba-cillus subtilis ( Turgay et al. , 1998 ) and CRP -RCB- CytR regulation of operons encoding the nucleoside transport and biosynthesis enzymes ( Valentin-Hansen et al. , 1996 ) . [11495998]
  • Under conditions in which CytR is inactive ( i.e. in the presence of cytidine ) , CRP interacts with RNP to form transcriptionally active CRP ± RNP ± promoter complexes , whereas under conditions in which CytR is active ( in the absence of cytidine ) , two CRPs interact with CytR to form transcriptionally inactive ( CRP ) 2 ± CytR ± deoP2 complexes ( Sùgaard-Andersen et al. , 1990a , b , 1991a , b ; Sùgaard-Andersen and Valentin-Hansen , 1993 ; Meibom et al. , 1999 ) . [11574471]
  • CAMP-CRP activation takes place from CRP-1 ( Valentin-Hansen , 1985 ) , whereas CytR regulation is dependent onthe presence of both CRP targets awsell as the distance and the sequence between these targets ( Sld-gaard-Andersen et al. , 1990a , 1990b ) . [1655726]

  • CRPa-CytR-Promotor Complex-It has previously been shown that both the CRP-1 and tC heRP-2 sites arneecessary for CytR repression of the deoP2 promoter , and DNase I footprintinghas indicated that bothsitesare occupiedby CRP in the repression complex with CytR bound in between the CRP sites ( Sbgaard-Andersen et al. , 199Ob ; Pedersen et al. , 1991 ) .   • As previously shown CytR and CAMP-CRP bind simultaneously to deoP2 in a highly cooperative manner and the protection pattern of the repressor complex is consistent with a model in which CytR is trapped between r -93 40 Uranyl Photofootprinting CRP-2 CRP-CytCRomplex-Uranyl photofootprinting reveals contacts between a DNA-bound ligand and thephosphates of the DNA backbone ( Nielsen et al. , 1988 ; Jeppesen and Niel-sen , 1989 ) . [8394345]
  • The CRP2 -- CytR -- DNA repression complex covers ~ 80 bp on one face of the DNA helix , and is held together by CRP -- DNA , CytR -- DNA and CRP -- CytR interactions ( Pedersen et al. , 1991 ; Søgaard-Andersen et al. , 1991a , b ; Rasmussen et al. , 1993 ) . [9155036]
  • The second repressor of the system , CytR , binds in concert with the CAMP-CRP complex in a highly cooperative fashion , forming a repression complex in which the DNA is wrapped around CytR and one or two molecules of CAMP-CRP ( Pedersen et al. , 1991 , 1992 ; Gerlach et al. , 1991 ; Holst et al. , 1992 ) . [8221894]
  • CytR and CRP turn off transcription by binding in a highly co-operative fashion to speciﬁc targets in the promoter regions ( Gerlach et al. , 1991 ; Pedersen et al. , 1991 ; 1992 ; 1995 ; Søgaard-Andersen et al. , 1991 ; Holst et al. , 1992 ) . [9767576]
  • In this context , it should be noted that the inducers of CytR ( cytidine and adenosine ) exert their effect on repression by interrupting the protein-protein interactions between CytR and CAMP-CRP ( Gerlach et al. , 1991 ; Pedersen et al. , 1991 ) . [8221894]
  • Discussion Previous results have shown that CytR can interact and bind co-operatively with CRP from a number of different settings of operator half-sites ( Valentin-Hansen et al. , 1996 ; Pedersen and Valentin-Hansen , 1997 ) . [9466254]
  • Binding studies have shown that CytR binds to deoP2 with a dissociation constant of approximately 1Om7M and that CAMP-CRP stimulates CytR binding approximately lOOO-fold ( Pedersen et al. , 1991 ) . [8221894]
  • Thus , CRP with single amino acid substitutions ( Hid7Arg , Cys18Arg , Val ' '' Ala , Pro ' 1oSer ) have been isolated that specifically abolish CytR regulation in uiuo ( Sb-gaard-Andersen et al. , 1991b ) . [8394345]

  • Discussion The multiple roles of CRP during activation of acs transcription Previously , we reported that in vitro RNAP alone could form an open complex ( TOC ) at both acsP2A and acsP2 . [17630973]
  • The increased stability of this ternary CRP -- RNAP -- acsP2 complex activates transcription at multiple levels . [17630973]
  • This allosteric transition increases the affinity of CRP for promoter DNA and thereby directly stimulates initiation of transcription by RNA polymerase . [3021588]
  • This indicates that CRP is unable to activate transcription from the aer promoter when its DNA site is moved to the opposite face of the DNA helix . [19843224]
  • AraC-dependent transcription initiation at the araBAD promoter is increased by CRP , which binds to a single DNA site upstream of I1 and I2 ( 11 ) . [12060687]
  • To activate transcription , CRP binds to a specific DNA site located upstream from a promoter and interacts with RNAP . [12881519]
  • One possibility was that CRP binds to DNA cooperatively with RhaR to improv the ability of RhaR to activate transcription , similar to the cooperative binding of MelR and CRP at the melAB promoter ( 4 ) . [16166533]
  • Since this site is far upstream of RNAP 's binding site , it seems unlikely that CRP is contacting RNAP to activate transcription of gcv unless DNA looping occurs at the gcv promoter , allowing contact between one of CRP 's activating regions and RNAP . [10074087]
  • As expected , positive control mutations that impair the ability of CRP to activate transcription but not DNA binding have no effect on P1 repression . [9079929]
  • These observations suggested that CRP repression is alleviated upon acid stress or that other DNA binding proteins regulate azuC transcription . [19734316]
  • Mutants of CRP that bind normally to the target site on the DNA and do not perturb bending of the DNA , but fail to activate transcription ( positive control or pc-mutants ) , have been isolated by several laboratories . [8895588]
  • Mutants of CRP mapping in this region , called positive control or pc-mutants , are ( nearly ) completely unable to activate transcription , but bind DNA with the same affinity and bend DNA to the same extent as does wt CRP . [8895588]
  • When the DNA upstream of the araFGl site or CRP site was deleted , no increase in the basal level of transcription was seen . [1400237]
  • As a prerequisite to activating transcription , CRP must bind to a 22-bp twofold-symmetric recognition site on DNA ( 2 , 9 , 15 ) . [11073923]
  • CRP binding to these sites bends the DNA and causes MalT to shift 3 bp downstream to-binding sites from which MalT can activate transcription ( 24 ) . [16166533]
  • It is shown that CRP can activate transcription at ﬁve of these targets and the functional DNA sites for CRP are identiﬁed . [17608696]
  • Another mechanism by which CRP can activate transcription at class III promoters involves DNA bending . [16166533]
  • However , it appears that this bending is not essential for CRP function because CRP variants that can not bend DNA are still effective transcription regulators ( Busby and Ebright , 1999 ) . [11407111]
  • It has been proposed that CRP correctly positions the R-subunit on the DNA and thereby activates transcription ( Busby & Ebright , 1994 ) . [8952481]
