  • In our model for synergistic activation of proP P2 , Fis minimally contacts one a-CTD domain , and the second a-CTD domain is bound to the CRP subunit oriented proximal to the promoter ( Fig. 10 ) . [10894725]
  • Depending upon the architecture of the promoter , one or two activation regions on the surface of CRP ( AR1 and AR2 ) are involved in positive contacts with the a subunit of RNAP . [11073923]
  • To test whether the - CTD was required for full activation by CRP or RhaR , we reconstituted RNAP from its individual subunits in order to obtain RNAP preparations in which both copies of the - CTD were deleted for all residues after amino acid 235 ( - 235 ) . [16166533]
  • This is similar to the ﬁnding at several other class III CRP-dependent promoters that interactions with - CTD and cooperative binding do not account for a activation by CRP ( 23 , 25 , 26 , 28 ) . [11073923]
  • As mentioned above , previous in vivo experiments from this lab did not provide conclusive evidence for or against an interaction between CRP and - CTD ; therefore , we used in vitro transcription assays to more directly measure the role of - CTD in transcription-activation at the rhaSR promoter . [16166533]
  • Our ﬁnding that several point mutations in - CTD also decreased CRP-dependent in vitro activation of the rhaSR promoter further supports our conclusion that CRP activation of rhaSR requires interaction with - CTD ( unpublished results ) . [16166533]
  • Residue 315 is a part of the `` 287 determinant '' of a-CTD that is believed to contact CRP ( 6 , 29 ) and is also important for activation by FNR ( 33 ) . [10852886]
  • We wished to identify residues in a-CTD involved in this activation and to investigate whether a-CTD activation depends on interactions with DNA and/or CRP and / or RhaS . [10852886]
  • Overall , our results suggest that CRP interaction with a-CTD may not be required for rhaBAD activation ; however , a-CTD does contribute to full activation , probably through interactions with DNA and possibly RhaS . [10852886]
  • In addition to the possible interaction between a-CTD and CRP , the alanine scan results indicate that DNA contacts by a-CTD are important for its activation . [11073923]
  • There is also a second component to CRP activation of rhaSR that appears to function through synergism with RhaR and a-CTD . [11073923]
  • CRP activation of rhaBAD expression appears to occur by a mechanism other than interaction with a-CTD . [10852886]
  • If an interaction between CRP and a-CTD does occur at rhaSR , it appears to make a relatively small contribution to activation in the wild-type context . [11073923]
  • The small defect upon substitution of CRP G162 leaves open the possibility that CRP activation of rhaBAD could involve AR1 contacts with a-CTD ; however , the evidence for such an interaction is not strong . [10852886]
  • We have some evidence that a-CTD activation , at least in the absence of CRP , may involve contacts with RhaS . [10852886]
  • This increased activation by CRP and a-CTD in the absence of the other is the opposite of what would be expected if CRP activation required contacts with a-CTD . [10852886]
  • We expected that CRP activation would involve contacts with - CTD ; hence , - CTD would be required a a for full activation . [10852886]
  • Does activation by a-CTD involve contacts with CRP ? [10852886]
  • In addition , the 10 and extended 10 elements are important for lacP ; single base 1-6S1 pair substitutions at the two elements decreased the promoter activity and made the promoter regain CRP activation . [15385551]
  • The lack of defect from 70 K593A , R599A , or R608A at the ( rhaS-lacZ ) 216 promoter is similar to previous ﬁndings with RhaS and AraC that substitutions at 70 some residues were defective only in the absence of CRP activation ( 4 , 27 ) . [15342598]
  • It is possible that these residues are also important for RhaS activation in the full-length promoter , but for reasons described in the Discussion , such as redundancy , they did not show any detectable defect in the presence of CRP activation . [10940041]
  • Further , if these s70 residues are important for activation by RhaS in the absence of CRP , it is possible that other AraC / XylS family proteins that activate transcription without the aid of a second activator , such as CRP , may also require these residues . [10940041]
  • Figure 6B shows that the CRP mutants T158A and H159L ( 52 ) , which contain mutations in AR1 , had similar levels of activity regardless of the presence of the CRP binding site , indicating that they were unable to stimulate P2 transcriptional activation . [10894725]
  • Both H159L and H159L K101E CRP mutants signiﬁcantly decreased ( 3.5-fold ) PcspD activity , indicating that the H159 residue is critical for PcspD activation . [24509317]
  • We have recently demonstrated that several of the four CRP binding sites are involved in the activation of both malEp a.nd malKp in , rh . [2016744]
  • Some elements of this structure , namely the CRP site 1 , located at − 76.5 , and the distal MalT sites , seem to play a direct role in malEp activation besides their participation in the assembly of the higher-order structure . [9000616]
  • The mechanism of activation by CRP is clearly different from that occurring at the divergent malEp-malKp promoters , which are simultaneously controlled by an array of three binding sites for CRP , all located at distal positions in between ( 36 ) , and forming a high-order structure responsible for activation , assisting direct activation by the MalT primary regulator . [9573142]
  • The binding of MalT and CRP to this region is known to result in the formation of a higher-order structure that is responsible for malKp activation . [9000616]
  • It is noteworthy that other transcription activators , such as CRP , Fnr , and the Mor protein , whose binding site is centered around 241 , also interact simultaneously with the a and s70 subunits and contact similar activation targets at the amino acid level ( 2 , 33 ) . [11073893]
  • Furthermore , in the promoter , the putative cAMP -- CRP binding site is located at a proper distance for activation . [18619465]
  • The promoter region contains only one potential CRP binding site , centred at a position ( -37.5 ) that is normally associated with repression rather than activation ( Fig. 4b ; Busby & Kolb , 1996 ) . [9421904]
  • The next activation peak is observed when the CRP binding site is moved one helical turn further upstream to position -81.5 , with an activation factor almost as strong as for the more promoter-proximal positions . [8895588]
  • Instead , the presence of C rather than T at position 6 of the CRP half-site appears to make Sxy essential for CRP-DNA-binding and transcription-activation ( 13,14 ) . [17068078]
  • These NMR experiments indicate a possible role of E72 and R82 in cAMP-binding and subsequent cAMP-mediated activation of CRP . [16934214]
  • These experiments argue that optimal activation of s28-dependent transcription requires CRP binding at position -49.5 . [19843224]
  • The more recent ﬁnding that other s70 substitutions at positions near R596 , especially K593A , signiﬁcantly reduce activation by AraC in the absence of CRP supports the hypothesis that wild-type AraC and s70 make an interaction that contributes to transcription-activation ( 36 ) . [10940041]
  • Discussion The multiple roles of CRP during activation of acs transcription Previously , we reported that in vitro RNAP alone could form an open complex ( TOC ) at both acsP2A and acsP2 . [17630973]
  • The role of two surface exposed loops in transcription-activation by the Escherichia coli CRP and FNR proteins . [9440505]
  • Therefore , even though CRP and FNR share the same structural framework , there are major differences in the way they interact with CZCTD , such that different contacts are used to modulate the extent of transcription-activation at specific promoters . [11407111]
  • In vitro transcription studies effectively demonstrated this , whereby no CRP-dependent transcription-activation was observed on a linear template ; however , use of a supercoiled template permitted transcription-activation to occur , presumably through providing sufficient helical twist in the DNA to align cAMP ± CRP and RNAP correctly . [11251844]
  • Taken together , these results confirm the existence of three functional CRP sites 364 We have distinguished two functional regions within cddP that are involved in cAMP-CRP activation of transcription . [1327747]
  • Biochemical and biophysical results revealed that regulation of transcription-activation depends on alignment of CRP tertiary structure through inter-domain communication and it was concluded that positions 72 and 82 are essential in the activation of CRP by cAMP . [16934214]
  • The larger , N-terminal domain ( NTD ) , which is predominantly β-stranded , is basically responsible for CRP dimerization ( see Fig. 1 ) , and the cAMP-binding to this domain results in the functional activation of CRP . [19439203]

  • Although the presence of both core motifs was found to be necessary for CRP to bind to the target site in PcspE ( Fig. 3A ) , an intact second core motif was shown to be more important for CRP-PcspE interaction ( Fig. 3B and C ) . [21926233]
  • Sequence integrity of the second core motif is more important for CRP binding . [21926233]
  • Taken together , these data demonstrated that the changes are tolerated relatively more poorly in the second core motif than in the ﬁrst core motif , suggesting that the presence of an intact second core motif is more important for CRP binding to PcspE . [21926233]
  • Based on these predictions , CRP and FNR homologues have been classified according to the amino-acid-sequence motifs in their putative DNA-recognition helices , where those containing the FNR motif ( E -- SR ) are regarded as FNR-like proteins and those containing the CRP motif ( RE -- R ) are regarded as CRP-like proteins ( Spiro , 1994 ) . [11407111]
  • Examination of multiple alignment of the CRP/FNR-like proteins revealed one speciﬁc amino acid ( R180 ) in the HTH motif involved in DNA-recognition , which has changed from arginine ( like in E. coli CRP and Desulfovibrio HcpR ) to Ser or Pro in other dproteobacteria ( see the HcpR1 branch of the phylogenetic tree in Figure 3 ) .   • Based on sequence homology with CRP ( 8 ) , FNR consists of a C-terminal DNA-binding domain , which recognizes specific sequences within FNR-controlled promoters ( 9 ) , and an Nterminal sensory-domain containing 5 cysteine residues , 4 of which , Cys-20 , 23 , 29 , and 122 , but not Cys-16 , are essential for function ( 10 , 11 ) . [19261852]
  • However , FIpA and FIpB were designated FNR-like because : they are more similar to FNR than CRP when conservative amino acid substitutions are included in the comparison ; they retain the FNR-like DNA-recognition motif ( see below ) and lack the amino acid residues required for cAMP-binding ; and they retain one N-terminal cysteine residue ( Cysl5 ) and a single internal residue ( Cys112 ) corresponding to two of the four essential cysteine residues of FNR ( Plate 3a ; Gostick et al. , 1999 ) . [11407111]

[12667072]
  • To address this question requires CytR Core domain in which the interaction between CytR and DNA is eliminated but other CytR functions ( i.e. , dimerization , cytidine binding , and CRP association ) are unperturbed . [12667072]
  • This suggests that there are contacts between the DNA-binding domain of CytR ( the ` toes ' of CytR ; Figure 6B and C ) and CRP near the DNA , besides the interaction between the ligandbinding/dimerization domain of CytR and CRP demonstrated previously ( Søgaard-Andersen and ValentinHansen , 1993 ) . [9155036]
  • CytR Core domain associates when CRP is bound to both CRP1 and CRP2 as a result of favorably oriented protein-protein contacts , despite no interaction between Core domain and DNA . [12667072]
  • CRP is a homodimer of a 209 amino acid-long subunit ( Aiba et al. , 1982 ) , each consisting of two domains , N-terminal dimerization and cAMP-binding domain and C-terminal DNA-binding domain . [24814025]
  • The acceleration of Fur proteolysis in the presence of metal is analogous to the behavior of the E. coli CRP protein : cyclic-AMP-binding to the N-terminal domain of CRP induces protease sensitivity in the C-terminal DNA-binding domain ( Heyduk & Lee , 1989 ) . [1868094]
  • The crystal structure of CRP from E. coli shows that it is 40 % helical and 29 % β-sheet , constituting an N-terminal cAMP-binding domain and a Cterminal `` winged helix '' DNA-binding domain . [16814929]
  • If so , elimination of CytR-CRP interactions in response to cytidine binding might allow the CRP-RNAP interaction necessary for full activation even in the presence of DNA-bound CytR . [10347150]
  • Effect of defective DNA-binding domain of CRP on PcspE activation . [21926233]
  • CRP 's DNA-binding domain is contained within 50 C-terminal amino acids ( aligned in Figure 8 ) ; six of these are shared only within the EPV clade , as expected of residues that might mediate interactions with CRP-S sites . [17068078]
  • Additionally , the data suggest that CytR has a modular structure with an NHr terminal DNA-binding domain and a COOH-terminal domain engaged in CAMP-CRP interactions , inducer-binding , and oligomerization . [8221894]
  • But observations made several years ago using truncation mutants of CytR that lack the N-terminal DNA-binding domain suggest that CytR-CRP and CytRCytO interactions may not combine quite so favorably as this . [12667072]
  • CRP binding in the absence of Core domain produced the expected pattern of mobility-shifted bands corresponding to species with either one or two CRP dimers bound . [12667072]
  • The region in CAMP-CRP that contacts CytR has been identified and consists of two surface-exposed loops that are in close proximity and physically separated from the DNA-binding domain in CAMP-CRP . [8221894]
  • Many repressor proteins , such as LacR , TrpR , and CRP , have been found to have a two-domain structure , in which one domain is involved in DNA-binding while the other is involved in ligand binding ( Steitz , 1990 ; Pabo & Sauer , 1984 ) . [1868094]
  • So even though independent DNA-binding of CytRA9-48 can not be detected , CytRA9-48 may be brought into such close contact with the DNA in the presence of CAMP-CRP that interactions with the backbone contribute to stabilizing the repression complex . [8221894]
  • The protein makes direct contact with base pairs G : C5 , G : C7 and A : T8 in the highly conserved core motif T4G5T6G7A8 , and binding induces a localized kink of 43 between positions 6 and 7 , wrapping the DNA around CRP and strengthening the association ( 5,6 ) . [17068078]
  • However , because the core motif and two residues in the DNA-binding motif ( E -- R ; Glu 184 an Arg188 ) are conserved relative to CRP and FNR , it is predicted that FLP will make the same contacts with its target , as shown in Fig. 4a . [11407111]
  • The core interactions between the Glu ( position 2 ) and Arg ( position 6 ) residues and the conserved C-G and T-A base pairs at the FNR , FLP and CRP DNA-binding sites , arc indicated . [11407111]
  • The conserved G-C and A-T pairs of the TGA half-site core motif are contacted by glutamate and arginine residues ( Glu209 and Arg213 ) , which are predicted to occupy similar positions within the DNA-binding helix as Glu 181 and Arg 185 of CRP ( Fig. 4a ) . [11407111]
  • Genetic analysis and in vitro chemical protection studies have localized the initial binding site of cAMP - CRP around position -40 on the DNA , with the G residue at position -35 probably making contact with the protein ( 5 , 6 , 27 ; A. Majumdar and S. Adhya , manuscript in preparation ) . [2537823]
  • Based on a comparison with the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) and its recognition sequence on the DNA , Spiro and Guest ( 1990 ) have proposed that a glutamic acid residue in the DNA-binding domain of FNR makes an important contact with the GC base pair in the DNA sequence . [7934836]

  • To explain these observations , we propose that the DNA-binding domains of CytR are tethered to the rest of the protein through a flexible linker that allows the repressor to interact with half-operators separated by different spacings , and to interact with cAMP-CRP complexes at various distances from the operator . [8596434]
  • CRP DNA-binding domains are aligned with the closely related P.aeruginosa DNR and the distantly related E.coli FNR . [17068078]
  • Therefore , it is probable that it is the CytR core protein , not the DNA-binding domains of CytR , that interacts with CRP . [8596434]
  • These putative domains are approximately the same size as : the XCro protein ( 66 residues ) and the DNA-binding domains of many transcriptional regulators , e.g. CRP ( 70 residues ) . [2060763]
  • Its car-boxyl-terminal fragment contains an a-helix-turn-a-helix secondary structure ; the F-helix of each CRP monomer interacts with two consecutive major grooves of DNA ( Weber & Steitz , 1984 ) . [2160266]
  • Chemical protection studies of the ara and.lac sites as well as mutational data suggest that cAMP/CRP recognizes two regions on the DNA helix . [6329724]
  • When activated by cAMP , CRP recognizes speciﬁc DNA sites via the C-terminal F-helix ( αF ) which forms a typical helix -- turn -- helix ( HTH ) motif , together with the neighboring E-helix ( αE ) ( Fig. 1 , 1G6N ) . [19439203]
  • The two c ~ v helices in the CRP - ( cAMP ) 2 complex each occupy one half of the CRP target site , where the individual CRP half-sites are located in adjacent major grooves separated from each other by one complete turn of the double helix , such that the C R P : D N A interactions occur on only one lace of the helix ( Plate 1 ) . [11407111]
  • Binding cAMP induces a conformational change in the CRP dimer that aligns the helix-turn-helix motifs of the DNA-binding domains such that they are configured to penetrate adjacent channels of the major groove on one face of the DNA helix ( reviewed by Kolb el al. , 1993 ) . [11407111]
  • The cAMP-CRP complex contacts DNA via a helix-turn-helix motif in which the second helix ( recognition helix ) fits into the major groove of the DNA and specific Summary . [1661372]

[9409145]

[10760178]
  • Clearly , the dsdXA promoter belongs to the more complex class III CRP-dependent promoters , in which a regulon-speciﬁc activator protein in addition to CRP is required for transcriptional activation . [7592420]
  • Our ﬁnding that the cAMP-CRP complex activates a 54-dependent promoter in concert with a member of the 54-dependent activator family suggests that the CRP family might interact with the 54-dependent expression system regardless of nitrogen metabolism . [15805526]
  • Such peculiar synergistic transcription activation has not yet been observed in other aromatic cat-abolic pathways , and the MhpR activator becomes the first member of the IclR family of transcriptional regulators that is indispensable for recruiting CRP to the target promoter . [12748194]

  • From our studies and those reported by other authors ( 16 , 21 , 30 ) , we may conclude that activation by cAMP-CRP and the repressor effect caused by binding to several operator sites are general features of the genetic systems under the control of repressors belonging to the DeoR family in E. coli . [14996803]

  • As far as we are aware , this is the first report of a direct interaction between CRP and an AraC family member ( although there may be a parallel with the interaction between CRP and CaiF reported by Buchet et al. , 1999 ) . [10760178]
  • Conclusions Members of the LacI -- GalR family of transcriptional repressors are usually functional as dimers , although in some cases , repression depends on the dimerization of dimers or interactions with other proteins , such as CRP ( Weickert & Adhya , 1992 ; Valentin-Hansen et al. , 1996 ) . [20141531]
  • Opposing activation and repression , mediated by CRP and a LacI family member , respectively , is one of the most common ways in which transcription of catabolic genes is regulated in bacteria to meet the cell 's metabolic needs . [20000490]
  • Perspectives The four examples of oxygen/redox responsive members of the CRP family discussed above illustrate the great versatility of the basic CRP fold . [11407111]
  • Microbiology ( 2000 ) , 146 , 3157 -- 3170 Printed in Great Britain YeiL , the third member of the CRP -- FNR family in Escherichia coli Muna F. Anjum , Jeffrey Green and John R. Guest Author for correspondence : John R. Guest . [11101674]
  • The E. coli CRP is the only member for which a three-dimensional ( X-ray ) structure has been defined , but there is strong evidence to support the view that each family member possesses an analogou structure . [11407111]
  • This work has laid a foundation for future investigations aimed at deﬁning the precise role of the third member of the CRP family in E. coli . [11101674]
  • The complete genome of Escherichia coli ( Blattner et al. , 1997 ) was recently shown to encode a third member of the CRP -- FNR family ( YeiL ) when searched with a sequence proﬁle derived from a multiple alignment of ﬁve members of the family : CRP and FNR from E. coli ; FLP from L. casei ; and FlpA and FlpB from Lactococcus lactis ( Gostick et al. , 1999 ) . [11101674]
  • A phylogenetic tree derived from 38 members of the CRP -- FNR family indicated that YeiL is a distant relative of the CRP group ( Gostick et al. , 1999 ) . [11101674]
  • Keywords : CRP -- FNR protein superfamily , iron -- sulphur proteins , transcriptional regulation , nitrogen starvation , stationary phase INTRODUCTION The CRP -- FNR family of transcription regulators contains at least 70 members that respond to a variety of metabolic and environmental signals to control a diverse range of physiological functions in an equally diverse range of bacteria ( Spiro , 1994 ; Guest et al. , 1996 ; Vollack et al. , 1999 ) . [11101674]
  • & control in bacterial denitriﬁcation by members of the FNR-CRP regulator family . [16261196]
  • The L. casei FLP protein groups with the CRP rather than the FNR family . [7747934]
  • FNR is predicted to contain all the structural elements of CRP , and both regulators constitute a family of transcriptional regulators . [8588737]
  • DISCUSSION The yeiL gene of E. coli was predicted to encode a new and distinct member of the CRP -- FNR family of transcriptional regulators that might have an iron -- sulphur centre and a reversible intra - or inter-molecular disulphide bond . [11101674]
  • A member of the CRP family of regulatory proteins , Fnr differs by having a cysteine rich N-terminal segment which binds iron . [7747940]
  • The structural framework of the founder member of the family , the Escherichia coli cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , provides a versatile system for sensing and transducing environmental or metabolic signals into a physiological response ( 2 -- 5 ) . [19261852]
  • The cents rst member of the family was the cyclic aden-osine monophosphate ( cAMP ) - binding protein , CRP ( cAMP receptor protein ) , also called CAP for catabolite activator protein . [14638413]
  • It is a member of an expanding family of transcriptional regulators that are structurally related to CRP , the cyclic AMP receptor protein ( Irvine and Guest , 1993 ; Kolb ef ai . [8065261]
  • In studies of sotA , a SET family member in D. dadantii , the global regulators CRP and KdgR were implicated in transcriptional regulation . [20971900]
  • Whereas the LH region of the PaaX binding motif is rather conserved in the operator sequences of other bacterial regulators such as GntR ( 6 ) and PdhR ( 27 ) ( which belong to the GntR family ) and , surprisingly , CRP ( 23 , 25 ) and LacI ( 26 ) ( which belong to the GalR-LacI family ) , the RH region differs from that of other operators ( Fig. 8 ) . [10766858]
  • CRP , which is not a member of the GalR-LacI family of regulators , also functions as a symmetric dimer by binding to DNA sites with dyad symmetry located upstream of the RNA polymerase in the promoters . [7934815]
  • Its hyphenated dyad symmetry resembles that of the binding sites for other regulators with helix-turn-helix motifs ( e.g , CRP and FNR ) but it differs from the known sites for other members of the GntR family which exhibit uninterrupted dyad symmetry , i.e. GntR -LCB- ATACnGTATACAAGTAT : Fujita and Miwa , 1989 ) and HutCpp -LCB- TTGJAATAtAc ; Hu et ai . [7783622]
  • Whereas inducer or co-repressor binding to other family members controls a switch between DNA-binding protein and non-DNA-binding protein conformations , cytidine binding to CytR affects only cooperative interactions between CytR and CRP . [10347150]
  • CytR is unique among LacI/GalR family members in that binding of its regulatory ligand , cytidine , is linked not to DNA-binding affinity but instead to the cooperative interactions between CytR bound at CytO and CRP bound to CRP1 and CRP2 . [20000490]
  • © 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. Keywords : GntR ; cAMP-CRP ; GntP family 1 . [9358057]
  • Unlike the other members of this protein family , CytR binds with only modest afﬁnity to its operators and transcription repression thus relies on the formation of nucleoprotein complexes with the cAMP -- CRP complex . [9466254]
  • Condusions Proteins structurally homologous to FNR ( and CRP ) of E. coli are widespread amongst Gram-negative bacteria , and there is at least one example from a Grampositive organism . [7747934]
  • Sequence analysis of thefir gene indicates that FNR is structurally homologous to CAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , the transcriptional regulator of catabolite-sensitive genes [ 2,7,8 ] . [8119409]
  • FNR shows sequence and functional similarity to CRP , the cyclic AMP receptor protein ( BELLet al. 1989 ; SPIROand GUEST1987 ) , although the mechanism by which FNR senses ana-erobiosis is unknown . [2168848]
  • The protein shows a close homology to the transcriptional regulator CRP ( cyclo AMP receptor protein ) of E. coli , and the gene products of the hlyX gene of Actino-bacilluspleuropneumoniae , the orf240 gene of Rhizobium leguminosarum and the fixK gene of R. meliloti ( Fig. 1 ) ( De Crombrugghe et al. 1984 ; Shaw et al. 1983 ; Maclnnes et al. 1990 ; Colonna-Romano et al. 1990 ; Batut et al. 1989 ) . [1854188]
  • Three amino acids in the E.coli CRP helix -- turn -- helix confer CRP-N site recognition through base contacts ( R180 , E181 and R185 ) ; Figure 8 shows that they are conserved in all ﬁve families . [17068078]
  • In some of these proteins the presence of extensive sequence similarity has allowed specific families with common ancestries and similar modes of action to be recognised , e.g. the XCro , LysR and CRP families [ 2-5 ] . [2060763]
  • Given the 30 % amino acid sequence identity and 62 % similarity between RhaS and RhaR , we attempted to identify the difference between RhaS and RhaR that dictates their difference in optimal CRP binding site position . [19854903]

probably responsible for energy coupling to the transport system Provides resistance to osmotic stress ; may be important for stationary-phase survival ; induced by elevated osmotic pressure in the growth medium Preferentially metabolizes organic hydroperoxides over inorganic hydrogen peroxide ; induced by elevated osmotic pressure and during the decelerating phase , before entry into stationary phase ; regulated by a complex network of several global regulators , including at least S , Lrp , and H-NS Induced by elevated osmotic pressure Osmotically and stationary phase inducible and controlled by several global regulators , including S , cAMP-CRP , IHF , and Lrp Induced by growth in glucose-mineral medium of elevated osmotic strength ; TCA , trichloroacetic acid ; Xcorr , cross-correlation ( measures how close the spectrum ﬁts to the ideal spectrum ) Biotin carboxyl carrier protein of acetyl-CoA carboxylase AccB P0ABD8 179 , 286 , 287 , 323 4.66 / 16,687.21 4.57 / 22,029 4.74 / 18,338 ( 4 -- 5 ) 5.01 / 18,459 ( 4 -- 5 ) 4.78 / 15,809 ( 4 -- 5 ) Biotin carboxylase 6.65 / 49,320.74 7.58 / 33,321.89 P24182 P0A9Q5 AccC AccD 179 179 Acetyl-CoA carboxylase carboxyl transferase subunit beta Isocitrate lyase Protein function and expressione Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is a heterodecamer of four copies of biotin carboxyl carrier protein ( AccB ) , two copies of biotin carboxylase ( AccC ) , and two copies each of the two subunits of carboxyl transferase ( AccA and AccD ) ; AccC catalyzes the carboxylation of the carrier protein and then the transcarboxylase transfers the carboxyl group to form malonyl-CoA See AccA ; induced by high pH during anaerobic growth 4.57 / 22,029 4.74 / 18,338 ( 4 -- 5 ) 5.01 / 18,459 ( 4 -- 5 ) 4.78 / 15,809 ( 4 -- 5 ) See AccA See AccA 6.65 / 49,320.74 7.58 / 33,321.89 P24182 P0A9Q5 AccC AccD 179 179 Involved in glyoxylate-bypass ; activated by phosphorylation ( on histidine ) and inhibited by phosphoenolpyruvate ( PEP ) , 3-phosphoglycerate , and succinate ; induced by pH change ; increases in the physiological short-term adaptation to glucose limitation The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex contains multiple copies of three enzymatic components : pyruvate dehydrogenase ( E1 ) , dihydrolipoamide acetyltransferase ( E2 ) , and lipoamide dehydrogenase ( E3 ) ; catalyzes the overall conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA and CO2 ; increases during aerobic growth and after benzoic acid treatment See AceE ; increases during aerobic growth , during the low temp at 10 ° C , and after benzoic acid treatment Involved in the activation of acetate to acetyl-CoA and the secretion of acetate ; involved in the synthesis of most of the ATP formed catabolically during anaerobic growth ; induced by low pH during anaerobic growth Aconitate hydratases ( AcnA and AcnB ) serve as a protective buffer against the basal level of oxidative stress that accompanies aerobic growth by acting as a sink for reactive-oxygen-species and by modulating translation of the sodA transcript ; AcnA enhances the stability of the sodA transcript , whereas AcnB lowers its stability ; it is induced by iron and oxidative stress and may have an ironresponsive regulatory function See AcnA AceA 27 , 179 , 287 , 311 5.16 / 47,521.57 P0A9G6 5.19 / 44,130 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.12 / 44,130 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.01 / 33,761 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 4.99 / 33,624 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.01 / 51,702 ( 5 -- 6 ) AceE 5.40 / 99,289 5.46 / 99,537.29 P0AFG8 Pyruvate dehydrogenase E1 component 179 , 228 , 270 , 294 , 321 5.39 / 94,195 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) AceF Dihydrolipoyllysine residue acetyltransferase component of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex Acetate kinase P06959 133 , 179 , 228 , 270 , 294 , 321 5.01 / 77,450 5.09 / 65,964.87 5.09 / 78,105 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) AckA 5.84 / 44,001 5.85 / 43,290.45 P0A6A3 179 , 228 , 294 , 287 , 321 , 323 5.79 / 41,417 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) 5.72 / 31,846 ( 5 -- 6 ) 5.59 / 97,516.00 Aconitate hydratase 1 P25516 AcnA 151 , 278 AcnB 151 , 179 , 278 , 287 , 321 Aconitate hydratase 2 P36683 5.30 / 95,000 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) 5.24 / 75,907 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.24 / 93,498.11 Continued on facing pag TABLE 2 -- Continued pI/MW Descriptionb Protein function and expressione Experimentald Theoreticalc AcpP P0A6A8 Acyl carrier protein 3.98 / 8,508.33 A carrier of the growing fatty acid chain in fatty-acid-biosynthesis ; even though AcpP is an abundant protein ( ca. 60,000 copies per cell ) , its small size ( 8.5 kDa ) makes it difﬁcult to detect by typical 2-DE ; it can be detected after subcellular fractionation AcrAB is a drug efﬂux protein with broad substrate speciﬁcity 1 Acriﬂavine resistance protein A Adenosine deaminase Adenine deaminase AcrA P0AE06 179 6.08 / 39,723.72 Add P22333 Ade P31441 ( YicP ) 5.36 / 36,397.46 5.63 / 34,723.76 179 321 5.22 / 61,539 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) Repressed by H-NS but activated by insertion of a variety of insertion elements into a region extending from 145 to 13 relative to the transcription start site ; decreases after benzoic acid treatment AdhE has three activities : alcohol dehydrogenase , acetaldehyde dehydrogenase , and PFL deactivase ; PFL deactivase activity catalyzes the quenching of the pyruvate-formate-lyase catalyst in an iron - , NAD - , and CoA-dependent reaction ; in aerobic conditions , it acts as a hydrogen peroxide scavenger ; induced under anaerobic conditions in the absence of nitrate Catalyzes the reversible transfer of the terminal phosphate group between ATP and AMP ; essential for maintenance and cell-growth ; increases during phosphate limitation Absolutely required for the growth of E. coli in a high-phosphate medium containing glucose-1-phosphate as the sole carbon source ; positively controlled by cAMP-CRP Directly reduces organic hydroperoxides in its reduced dithiol form ; may be directly degraded by ClpXP or modulated by a protease-dependent mechanism ; induced by oxidative stress but repressed by sulfate or cysteine ; increases during high-cell-density cultivation and acid or propionate condition during aerobic growth 6.33 / 95,996.05 Aldehyde-alcohol dehydrogenase P0A9Q7 AdhE 179 Adk 5.49 / 28,491 5.60 / 22,470 5.55 / 23,586.02 Adenylate kinase P69441 179 , 228 , 287 , 293 5.00 / 9,929 ( 4 -- 5 ) 4.99 / 9,991 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.48 / 31,661 ( 5 -- 6 ) 5.38 / 43,560.36 Glucose-1-phosphatase P19926 Agp 79 1 AhpC Alkyl hydroperoxide reductase subunit C P0AE08 5.01 / 21,554 5.03 / 20,630.25 27 , 179 , 228 , 266 , 287 , 294 , 308 , 321 , 325 5.09 / 23,123 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) 5.08 / 21,705 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.03 / 22,439 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) AhpF Serves to protect the cell against DNA damage by alkyl hydroperoxides ; can use either NADH or NADPH as electron donor for direct reduction of redox dyes or of alkyl hydroperoxides when combined with the AhpC protein ; induced by oxidative stress and after benzoic acid treatment 5.44 / 53,485 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) 5.20 / 41,503 ( 5 -- 6 ) 5.47 / 56,177.11 Alkyl hydroperoxide reductase subunit F P35340 179 , 203 , 266 , 287 , 321 Alanyl -- tRNA synthetase Aldehyde dehydrogenase A AlaS 29 , 179 , 228 , 294 5.53 / 96,032.40 5.50 / 96,123 P00957 AldA Acts on lactaldehyde as well as other aldehydes ; induced by growth on fucose , rhamnose , arabinose , and amino acids such as glutamate ; increases in the physiological shortterm adaptation to glucose limitation 5.11 / 52,363 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) 5.29 / 42,547 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.53 / 38,913 ( 4.5 -- 5.5 ) 5.43 / 50,034 ( 5 -- 6 ) 5.07 / 52,141.60 P25553 179 , 287 , 308 , 311 , 321 , 325 Continued on following pag Involved in regulation of AMP concentrations ; allosterically activated by Mg-ATP but inactivated by inorganic phosphate ; induced by cAMP at limiting phosphate concentrations Serine beta-lactamase with substrate speciﬁcity for cephalosporins AnsA converts L-asparagine into L-aspartate ; there are two L-asparaginase isoenzymes : L-asparaginase I ( AnsA ) , a low-afﬁnity enzyme located in the cytoplasm , and L-asparaginase II ( AnsB ) , a high-afﬁnity secreted enzyme See AnsA ; induced by cAMP and anaerobiosis It is induced during entry into the stationary phase ; its synthesis is triggered by carbon starvation , phosphate starvation , osmotic shift , or a shift from aerobic to anaerobic conditions ; controlled by S and AppY Catalyzes a purine-salvage reaction , resulting in the formation of AMP that is energically less costly than de novo synthesis Involved in L-arabinose-catabolism 293 Amn P0AE12 AMP nucleosidase 5.90 / 53,994.91 6.38 / 47,693 87 Beta-lactamase AmpC P00811 8.78 / 39,551.14 9.06 / 43,647 ( 6 -- 11 ) 2 179 AnsA P0A962 L-Asparaginase I 5.52 / 37,127.24 AnsB P00805 5.66 / 34,593.94 L-Asparaginase II 179 6.11 / 44,689.86 5.42 / 46,694 Periplasmic AppA protein AppA P07102 13 , 228 , 293 Apt 5.30 / 23,792 ( D 5.26 / 19,858.88 Adenine P69503 IG E 4.5 -- 6.5 ) 179 , 321 phosphoribosyltransferase 5.73 / 25,518.91 6.06 / 29,165 L-Ribulose-5-phosphate 4-epimerase L-Arabinose-binding periplasmic protein AraD P08203 294 Involved in high-afﬁnity L-arabinose membrane transport system ; the fumarate reductase is used in anaerobic growth , and the succinate dehydrogenase is used in aerobic growth See FrdA Flu 5.37 / 101,278.83 Antigen 43 P39180 1 Fmt 5.56 / 34,037.27 5.49 / 35,885 Methionyl-tRNA formyltransferase P23882 179 , 228 , 236 , 294 FolA P0ABQ4 Dihydrofolate reductase 179 , 228 , 293 , 294 , 321 5.01 / 19,989 4.84 / 17,999.38 5.02 / 21,096 ( DIGE 4.5 -- 6.5 ) Fumarate reductase ﬂavoprotein 5.87 / 65,840.41 subunit P00363 FrdA 179 179 P0AC47 Fumarate reductase iron-sulfur 6.09 / 26,991.87 protein P0A805 Ribosome recycling factor 6.44 / 20,638.57 6.16 / 21,725 FrdB Responsible for the release of ribosomes from mRNA at the termination of protein-biosynthesis ; may increase the efﬁciency of translation by recycling ribosomes from one round of translation to another FrdB Frr 179 , 228 , 294 The phosphoenolpyruvate-dependent sugar PTS , a major carbohydrate active-transport system , catalyzes the phosphorylation of incoming sugar substrates concomitant with their translocation across the cell membrane ; involved in fructose-transport ; induced by fructose ; decreases after benzoic acid treatment May be involved in anomalous ﬁlament growth ; may be a component of the septum and interact with FtsZ ; induced at the stationary phase Essential to the cell-division process ; seems to assemble into a dynamic ring on the inner surface of the cytoplasmic membrane at the place where division will occur , with the formation of the ring being the signal for septation to begin ; decreases during phosphate limitation early GadA converts glutamate to gamma-aminobutyrate , consuming one intracellular proton in the reaction ; the Gad system helps to maintain a near-neutral intracellular pH when cells are exposed to extremely acidic conditions ; prevents nitrogen regulatory ( NR ) - II-catalyzed conversion of NR-I to NR-I-phosphate , the transcriptional activator of glnA ; when P-II is uridylylated to P-II-UMP , these events are reversed ; when the ratio of Gln to 2-ketoglutarate decreases , P-II is uridylylated to P-II-UMP , which causes the deadenylylation of glutamine synthetase by GlnE , thus activating the enzyme .   • The phosphoryl group from PEP is transferred to the phosphoryl carrier protein HPr by enzyme I ( PtsI ) ; phosphoHPr then transfers it to the permease ( enzymes II/III ) ; HPr is common to all PTS ; regulated by the cAMP-CRP complex and also by growth on glucose ; induced by low pH and phosphonate growth See PtsH ; decreases after benzoic acid treatment but increases at phosphonate growth Plays an important role in de novo pathway of purine-nucleotide-biosynthesis : AMP-biosynthesis ;   • Regulation of the gcv operon by GcvA and GcvR is part of a growing number of prokaryotic regulatory systems involving an activator -RCB- antiactivator complex , including TraR -RCB- TraM regulation of conjugal transfer of the Ti plasmid in Agrobacterium tumefaciens ( Hwang et al. , 1999 ) , NifA -RCB- NifL regulation of nitrogen ﬁxation in Klebsiella pneumoniae ( Narberhaus et al. , 1995 ) , ComK -RCB- MecA -RCB- ClpC regulation of competence in Ba-cillus subtilis ( Turgay et al. , 1998 ) and CRP -RCB- CytR regulation of operons encoding the nucleoside-transport and biosynthesis enzymes ( Valentin-Hansen et al. , 1996 ) .   • The latter circuit is also the most complex because apart from GadX and GadW , it also involves the global regulators H-NS and CRP , which act as transcriptional repressors , and RpoS , which positively affects gadA and gadBC transcription ( De Biase et al. , 1999 ; Castanie-Cornet and Foster , 2001 ; Hommais et al. , 2001 ; Tramonti et al. , 2002 ; Giangrossi et al. , 2005 ; Weber et al. , 2005 ) .   • The stationary phase global regulator RpoS ( S ) ( Olsén et al. 1993 ; Römling et al. 1998 ) and other global regulators including H-NS ( Arnqvist et al. 1994 ; Olsén et al. 1993 ) , Crl ( Arnqvist et al. 1992 ) , OmpR ( Römling et al. 1998 ; Vidal et al. 1998 ) , MlrA ( Brown et al. 2001 ) and CRP ( Zheng et al. 2004 ) can aVect curli synthesis by promoting or suppressing expression of the curli-encoding genes by regulating the expression of csgD . [21559929]
  • Fis can also affect DNA supercoiling indirectly , because of its roles in repressing transcription of gyrA and gyrB to reduce the DNA gyrase activity ( Schneider et al. , 1999 ) , increasing topA transcription to enhance topoisomerase I activity ( WeinsteinFischer et al. , 2000 ) , and regulating the expression of other DNA-binding proteins such as H-NS , HU and CRP ( Claret & Rouviere-Yaniv , 1996 ; Falconi et al. , 1996 ; Gonzalez-Gil et al. , 1998 ) that also affect DNA supercoiling directly or indirectly ( Broyles & Pettijohn , 1986 ; Gomez-Gomez et al. , 1996 ; Tupper et al. , 1994 ) . [17768236]

Mika and R. Hengge , in prep . [16291649]
  • For example , cAMP-CRP , GlcIIa , BarA , polyphosphate , homoserine lactone , acetate , and the NADH/NAD ratio have been shown to affect rpoS transcription , whereas DnaK , DksA , Hfq , HU , StpA , LeuO , and several small regulatory RNAs control rpoS translation ( Hengge-Aro-nis 2002 ; Repoila et al. 2003 ) . [17403784]

  • However , whereas FIS is primarily involved in the reorganisation of cellular-metabolism on transition to exponential growth in rich medium , CRP is most active under the conditions of exhaustion of glucose and its analogues . [11278071]

[16857675]
  • Identiﬁcation of the effectors involved in GadX activation and further investigation of the interactions between regulatory components of the gad system ( H-NS , RpoS , CRP , and GadX ) may provide further insight into the molecular circuitry underlying the glutamic acid-based acid stress response of E. coli A. Tramonti and P. Visca contributed equally to this work . [11976288]
  • Examination of multiple alignment of the CRP/FNR-like proteins revealed one speciﬁc amino acid ( R180 ) in the HTH motif involved in DNA recognition , which has changed from arginine ( like in E. coli CRP and Desulfovibrio HcpR ) to Ser or Pro in other dproteobacteria ( see the HcpR1 branch of the phylogenetic tree in Figure 3 ) . [16261196]
  • Genes involved in denitriﬁcation , such as nir , nor , and nos , are mainly regulated by two NO-responsive transcriptional activators from the FNR/CRP family , NnrR in a-proteobacteria and DNR in b-proteobac-teria , and Pseudomonas spp . [16261196]
  • On this view FIS , and possibly also CRP , act to ﬁne tune a fundamental mode of transcriptional regulation , not only by their direct effects on DNA topology but also from the indirect effects of their transcriptional-control of other nucleoid-associated proteins , such as HU and H-NS [ 3 , 4 ] , which also act as determinants of chromosomal structure . [11278071]
  • Regulation of the fatty acid pathways is complex and involves transcriptional regulators ( including FadR , FarR , IclR , and CRP ) and post transcriptional mechanisms . [10396600]
  • Whereas rs , Lrp , CRP , and IHF are clearly involved in stationary-phase induction , none of these regulators is essential for osmotic regulation of osmY . [8253679]
  • Thus , BglJ -- RcsB is a pleio-tropic transcriptional activator that coordinates regulation with global regulators including CRP , LeuO and HNS . [24335284]
  • Role of RpoS and Crl in bgl operon regulation The bgl operon is regulated by various pleiotropic regulators including H-NS and CRP , as essential factors . [12177351]
  • Negative autoreguiation seems to play a role in preventing unnecessary production of CRP . [1328816]
  • The proximal CRP target site plays an important role in CRP-mediated regulation of PcspD . [24509317]
  • Since CRP site-II seems to play a minor role in controlling CRP-mediated cspD regulation , PcspD with CRP site-I target site alone ( CRP site-II deletion or mutation ) was analyzed for AR domain preferences . [24509317]
  • This suggests the occurrence either of processing of CRP after translation or of proteolytic degradation of CRP during purification . [6280140]
  • w Location of DNA site for CRP relative to translation start as shown in ColiBASE ( http://colibase.bham.ac.uk/ ) . [17608696]
  • The observations reported here have many notable features : in the deﬁned MOPS minimum medium with different carbon sources , CRP is activated in poor quality ( deﬁned by growth rate ) carbon sources relative to rich quality ones ; this activated CRP associates with the ﬂhDC operon encoding the master regulator with roles in ﬂagellar regulation and development ; the activation of CRP is correlated with the increase of expression of sF as well as the increase of cell-motility . [17576668]
  • While it is known that carbon-catabolite-repression affects the ﬂagellar synthesis and the CRP activation might be involved in alleviating this repression ( 41,42,44,45 ) , much less is known regarding the role of CRP in motility regulation under a range of carbon source conditions . [17576668]
  • Carbon source effects on cell-motility through activation of CRP . [17576668, 17576668]
  • In addition , the synchronized pattern of increasing CRP activity causing increasing FlhDC expression with decreasing carbon source quality , together with the apparent coupling of motility activity with the activation of motility and chemotaxis genes in poor quality carbon sources , highlights the importance of CRP activation in allowing E. coli to devote progressively more of its limited reserves to search out better conditions . [17576668]
  • The correlation between the activity of CRP and the motility of cells indicates that activation of CRP plays an important role in triggering E. coli ` foraging ' - like behavior ( 20 -- 22 ) to actively search for better conditions as the quality of the available substrate ( s ) decreases . [17576668]
  • The upregulation of motility genes correlated with increasing motility of cells in poor quality carbon sources , together with the synchronized pattern of increasing CRP activity causing increasing FlhDC transcription , further suggests CRP is a factor ( or at least one of multiple factors ) to play a positive role in triggering E. coli ` foraging ' - like behavior to actively search for better conditions as the quality of the available substrate ( s ) decreases . [17576668]
  • 0 5-minute induction of σF 5 A 0 2 = σF β ' Motility control by carbon source : CRP binds to and scalably activates FlhDC operon in alternative carbon sources Recently , Liu and coworkers ( 20 ) proposed a new model for carbon source foraging strategy by E. coli . [17576668]
  • Laboratoire de Microbiologie et Genetique Mokculaire , Centre de Gknetique Moleculaire et Cellulaire , UMR CNRS 5534 , Universite Claude Bernard , 69622ViIleurbanne Cedex , France Keywords : Escherichia coli , transcription , CAMP-CRP , maltose regulon , pH The maltose regulon of E. coli consists of numerous genes whose products are involved in the transport and catabolism of maltose and maltodextrins ( Schwartz , 1987 ; Boos et al. , 1996 ) . [9884223]
  • CRP activates transcription from over 150 different promoters in E. coli ( Kolb et al. , 1993 ; Zheng et al. , 2004 ) and this CRP regulon includes several operons mainly involved in catabolism of carbon sources other than glucose ( Kolb et al. , 1993 ) . [20966094]
  • Results Two global regulators , CRP and Cra , of E. coli recognize and regulate as many as 378 and 164 promoters , respectively , of the genes for carbon source utilization ( Shimada et al. , 2005 , 2011a , 2011b ) . [24814025]
  • Expression of the E. coli K-12 melAB genes , which encode products essential for melibiose-metabolism , depends on transcription activation by MelR and CRP , and is triggered by melibiose ( 7,9 ) . [18346968]
  • CRP was the first purified [ 5 ] , the first crystallized [ 6 ] and the best studied transcription activator from Escherichia coli [ 7 -- 13 ] , and plays a key role in activation of a number of the genes for utilization of carbon sources other than glucose ( for reviews see 7 , [ 14 -- 16 ] ) . [21673794]
  • CRP activates transcription of about 200 genes in E. coli ( 9 ) in response to the carbon source available . [20000490]
  • CRP controls transcription of a large number of Escher-ichia coli genes in response to carbon source limitation ( for a review , see Kolb et al. , 1993a ) . [8895588]
  • The CRP regulon deﬁned in this study includes several operons that are involved in carbohydrate-transport and metabolism , such as fucPI for fucose , kdgT for gluconate and fucAO for fuculose . [15520470]
  • Transcription depends upon CRP , the anaerobically triggered transcription activator FNR , the glyoxylate shunt repressor IclR and its activator FadR , and several enzymes involved in acetate-metabolism . [12923087]
  • This analysis demonstrates that the majority of genes for the transport and utilization of sugar acids are under the regulation of CRP ( Fig. 1 ) . [11115104]
  • Results Search for the regulation targets of CRP by using Genomic SELEX screening : SELEX-clos analysis In order to get insight into the genome regulation by CRP for control of carbon source utilization in E. coli , we first tried to identify the whole set of target promoters , genes and operons under the control of CRP . [21673794]
  • In reﬂecting the physiological role of GapA as a real GAPDH , the promoter organization is very unique , being controlled by two global regulators , CRP and Cra , for a large set of genes for carbohydrate-metabolism . [16115199]
  • Besides CRP , another transcription factor , Cra ( catabolite repressor activator ) , has been indicated to play a role in the global regulation of the genes for carbon metabolism ( 16 , 46 ) . [21115656]
  • Moreover , the differences in the regulation targets and regulatory roles of two global regulators , CRP and Cra , in the control of a number of genes for carbon source utilization are totally left undetermined . [21115656]
  • This finding raises the need for reevaluation of the differential roles of two global regulators , CRP and Cra , in the overall regulation network of carbon source metabolism . [21673794]
  • Cra is involved in regulation of the whole set of enzymes in central carbon metabolism ( 43 ) , while CRP regulates the genes for carbon source utilization outside the central metab-olism , including transport of various carbon sources , glycolysisgluconeogenesis switching , the tricarboxylic acid ( TCA ) cycle , the pyruvate-dehydrogenase-pathway , and aerobic-respiration ( 35 ) . [23475967]
  • Based on the functions of novel target genes , we conclude that CRP plays a key regulatory role in the whole processes from the selective transport of carbon sources , the glycolysis-gluconeogenesis switching to the metabolisms downstream of glycolysis , including tricarboxylic acid ( TCA ) cycle , pyruvate dehydrogenase ( PDH ) pathway and aerobic-respiration . [21673794]
  • More recent genomic studies have shown that CRP also activates transcription of genes that encode enzymes involved in central carbon metabolism and transporters of various alternative carbon sources ( 26 , 29 , 85 ) . [19633076]
  • Regulatory roles of CRP : Regulation of the genes for transport of carbon sources Figure 4 . [21673794]
  • Regulatory roles of CRP : Regulation of the genes for carbon metabolism Regulatory roles of CRP : Switching control between glycolysis and gluconeogenesis Several step reactions of the central carbon metabolism are apparently irreversible , different enzymes being involved in catalysis of forward and backward reactions . [21673794]
  • Among the enzymes involved in these four steps reactions for entry to and exist from the central glycolysis pathway , only one enzyme , GlpX , had been identified as a regulation target of CRP . [21673794]
  • Interestingly , a large number of genes involved in the nutrient transport and metabolic pathways are regulated by CRP ( 18 ) and also have been shown to be differentially regulated during a downshift in temperature ( 16 , 34 ) . [21926233]
  • Together with CRP , it is involved in the ( generally ) positive regulation of a number of catabolic genes . [8246840]
  • Lower panel : Most of the genes for the enzymes involved in glycolysis are controlled by Cra [ 30 ] while only three genes , fbaA , gapA and pgk , had been identified as the regulation targets of CRP ( shown in while under blue background ) . [21673794]
  • A limited number of the genes encoding the enzymes involved in glycolysis had been found to be regulated by CRP , including fabA ( fructose-1 ,6 - bisphosphate aldolase ) , gapA ( glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase ) and pgk ( phosphoglycerate kinase ) ( Fig. 5 ) . [21673794]
  • Furthermore a number of the genes involved in the metabolism downstream of glycolysis including PDH pathway and aerobic-respiration were found to be the targets of CRP regulation . [21673794]
  • Regulatory roles of CRP : Regulation of the genes for aerobic respiratory CRP was found to regulate a number of the genes coding for enzymes involved in the metabolism downstream of glycolysis , including pyruvate dehydrogenase ( PDH ) complex , and most of the TCA-cycle enzymes . [21673794]
  • While the cyclic AMP-CRP complex primarily controls the initiation of carbon source utilization , Cra primarily influences the direction of carbon metabolic flux within the central pathways of carbon metabolism by regulating the levels of key enzymes in these pathways [ 26 , 29 ] . [8824175]
  • g002 Location of the CRP-binding sites CRP has been identified to regulate some of the enzymes for central carbon metabolism , including fbaA , gapA , and pgk . [21673794]
  • A total of 28 CRP targets including CRP itself are the specific regulators of carbon metabolism ( shown under green background in Fig. 6 ) , while 13 are the regulators of nitrogen metabolism ( orange background in Fig. 6 ) . [21673794]

  • acs transcription requires CRP I , while optimal transcription also involves CRP II . [12923087]
  • We also show that CRP directly activates transcription from a second s28-dependent promoter that has a similar organization . [19843224]
  • As observed for the MhpR regulator , CRP also regulates expression of other transcription factors in E. coli such as MelR ( Webster et al. , 1988 ) , MalT ( Chapon & Kolb , 1983 ) , RhaS ( Wickstrum et al. , 2005 ) , MaoB ( Yamashita et al. , 1996 ) , HcaR ( Turlin et al. , 2001 ) , GalS ( Weickert & Adhya , 1993 ) , RpoH ( Kallipolitis & Valentin-Hansen , 1998 ) , BlgG ( Gulati & Mahadevan , 2000 ) , PrpR ( Lee et al. , 2005 ) and Fis ( Nasser et al. , 2001 ) . [20966094]
  • This simultaneous CRP control is not unique to the mhp pathway , since it has been also described for the genes for propionate-catabolism in E. coli and Salmonella enterica ( Lee et al. , 2005 ) and for some regulons from E. coli such as those for L-rhamnose ( Holcroft & Egan , 2000 ; Wickstrum et al. , 2005 ) , melibiose ( Webster et al. , 1988 ; Belyaeva et al. , 2000 ) and maltose ( Chapon & Kolb , 1983 ; Richet & Sogaard-Andersen , 1994 ; Richet , 2000 ) . [20966094]
  • Expression of FlhDC is tightly regulated by multiple transcription factors , including CRP , H-NS and OmpR , and hence the genes of the ﬂagellar cascade are regulated in response to many different environmental inputs ( Shin and Park , 1995 ; Sout-ourina et al. , 1999 ) . [19843224]
  • FruR ( Cra ) is a transcriptional regulator which , together with CRP , controls the expression of genes involved in C metabolism , particularly with respect to the direction of metabolic flow , glycolysis being repressed whereas gluconeogenesis is activated ( Ramseier et al. , 1993 ; Saier & Ramseier , 1996 ) . [9421904]
  • For example , the oxidative acid resistance system is regulated by rs and CRP ( Foster 2004 ) , and rs regulates both gene-expression for osmotic stress ( Hengge-Aronis 1996 ) and regulates many acid resistance genes including the uncharacterized ygiW and yodD genes ( Weber et al. 2005 ) identiﬁed in this study . [19919618]
  • CRP is known to be essential for the expression of many genes involved in the transport and catabolism of different substrates ( Kolb et al. , 1993 ) , and it is unsurprising to ﬁnd that the expression of the malXY operon is regulated by a completely CRP-dependent promoter . [19054084]
  • With increasing acetate-formation , expression of many genes known to be differentially expressed in glucose-grown and acetate-grown cells ( Oh et al. 2002 ) or in cells lacking CRP ( Gosset et al. 2004 ) decreased . [17273855]
  • Transcription factor networks under the control of CRP ( TIF ) Promoters for the genes encoding the key metabolic enzymes and the essential cell architectures are under the control of multiple regulators , each monitoring different environmental conditions or metabolic states [ 38 ] . [21673794]
  • Given the lack of probes for these genes on most microarrays , the genes also were not assayed in whole-genome expression surveys to characterize the regulons of well-studied global transcriptional regulators such as CRP ( 16 ) . [19734316]
  • Indeed , the more stress-responsive genes are studied , the more it appears that their regulation involves a network of global regulators , such as H-NS or Lrp , but also CRP , IHF or Fis . [9663683]
  • This raises the question of why CRP should directly regulate transcription of aer and trg , particularly when CRP indirectly regulates transcription of all genes in the ﬂagellar cascade by controlling expression of the master regulator , FlhDC . [19843224]
  • Thus , we propose a complex regulatory cascade in which global regulators ( RpoS , CRP , HN-S , EvgA , etc. ) inﬂuence the expression levels and/or activities of GadX and GadW , which in turn activate the expression and/or activities of transcription activators ( e.g. , YdeO and YhiE ) that directly activate subsets of target genes involved in AR . [12730179]
  • It has long been established that in the absence of exogenous glucose , CRP activates the expression of a large number of genes required for catabolism of alternative carbon sources by E. coli ( for a review , see reference 41 ) . [19633076]
  • CRP modulates positively or negatively the expression of a large number of genes and operons in response to glucose depletion ( 9 , 18 ) . [8655515]
  • Analysis of these operons supports the hypothesis that CRP is not only a regulator of genes required for catabolism of sugars other than glucose , but also regulates the expression of a large number of other genes in E.coli . [15520470]
  • CRP has been identiﬁed as a regulator of genes required for catabolism of sugars other than glucose and a large number of other genes [ reviewed in ( 1 ) ] . [15520470]

  • These mutants identified the genes for catabolite activator protein ( CAP , also known as CRP ) and adenylate cyclase . [11929525]
  • Likewise , CRP may serve as a repressor in genes for adenylate cyclase ( 10,11 ) , glutamine-metabolism enzymes ( 12 ) and the outer membrane protein III ( 13 ) . [6280140]
  • Furthermore , cAMP -- CRP is reported to be a repressor of its own transcription ( Aiba , 1983 ; Cossart and Gicquel-Sanzey , 1985 ; Okamoto and Freundlich , 1986 ; Hanamura and Aiba , 1991 ) , of genes for adenylate cyclase ( Majerfeld et al. , 1981 ; Mori and Aiba , 1985 ) , of genes encoding enzymes participating in glutamine-metabolism ( Prusiner et al. , 1972 ) and of genes for the outer membrane protein III ( Mallick and Herrlich , 1979 ) . [9582281]
  • The CytR anti-activator and CRP act in concert to repress transcription from genes encoding transport proteins and enzymes necessary for uptake and catabolism of ribonucleosides and deoxyribonucleosides ( reviewed by Hammer-Jespersen , 1983 ; Valentin-Hansen et al. , 1996 ) . [9767576]
  • The CRP regulon includes the genes encoding the transporters and the catabolic enzymes of non-glucose sugars [ 9,11 -- 13,15 ] . [21673794]
  • Upper panel : The genes under the control of CRP are indicated under either purple background ( the genes for sugar-transport systems ) or blue background ( the genes for metabolic enzymes ) . [21673794]
  • In any case , CRP was found to regulate not only the genes for carbon-utilization but also some ribosome-related genes . [23475967]
  • In this case , CRP seems to act as a repressor of the mdtEF genes . [16885453]
  • CRP also regulates transcription of genes required for energy production , amino-acid-metabolism , nucleotide-metabolism and ion-transport systems . [15520470]
  • FNR is a CRP homologue and regulates genes during anaerobic growth . [15520470]
  • CRP regulates the majority of genes for three pathways of sugar-transport ( MFS , PTS and ABC ) . [21673794]
  • CRP has also been shown to repress transcription of some genes , including the crp gene itself and cyaA , encoding adenylate cyclase ( 2 , 25 , 26 , 52 , 85 ) . [19633076]
  • Also , evidence has accumulated to indicate that CAMP-CRP complex represses the transcription of as many genes as it activates ( Mallick and Herrlich , 1979 ) . [3021588]
  • In addition , CRP can regulate transcription of other transcription factors , such as MelR , RpoH , BlgG , Fis and PdhR , which could further regulate transcription of genes involved in the above processes . [15520470]
  • A number of genes for uncharacterized transcription factors are under the control of CRP ( black background ) . [21673794]
  • After Genomic SELEX screening , we discovered that a number of genes encoding transcription factors are under the control of CRP ( Fig. 6 ) . [21673794]
  • CRP complex acts as a positive control element for P1 and as a negative factor for P2 . [2537823]
  • Regulation of this operon is complex , involving negative control by attenuation ( 2,3 ) and positive control by a number of factors ( 4,5 ) including cAMP-CRP ( 6,2 ) . [6095192]
  • Well studied regulatory cases include OxyR regulation of OxyS RNA ( oxidative stress ) ( 4 ) , Fur regulation of RyhB RNA ( iron limitation ) ( 5 ) , cAMP-CRP regulation of CyaR and Spot 42 RNA ( glucose limitation ) ( 6 -- 9 ) , OmpR regulation of MicF , OmrA , and OmrB RNAs ( osmotic shock ) ( 10 , 11 ) , E-mediated transcription of MicA and RybB RNAs ( envelope stress ) ( 2 , 12 ) , PhoPQ regulation of MgrR ( Mg2 / Ca2 transport and virulence ) ( 13 ) , and LuxO control of Qrr1 -- 4 ( quorum-sensing in Vibrio ) ( 14 ) . [20075074]
  • A number of small mol-ecules , RNAs , and proteins belong to the complex regulatory network that controls S expression ; ppGpp ( the stringent control signal ) ( 11 ) , homoserine lactone ( 12 ) , inorganic phosphate ( 13 ) , UDP-glucose ( 14 ) , and cAMP-CRP ( 8 ) have been reported to influence the transcription of rpoS . [14978043]
  • The CRP regulators represent a fairly homogeneous group of proteins that control the response to glucose starvation . [11407111]

  • ( iii ) Most of the sugar-transport operons , whose transcription is activated by CRP , are also under the control of repression by other transcriptional regulatory proteins . [8729576]
  • Thus , CRP enhances hlyE expression in response to glucose starvation ( 36 ) and FNR enhances hlyE expression in response to oxygen starvation ( 10 , 11 , 23 ) . [14996792]

  • Thus , CRP and FNR positively control cai expression and H-NS exerts a negative control . [9573142]
  • Expression of the caiF gene is dependent on the same general regulatory proteins , H-NS , CRP , FNR , and transcription factor RpoN ( 11 ) , which control cai and ﬁx expression ( Table 2 ) ( 10 ) . [9573142]

  • INTRODUCTION The structural genes encoding the ~ ystems for nucleoside uptake and metabolism in E. coli are organized in a regulon that is controlled positively by the cAMP/CRP activator complex and negatively by the DeoR and CytR repressors . [2265760]
  • The cAMP-CRP complex regulates many E. coli genes positively and/or negatively at the transcriptional level . [6344011]
  • Our results also point to a direct role of S in response-to-nutrient starvation , suggesting that the S regulon overlaps with other nutrient-speciﬁc regulatory pathways such as cAMP/CRP , NtrB / 54 NrtC / , and PhoB/PhoR . [15489429]
  • Since nitrogen assimilation consumes energy and intermediates of central metabolism ( 35 , 38 ) , the direct action of the cAMP-CRP complex as a modulator of E 54 could provide a regulatory link between carbon and nitrogen metabolism by the dual regulatory role of PTS components and the cAMP-CRP complex ( the activation of 70-dependent promoters involved in carbon metabolism and the downregulation of 54-dependent promoters involved in nitrogen assimilation ) ( 5 , 36 , 37 ) . [15805526]
  • The authors proposed a regulatory role for the cAMP-CRP complex as a switch balancing carbon metabolism and nitrogen assimilation in E. coli by cAMP-dependent repression of a 54-dependent promoter via CRP . [15805526]
  • As NtrC protein levels are controlled by the glnAp2 promoter , the dual regulatory role of the CRP -- cAMP complex ( i.e. the activation of s - dependent promoters involved in carbon 70 metabolism and the downregulation of s - dependent 54 promoters , in particular the glnAp2 promoter , involved in nitrogen assimilation ) might provide a novel and general regulatory linkage between carbon metabolism and nitrogen assimilation in E. coli . [11532153]

  • The cAMP-CRP complex has been shown to be a global regulator of numerous cellular mechanisms and gene-expressions , either as an activator or as a repressor ( 1 ) . [9023186]

  • As a result , almost all the genes for transport of carbon sources are now identified to be under the direct control of cAMP-CRP . [21673794]

  • Commonly , cAMP-CRP is an activator of the 70-dependent transcription of genes coding for catabolism of alternative carbon sources ( 19 ) . [15805526]
  • cAMP-bound active form of CRP is then regulates transcription of a number of genes that are involved in the utilization of non-glucose carbon sources in the absence of glucose [ 9,11 -- 13 ] , and thus it is an antagonist of catabolite repression [ 9,12 ] . [21673794]

  • Key words : autoregulation/catabolite repression/CRP - cAMP/crp expression/transcriptional activation The inhibition of gene-expression by glucose in culture medium has been a paradigm for understanding how genes are regulated in response-to-nutrient status in bacteria . [7518773]

  • A balanced aerobic growth on glycerol depends on three global regulators : cAMP-CRP as the principal inducer of the glycerol catabolic regulon ( including glpF , glpK and glpD ) ; Cra ( FruR ) as regulator of some gluconeogenic genes , and ArcA as regulator of several central metabolic genes including the TCA-cycle and others involved in respiration [ 1,5 ] . [22513097]

[15556475]

  • These seemingly include direct interactions by CRP and FNR to activate transcription initiation and indirect effects by acetate metabolic enzymes and transcription factors that control carbon ﬂux . [10894724]
  • Our set of 11 global regulators are transcription factors involved in carbon degradation ( mlc and lrp ) , redox status sensing ( arcA , narL and FNR ) , ion-transport regulation ( fur ) , environmental sensors ( cspA and CRP ) , a regulator of structural proteins ( hns ) and two general enhancers ( IHF and FIS ) . [12582243]
  • Thus the global regulators are proteins that control responses to changing food levels and carbon degradation ( mlc , lrp , CRP ) and transcription factors that respond to changes in redox status or ion levels of the cell ( arcA , narL , FNR , fur ) . [12582243]

  • Both CRP and FNR are 50-kDa homodimers that bind related inverted-repeats with a TGANNNNNNTCA core motif ( 12 ) . [14996792]

  • FNR and CRP are ~ 50 kDa proteins that recognize related inverted-repeat sequences ( Scott et al. , 2000 ) . [17892462]
  • On the contrary , in vitro and in vivo studies with FLP have shown that it recognizes sequences conforming to a CCTGA N4 TCAGG consensus , which is related to but not congruent with either of the FNR or CRP consensus sequences ( Gostick et al. , 1998 ) . [11407111]
  • Promoter fragment pacs155 was constructed by digestion of pCB63 ( Browning et al. , 2004 ) , followed by religation to form a promoter fragment that lacked sequences upstream of CRP II . [17630973]
  • In the other , the putative half UP-element present in the wild-type promoter was optimized and completed to a full UP-element ( which has a sequence identical to a full UP-element that is known to function with Es and a CRP box located at 269.5 ; Law et al. , 1999 ) . [11532138]
  • FNR is structurally related to CRP and , like CRP , binds to a 22bp sequence that accommodates two FNR subunits ( Green et al. , 1991 ; Sharrocks et aL , 1991 ) . [8748035]
  • LuxS was previously shown by Wang et al. ( 65 ) to be negatively regulated by crp , but it lacked a sequence upstream of the coding sequence for luxS that was able to bind CRP in vitro . [18978044]
  • The role of IHF has remained less clear : while in vitro it is known to bind simultaneously with CRP and to cause inhibition of acsP2 transcription , in vivo the upstream sequence containing the three IHF sites has a positive effect on transcription ( Browning et al. , 2004 ) . [17630973]
  • To ﬁnd out whether coregulation by S-containing RNA polymerase and cAMP-CRP is a more general phenomenon , the upstream regions ( 200 bp ) of all 481 positively S-controlled genes identiﬁed here were screened for putative cAMP-CRP boxes , de-ﬁned as TGTGA ( N6 ) TCACA , with a maximum of three mismatches allowed . [15716429]
  • This indicates that the minimal csiE promoter consisting of just the -35 and - 10 regions can be recognized by os-containing RNA polymerase holoenzyme , whereas transcriptional initiation by 070-containingRNA polymerase requires activation directly or indirectly by cAMP-CRP mediated by a cis-acting sequence element situated at least partially upstream of position -38 . [8596457]
  • Alternatively , Shanblatt & Revzin ( 1983 ) have recently proposed that RNA polymerase bound at P induces the fixation of a second CRP molecule , which binds to the sequence upstream from - 5 0 and is responsible for the protection as far as - 7 0 . [6408264]
  • Together with CRP , puriﬁed RNA polymerase gives a clear footprint that runs from position 115 to upstream of +1 +10 +20 CRP bound at Site 1 . [19054084]

  • These results indicate that upstream sequences of glnAp2 are not essential for CRP -- cAMP-mediated inhibition . [11532153]
  • These sequences are recognized by at least three regulators , Gal repressor ( GaIR ) , Gal isorepressor ( GalS ) and cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , which modulate transcription from these promoters . [7934815]
  • A total of about 70 promoters carry two CRP box sequences , some of which have been experimentally identiﬁed to bind two molecules of cAMP-CRP . [24814025]
  • Specific sequences to which the CRP and FNR proteins bind , to stimulate transcription , have been proposed . [2407723]

  • It has been shown recently that when CytR and CRP are used together to select DNA sequences that are preferred for formation of the three-protein complex , the sequences most commonly selected are CytR recognition motifs separated by 10 -- 13 base pairs and almost centered between CRP1 and CRP2 ( 8 ) . [10347150]
  • For screening of DNA sequences with affinity to CRP , purified His-tagged CRP was mixed with a collection of E. coli genome fragments of 200 -- 300 bp in length , and CRP-bound DNA fragments were affinity-purified . [21673794]
  • For identification of the sequences of DNA fragments bound to CRP , we first performed SELEX-clos ( cloning-sequencing ) analysis . [21673794]
  • This implies that CytR and CRP recognize very similar DNA sequences . [2575702]
  • On the basis of these results , we first proposed a simple competition model for the action of CytR in which the repressor and the cAMP-CRP complex recognize very similar or overlapping DNA sequences . [1649947]
  • © 2003 Blackwell Publishing Lt Results FIS binds the acs regulatory region at multiple locations Beatty et al. ( 2003 ) showed that acs transcription from the major promoter acsP2 depends upon CRP and that CRP binds to tandem sites centred at positions -69.5 and -122.5 ( Fig. 1 ) . [14651625]
  • Discussion Beatty et al. ( 2003 ) showed that CRP binds tandem sites located upstream of the major promoter acsP2 to activate its transcription synergistically . [14651625]
  • Most notably , in E.coli CRP binds to and stimulates transcription at novel CRP sites with a distinct consensus ( CRP-S ) that makes transcription activation dependent on an additional protein factor , Sxy . [17068078]
  • In promoters where CRP acts as a sole transcription activator or synergistic activator , it binds to highaffinity sites . [17068078]
  • Transcription from the melR promoter is dependent on CAMP-CRP : specific nucleotide sequences downstream of bp -59 with respect to the me & transcription start are sufficient for full promoter activity . [2851497]
  • Predicted FNR and cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) sites at suitable distances from putative promoter sequences are located immediately upstream of aspA and dcuB ( 36 , 44 ) . [9852003]
  • In all cases , these studies have implicated interactions of CRP and CytR with sequences located in the 80 -- 100 bp immediately upstream of the various transcription start sites and interactions between the proteins as the basis for positive and negative gene regulation . [8969182]
  • However , at the metK , ybiS and yjcB predicted promoter regions , the CRP sites are located 3 bp upstream of the 35 hexamer . [15520470]

  • When activated by cAMP , CRP recognizes speciﬁc DNA sites via the C-terminal F-helix ( αF ) which forms a typical helix -- turn -- helix ( HTH ) motif , together with the neighboring E-helix ( αE ) ( Fig. 1 , 1G6N ) . [19439203]
  • CRP binds as a dimer to speciﬁc DNA sites and induces a DNA bend of approximately 90 degrees in the presence of its ligand , cAMP ( 21 ) . [16166533]
  • As a consequence , the active cAMP-CRP complex binds to speciﬁc DNA sites located at or upstream of CRP-dependent promoters . [15805526]
  • We carried out DNase I protection experiments with a wild-type malEpmalKp DNA fragment to examine whether CRP binds to these sites . [2538630]
  • On the basis of these observations , we propose that P2 is a synergistic class III promoter that consists of tandem DNA sites for CRP , each lo cated at a class I position . [12923087]
  • Two CRP homodimers bind in tandem at DNA sites centred at the Class I positions -69.5 and -122.5 . [17630973]
  • AraC , one of the members in Group 2 , is suggested to bind to at least two sites around the promoter region and to form a double stranded DNA loop of more than 200 bp in the absence of arabinose , cAMP or CRP , while the loop could open in the presence of both arabinose and cAMP-CRP ( Dunn et al. , 1984 ) . [8729576]
  • Homodimeric CRP forms a complex with cAMP , which is able to bind DNA at specific sites near the promoter region . [16814929]
  • However , comparison of the deo sites with the other known CRP sites ( Figure 5 ) suggests that the cAMP-CRP complex recognizes not only the consensus described by Ebright but two specific 8 bp regions separated by a region of 6 bp . [6329724]

  • Speciﬁcally , CytR has a relaxed spacing requirement between operator half-sites and can , in concert with cAMP -- CRP , repress transcription in vivo from octamer boxes separated with centre distances up to three helical turns . [9466254]

  • In the galPi promoter , this CRP site is centered at -41.5 , while for galS it is centered at -42.5 , but the spacing between the -10 region and the center of the CRP site is 29 bp in each case , a distance optimal for cAMP-CRP-activated promoters in E. coli ( 30 ) . [8416900]

  • Co-operative binding of cAMP-CRP and CytR Next we tested binding of CytR and cAMP-CRP to a 160 bp fragment containing nupG sequences from - 1 1 8 to - 1 0 in the DNase I footprinting assay . [8596434]
  • Addition of CytR protein to binding reactions containing cAMP-CRP resulted in protection of an 84 bp region spanning from CRP-1 to around position - 10 . [1327747]
  • Addition of the CytR extract to binding reactions containing cAMP-CRP results in protection of an 80 bp region spanning from CRP-1 to CRP-2 ( lanes 7-9 ) . [1649947]
  • However , the location and spacing of two CRP targets within the udpP promoter region were conserved : they were separated by 36 bp and the distance between the CRP1 target and the − 10 region in all four cases was identical . [14499937]
  • In the absence of cAMP -- CRP , the CytR repressor binds two such octamer motifs in inverted or direct repeat arrangement , preferably separated by 2 bp ( Figure 6A ) . [9155036]
  • ( A ) In the absence of cAMP -- CRP , the CytR repressor preferentially binds octamer repeats in direct or inverted orientation , separated by 2 bp . [9155036]
  • Thus , cAMP -- CRP preferentially stabilizes a set of CytR conformations that ﬁt operators composed of inverted-repeats with wide spacing ( 10 -- 13 bp ) , or direct repeats separated by 1 bp . [9155036]
  • In the presence of cAMP -- CRP , CytR recognizes ( B ) inverted octamer repeats separated by 10 -- 13 bp or ( C ) direct repeats separated by 1 bp . [9155036]
  • The latter was described as an inverted pentameric repeat TGCAA-N2 -- 3-TTGCA [ 36 ] , ( where N denoted the number of nucleotides ) , a palindrome TTGCAA [ 38 ] , or a pair of inverted octameric repeats ( either 59-AATGYCAAC-GC-GTTGCATT-39 or 59-AYGTGCAAC-Nx-GTTRCATT-39 , where Y = T or C , R = A or G , and x = 10 , 11 , 12 or 13 ) which are the optimal CytR-binding sites in the absence of CRP , or direct repeats of octamers in either orientation with a 1 bp spacer [ 37 ] . [23028500]
  • In the absence of CRP , the optimal binding site for CytR consists of two octamer repeats , in direct or inverted orientation , and separated by 2 bp . [9466254]
  • The study revealed that CytR , when co-binding with two molecules of CRP , preferentially recognizes inverted-repeats separated by 10 -- 13 bp , or direct repeats separated by 1 bp . [9767576]
  • However , when co-binding with cAMP -- CRP , CytR instead recognizes inverted-repeats separated by 10 -- 13 bp , or direct repeats separated by 1 bp . [9155036]
  • When co-binding with tandem cAMP -- CRP complexes , CytR preferentially recognizes inverted octamer repeats separated by 10 -- 13 bp or direct octamer repeats separated by 1 bp . [9466254]
  • Finally , CRP 3 and CRP 4 are separated from each other by 73 bp , or about seven helical turns . [7551052]
  • The CytR operator of the cdd promoter contains R -- 1 -- R direct repeats , and the repeats are separated by 5 and 14 bp , respectively , from the ﬂanking CRP targets . [9155036]
  • The apparent explanation for our observation is that CRP makes a direct interaction with MelR bound to Site 1 and Site 2 and this recruits the CRP dimer to the 20 bp gap between the two bound MelR subunits . [10760178]
  • The CytR/cAMP-CRP repression complex in rot is similar in structure to those formed at deoP2 and cddP and consists of two cAMP-CRP molecules separated by 53 bp , with CytR bound in between . [7715459]
  • The majority of the nucleoprotein complexes consist of a single CytR molecule bound between two CRP molecules separated by 52 or 53 bp . [9767576]
