  • The CRP boxconsensus sequence , 59-TGTGA-N6-TCACA-39 , agrees well with the hitherto identified [ 38 ] , but indicates clearly that G at position 4 and C at position 13 of the CRP-box are highly conserved in good agreement of their key roles to exhibit the high affinity to CRP . [21673794]
  • CRP recognizes a 22-bp target sequence and , at many promoters , activates transcription by making one or more direct contacts with RNA polymerase ( Busby & Ebright , 1999 ) . [19054084]
  • The consensus DNA target for CRP binding is the 22 bp inverted-repeat 50-AAATGTGATCTAGATCACATTT-30 and , at most previously studied targets , CRP activates transcription by making one or more direct contacts with RNA polymerase ( Belyaeva et al. , 1998 ; Busby & Ebright , 1999 ) . [17608696]
  • Alternatively , since the strong CRP2 target is expected to span ~ 30 bp ( Liu-Johnson et al. , 1986 ) , the sequence at the edges of the CytR operator may optimize both cAMP -- CRP and CytR interactions with DNA . [9155036]
  • When bound with cAMP , CRP is converted into a functional form and recognizes a spe-ciﬁc DNA sequence , referred to CRP box , with the consensus sequence of a 22-bp inverted-repeat sequence , 50-AAATGTGATCTAGATCACATTT-30 [ underlines are highly conserved ] ( De Crombrugghe et al. , 1984 ; Berg & von Hippel , 1988 ; Gunaskerra et al. , 1992 ) . [24814025]

  • At Class II promoters , CRP binds at a target that overlaps the promoter -35 element and is usually centred at position -41.5 . [19843224]
  • At class II promoters , a CRP dimer binds to DNA at a site centered near position 41.5 . [12923087, 15755952]
  • At class I promoters , a CRP dimer ( cross-hatched double oval ) binds to DNA at a site centered near position 61.5 , 71.5 , 82.5 , or 92.5 . [15755952]
  • DNase I footprint analysis showed that CRP binds and protects two sites centered at bp 2313 ( site 1 ) and bp 2140 ( site 2 ) relative to the transcription initiation site , but a mutational analysis demonstrated that only site 1 is required for CRP-mediated regulation of gcvT-lacZ expression . [10074087]
  • 20 No. 19 pp. 5392 ± 5399 , 2001 Repression of deoP2 in Escherichia coli by C conversion of a transcription activator into a repressor ytR : Minsang Shin , Soim Kang , Seok-Jin Hyun , Nobuyuki Fujita , Akira Ishihama , 1 1 Poul Valentin-Hansen and Hyon E.Choy 2 3 Department of Microbiology , Chonnam University Medical College , 5 Hakdong , Dongku , Gwangju , South Korea 501-714 , Department of 1 Molecular Genetics , National Institutes of Genetics , Mishima , Shizuoka 411 , Japan and Department of Molecular Biology , 2 Odense University , Campusvej 55 , DK-5230 Odense M , Denmark 3 Corresponding author e-mail : hyonchoy@chonnam.ac.kr In the deoP2 promoter of Escherichia coli , a transcription activator , cAMP ± CRP , binds at two sites , centered at ± 41.5 and ± 93.5 from the start site of transcription , while a repressor , CytR , binds to a space between the two cAMP ± CRP complexes . [11574471]
  • In contrast , for the P2 promoter , which functions in the absence of cAMP-CRP , the crucial sequence extends to only 39 base-pairs upstream from the transcription start . [6408264]
  • CRP , a homodimer , undergoes a conformational change when complexed with its allosteric effector cAMP and binds to a speciﬁc sequence located near or within target promoters to regulate transcription ( 18 ) . [10074084]
  • At low cAMP levels , transcription initiates from the galP2 promoter but as cAMP levels increase , the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) - cAMP complex binds to its recognition sequence preventing transcription from galP2 and activating transcription from the galP1 promoter , which is located 5 bp downstream . [8709852]
  • In this case of autogenous regulation , the CAMP-CRP complex binds to a site downstream from the transcription start point ; thus bound the complex presumably prevents RNA polymerase from transcribing distal sequences . [3021588]
  • In fact we showed previously that CRP-cAMP bound to the consensus CRP site placed far downstream of the transcription start site of test promoter only a weakly blocks enlongating RNA polymerase , while CRP-cAMP bound to the CRP site placed close to the promoter strongly inhibits the transcription by excluding RNA polymerase from the promoter ( 9 ) . [1715982]
  • It partially overlaps the -10 sequence of the dad promoter and the transcription initiation region , implying that interaction of the complex with this site might interfere with transcription as in the case of some promoters repressed by cAMP-CRP ( for a review , see reference 7 ) . [7906689]
  • Presumably the cAMP-CRP complex would bind to this site and interfere with the initiation of transcription of the speA gene . [2198270]
  • to the proposed model , the cAMP-CRP complex binds to this single site in the ara regulatory region to activate transcription of both the araC gene and araBAD operon . [2521619]
  • In the presence of cAMP , the cAMP-CRP complex ( hereinafter called CRP ) will bind to a 22 bp 2-fold-symmetric recognition site located within or near target promoters ( Berg and von Hippel , 1988 ) , and thereby activate transcription from these promoters . [8895588]
  • Based on in vitro studies of the cloned crp gene , we found previously that the transcription of crp is negatively regulated by CRP-cAMP that binds to a specific site -LCB- CRP site I ) located about 40 bp downstream from the transcription start site -LCB- Aiba , 1983 ) . [1328816]
  • Molecular mechanism of negative autoregulation of ABSTRACT Transcription of the Eschenchia coli crp gene encoding cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) is negatively regulated by CRP-cAMP complex that binds to a specific site located downstream from the transcription start site . [1715982]
  • Thus , MalI-dependent repression is marginally less efﬁcient compared with the malX promoter , the dependence on CRP is relaxed by the DNA site for CRP being located at position 43.5 , and the promoter carries seven repeats of a 50-TAN8-30 motif , to facilitate RNA polymerase recruitment ( Lloyd et al. , 2008 ) . [20141531]
  • The position of the Arr site ( -83 ) relative to the FNR site ( -41.5 ) of the ansB promoter suggests that Arr and FNR may co-regulate anaerobic ansB expression in a manner analogous to the co-activation of this promoter by tandemly bound FNR and CAMPreceptor protein ( CRP ) ( Scott et al. , 1995 ) . [9308170]
  • These CRP variants contain leucine ( CRP181 EL ) or valine ( CRPI 81EV ) substitutions at position 181 , they fail to discriminate between different bp at positions +4 and bind to both the intact CRP site in the lac promoter and to sites altered at positions +4 with an affinity 10-fold lower than that with which CRP-wt protein binds to the wildtype lac promoter target ( Ebright et al. 1984 , 1987 ) . [1661372]
  • Interestingly , the CRP sites at the galP1 and melR promoters ( de Crombrugghe et al. , 1984 ; Webster et al. , 1988 ) are located between positions 252 and 231 from the transcription start site and also share 14 and 12 positions , respectively , with the consensus sequence ( Fig. 2b ) . [20966094]
  • Interestingly the CRP site at the gafP1 promoter is also located from bp -52 to -31 and is also homologous to th consensus at ten positions ( de Crombrugghe et al. , 1984 ) . [2851497]
  • Based on genetic and biochemical analyses of cAMP-CRP/DNA interactions in the lac promoter , the second amino acid in the recognition helix of CRP ( glutamate at position 181 ) has been proposed to make contacts to the GC basepair located at position + 4 and the CG bp at position - 4 in the consensus CRP binding site , 5 ' - TGTGAN6TCACA-Y ( both positions underlined ) ( Ebright et al. 1984 , 1987 ) . [1661372]
  • In the crystal structure of the CRP-aCTD-DNA complex , aCTD contacts approximately 6 bp of DNA spanning a minor groove , centred 18 -- 19 bp from the centre of the DNA site for CRP ( Benoff et al. , 2002 ) . [19843224]
  • In accordance with this prediction , the CRP target has been found to vary for several genes , not only with respect to the DNA sequences and symmetry characters but also with respect to the distance between the binding site and the start of transcription ( Reznikoff and Abelson , 1978 ; Simpson 1980 ; Taniguchi et al. , 1979 ; Ogden et al. , 1980 ; Lee et al. , 1981 ; Queen and Rosenberg , 1981 ; Le Grice et al. , 1982 ) . [6329724]
  • In the case of class II CRP-dependent promoters the activation is mainly due to CRP binding to a 22 bp target site centred at or near position 241.5 from the transcription start site , overlapping and replacing the 235 determinant for binding of RNAP ( Zheng et al. , 2004 ; Busby & Ebright , 1999 ) . [20966094]

[8895588]

  • Although CRP sites appear from different distances upstream to cognate promoters , maximal activation is obtained when CRP is located at bp 261.5 or 241.5 upstream of the transcription start site ( reference 25 and citations therein ) . [8631699]
  • c Although derived from PguaB ( 133 to 36 ) , upstream displacement of the CRP site in this promoter derivative means that native PguaB sequences extend to position 117 and the upstream boundary of the CRP site is located 139 bp upstream of the transcription start site . [19633076]
  • In most cases , CRP activates transcription from a point about 40 bp upstream of the start of transcription , but in others it interacts from a point at least 6 turns of DNA helix upstream from the transcription start site . [12881519]
  • There are no known examples where CRP , acting alone or in concert with an UP element , modulates transcription from a site located more than 100 bp upstream of the transcription start site . [19633076]
  • CRP was first identified as a transcription activator of the lac operon , where CRP binds at a site located 61.5 bp upstream of the start of transcription . [12881519]
  • For class I promoters , the DNA target site for CRP is located upstream of the DNA site for RNAP , at 61.5 or at various distances upstream from the transcription start point , provided that the DNA target site for CRP and the DNA site for RNAP are on the same face of the DNA helix . [24509317]
  • From this position , or a site located one helical turn upstream , CRP can activate s38 - , but not s70-dependent transcription . [19843224]

  • Footprinting studies have shown that FNR and CRP activate hlyE expression from the same site centered 61.5 bp upstream of the SlyA-associated transcription start site ( 10 , 36 ) . [14996792]

  • Our results support the model in which repression normally involves the binding of CytR to cAMP-CRP to form a complex which binds to speciﬁc sites in the udp promoter , without direct interaction between CytR protein and a speciﬁc operator DNA sequence , and in which induction by speciﬁc inducer cytidine involves dissociation of CytR from cAMP-CRP and then RNA polymerase interaction with cAMP-CRP bound to a site upstream of the transcription start point . [8626289]
  • At class I promoters ( with the lac promoter as the prototype ) , cAMP-CRP binds to a position ( the ` CRP box ' ) centred around 261.5 nucleotides upstream of the transcriptional start site and interacts with the C-terminal domain of the RNA polymerase a-subunit ( aCTD ) , which is positioned on the DNA between cAMP-CRP and the promoter-binding s - subunit of RNAP . [11532138]
  • Expression from the melR promoter is completely dependent on the cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , which binds to a DNA site centered at position 241.5 upstream from the melR transcript start point ( Webster et al. , 1988 ) . [10760179]
  • CRP binds to a single DNA site upstream of I1 and I2 . [10760178]
  • AraC-dependent transcription initiation at the araBAD promoter is increased by CRP , which binds to a single DNA site upstream of I1 and I2 ( 11 ) . [12060687]
  • To activate transcription , CRP binds to a specific DNA site located upstream from a promoter and interacts with RNAP . [12881519]
  • Further studies showed that the melR promoter is a typical Class II CRP-dependent promoter , activated by a single dimer of CRP , that binds to a 22 bp DNA site centred at position 241.5 with respect to the transcription start point ( reviewed by Busby and Ebright , 1997 ) . [10760178]
  • The activity of the malT promoter is regulated by the activator protein CRP which binds to a specific recognition site centred at -70.5 bp from the start site of transcription . [8895588]

  • FIS prevents crp transcription initiation FIS and CRP compete for binding to overlapping binding sites at the crp promoter To investigate the mechanism by which FIS represses crp transcription , we mapped by DNase I footprinting the FIS - and CRP-binding sites on a crp promoter fragment encompassing sequences from -- 126 to 1119 . [9582281]

  • Transcription of the gltA and sdhCDAB gene appears to diverge from a single intergenic region that contains two pairs of potential promoter sequences and two putative CRP ( cyclic AMP receptor protein ) - binding sites . [6383359]

  • Although the sites in the glpFK promoter do not match the consensus very well , cooperative binding of CRP to the tandemly repeated sites may be at least part of the reason this promoter is relatively sensitive to catabolite repression . [1372899]
  • Model for Cooperative and Competitive Binding of CytR and cAMP-CRP -- To determine whether such interactions of CytR with DNA sequences overlapping and thereby occluding or competing with CRP binding to CRP1 and CRP2 can account quantitatively for both the loading free energy changes in Table I and apparent free energy changes in Fig. 6 , two models that incorporate two additional CytR binding sites and which constitute opposing possibilities were evaluated . [8969182]
  • Here too , CRP bound to either CRP1 or CRP2 or both is a net recruiter for CytR binding . [10347150]
  • By eliminating cooperativity between CytR and CRP bound to flanking sites , cytidine should make CytR into a simple competitor for CRP binding to CRP1 and CRP2 . [8969182]
  • Additionally , while cytidine binding to CytR nearly eliminates the pairwise interactions between CytR and CRP bound at CRP1 , it has little effect on pairwise cooperativity between CytR and CRP bound at CRP2 or as a consequence on the overall cooperativity of the three-protein complex in which CRP is bound to both sites . [20000490]
  • In this model , CRP and CytR compete for binding to mutually exclusive sites at CRP2 , but CRP alone binds to CRP1 with no competition from CytR . [10347150]
  • But this would also be partly offset by unfavorable competition between CytR and CRP for binding to overlapping sites at CRP1 and CRP2 . [8969182]
  • These data indicate strong cooperativity in CytR-CRP action and direct CRP binding to its recognition sites at udpP , as at other CytR-regulated promoters . [8626289]
  • While the majority of CytR-binding sites are imperfect inverted-repeats situated between binding sites for another transcription factor , CRP , other architectures were observed , in particular , direct repeats . [23028500]

  • Generality of the isolated DNA sequences One complication in devising a general selection scheme for cAMP -- CRP-dependent CytR-binding sites was that cooperative binding of cAMP -- CRP and CytR had been observed on DNA templates with 52 -- 54 bp separations between the centers of the two CRP targets ( Søgaard-Andersen et al. , 1990 ; Pedersen et al. , 1991 ; Holst et al. , 1992 ) . [9155036]
  • This structural complexity , together with the fact that CytR repression at deoP2 has a strict requirement for a spacing of 52 or 53 bp between the two CRP binding sites ( S0gaard-Andersen et al. , 1990b , 1991b ) , has hampered the proposal of a unifying binding model for CytR . [1327747]

  • ( B ) Sequence of the proP P1 promoter with the match to the CRP consensus noted . [10601034]
  • CRP functions as a dimer in the form of a CRP -- cAMP complex , and regulates transcription initiation by binding to a symmetrical DNA sequence ( consensus sequence 50-AAATGTGATCTAGATCACATTT-30 ) , located near or within the promoter regions . [15520470]
  • CRP modulates transcription initiation by RNA polymerase ( RNAP ) by binding to a 22-base consensus target DNA sequence contained in the gene promoter . [24509317]
  • Since the clones responded to multiple stresses ( Table 2 ) , sequences homologous to the o `` 32 promoter [ 19 ] , cAMP-CRP binding [ 36 ] , cr54 promoter sequence [ 37 ] , gearbox promoter [ 8 ] , or -10 hexamer ( TATACT ) , possible ~ - binding consensus sequence [ 31 ] , were also explored . [8647276]
  • Meanwhile , our ﬁndings that the three iscS-dependent genes commonly contain the CRP-binding consensus sequences in their promoter regions provide a potential link between iscS and gene regulation via CRP . [18482579]
  • Other consensus sequences for CRP binding have been suggested ( 18,19 ) and these sequences , differing by three nucleotides or less , appear in the proposed CRP binding region in the ilvB promoter . [6095192]
  • Although we have argued that some element in the sequence from - 4 5 to - 5 6 is necessary for stable CRP binding , we can not exclude the possibility that RNA polymerase also makes contacts in this zone that are essential to stabilize the open complex at P1 . [6408264]
  • Genes that are subject to catabolite repression are activated by the complex formed between cyclic AMP and its receptor protein ( CRP ) , which interacts with a conserved sequence of nucleotides close to the corresponding RNA polymerase binding site ( Valentin-Hansen , 1982 ; Chapon & Kolb , 1983 ) . [6383359]

  • This consensus sequence includes and extends the model for the CRP binding site proposed by O'Neill et al. ( 1981 ) in which it is postulated that the two subunits of the CRP dimer recognize a core of two inverted-repeats , which overlap each other ; the core 5 ' - TGTCACA-3 ' 3 ' - ACAGTGT-5 ' The two CRP binding sites in deo are in nearly perfect agreement with the 10-bp consensus proposed by Ebright , i.e. , a fit of 9 out of 10 for the proximal site ( from - 51 to - 35 ) and 8 out of 10 for the distal site ( from -83 to -99 ) ( see Figure 5 ) . [6329724]
  • The consensus sequence for FNR binding is very similar to that for CRP , differing at just two symmetrically related positions in the inverted-repeat ; appropriate changes at these positions can result in interconversion of CRP and FNR sites ( Bell et aL , 1989 ; Zhang and Ebright , 1990 ; Jennings and Beacham , 1993 ) . [8748035]
  • Consistently , the protected glycines are all located in the consensus part of the CRP sites at positions that are important for binding of CAMP-CRP ( see Figure 1B ) ( de Crombrugghe et al. , 1984 ; Schultz et al. , 1991 ) . [8221894]
  • In their survey of 15 CRP binding sites de Crombrugghe et al. ( 1984 ) showed that the nucle-otide sequence 5 ' TGTGA3 ' is the most conserved part ofthe consensus and that most sites contain this sequence element : indeed Weber and Steitz ( 1984 ) and Ebright et al. ( 1984 ) have shown that this sequence contains the bases that make the strongest contacts with CRP . [2851497]
  • Thirteen independently isolated mutations that stopped CRP binding all fell in the sequence 5 ' T-C-A-C-A 3 ' between - 3 8 and -34 , a sequence that matches well with the consensus sequences proposed for CRP binding sites ( O'Neill et al. , 1981 ; Queen & Rosenberg , 1981b ; Ebright , 1982 ) .   • ( iii ) There is not a potential CRP site at the position of the CRP site 2 in Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium ( 20 ) ( although there are CRP sites at the positions of sites 1 and 3 , each with the same number of matches to the CRP consensus sequence ) . [16166533]

  • Interestingly , the mutations creating a consensus sequence at CRP site 3 had a twofold negative effect on rhaBAD expression , while the CRP site 3 down mutation had a small positive effect on rhaBAD expression . [16166533]
  • CRP site 2 is a very weak match to the CRP consensus sequence that we would not have considered had it not been positioned symmetrically with CRP site 1 at rhaBAD . [16166533]
  • While the substitutions changing CRP site 1 to the consensus sequence at the 10 most conserved positions resulted in a small increase in rhaBAD expression , a similar increase in expression was observed in the absence of CRP , suggesting that the increase in expression may be due to the DNA sequence change and not a change in CRP occupancy of the site . [16166533]
  • These results suggest that the degree of CRP occupancy of the wild-type site 1 , which matches the consensus sequence at 9 out of 10 positions , does not limit rhaBAD expression , whereas the degree of occupancy of CRP site 3 does normally limit rhaSR expression . [16166533]

  • Each of these CRP site `` down '' mutations consisted of three simultaneous base pair substitutions that changed consensus base pairs to nonconsensus base pairs ( 5 ) ( Fig. 1 ) . [16166533]
  • The yjcB and ycfR operons contain a CRP site almost identical to the consensus . [15520470]
  • The construct pMWK10 contains an altered CRP site ( 59-AAATGTG ATCTAGATCACATTT-39 ) that perfectly matches the consensus . [11053378]
  • This possibility was tested in a set of constructs in which the distance between CRP-1 and a synthetic consensus CRP site was varied systematically between 37 and 54bp . [1962841]

  • The promoter structure of uidA resembles that of a promoter activated by cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) ; putative control regions are located at positions - 1 0 and - 3 5 ( relative to the transcription start site ) , are separated by more than 17 bp and exhibit poor homology with the normally recognized consensus sequences .   • Particularly from the fact that both the ompA and gal Pz promoters have the same octanucleotide sequence , T-C-A-C-A-C-T-T in their RNA polymerase recognition site ( -35 region ) , it became relevant to find out if the CAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) binds to this region of the ompA gene to influence the cellfree transcription of the ompA gene [ 2 ] . [7021177]
  • The mechanisms underlying the activation of transcription initiation at specific promoters are far from being elucidated , not only in eukaryotes but also in a simple organism such as Escherichia coli For prokaryotes , a simple model has emerged from extensive studies of transcription activation by the E. coli CRP protein ( CAMP receptor protein ) ( De Crombrugghe rt al. , 1984 ) and the lambda CI protein ( Ptashne , 1986 : ( 1 ) the activator , a dimeric protein , binds to a recognition sequence charact.erized by a dyad symmetry and located slightly upstream from the - 35 region of the RNA polymerase binding site , and ( 2 ) t ' hrough protein-protein contacts or/and a DNA conformational change , the activator facilitates one or several steps in the initiation process . [2538630]
  • In an in vitro system in the absence of CAMP-CRP , RNA polymerase binds preferentially to a site located 22 bp before the principal ( Pl ) binding site ( Malan & McClure , 1984 Malan et al. , 1984 ) and under certain reaction conditions can result in initiation of a transcript from this position in vitro ( $ - U-U-C-C-G - ; Reznikoff et al. , 1982 ; Malan & McClure , 1984 ) . [2582140]
  • In analogy with the preceding examples , the RNA polymerase binding site for the -52 transcript could compete directly for cAMP-CRP binding at the -50 to - 70 binding site for cAMP-CRP ( Dickson et al. , 1975 ) , while the transcript itself could interfere with initiation downstream . [2582140]
  • In others , such as lac ( 23 ) , araBAD ( 22 ) and malT ( 24 ) , CRP binds in a region outside of the RNA polymerase binding site ( around bp -62 , -90 and -70 respectively ) . [6095192]
  • whereas in tnost ' operons CRP binds at a site adjacent to RNA polymerase . [1848302]
  • Moreover , DNase I footprinting studies indicate that the CAMP-CRP complex binds to a site which overlaps extensively with the RNA polymerase binding site . [2982847]
  • Relevant nucleotides ( transcriptional and translational start sites , ÿ10 and ÿ35 positions of the csiD promoter and the divergent upstream promo-ter , and highly conserved nucleo-tides in the CRP binding site consensus ) are underlined . [9512707]

[9512707]

  • Recently , we showed that CytR binds specifically to multiple sites in the E. coli deoP promoter , thereby providing competition for CRP binding to CRP operator site 1 ( CRP1 ) and CRP2 as well as cooperativity . [10347150]
  • Figure 1A illustrates the complex architecture of the melAB promoter with four sites for MelR binding and a DNA site for CRP . [12675795]
  • Although there are very few known examples of E. coli proteins binding to noncanonical DNA sites , CRP binds to a noncanonical site in the melAB promoter in cooperation with MelR bound to adjacent DNA sites ( Wade et al. 2001 ) . [16264194]
  • Comparative analysis of the udpP promoter region from Y. pseudotuberculosis , V. cholerae , S. typhimurium and E. coli revealed that location , spacing and orientation of putative binding sites for CRP protein are highly conserved , whereas CytR protein recognition sequences of udpPYp and udpPV c deviate markedly from the E. coli and S. typhimurium CytR binding site .   • In order to precisely localize the CRP binding site , DNase I footprint experiments were performed with a radiolabeled PCR fragment that extended from positions ÿ172 to 44 with respect to the transcriptional start site . [9512707]
  • In this communication we report the results of in vitro CRP-DNA interaction studies which establish that four of the five putative binding sequences bind CRP with high affinity , and that the fifth ( the most distal one relative to the transcriptional start site ) binds CRP with lower avidity . [7551052]
  • Analysis of the nupC promoter region revealed the presence of at least two putative CRP binding sites , centred at - 40 bp and - 89 bp , which probably flank a CytR-binding site . [8022285]
  • Additionally , when carefully comparing the positioning of these putative CRP binding sites in the patZ promoter region , the two highest scoring sites were located at -41.5 ( score 2.60 ) and -81.5 ( score 2.66 ) bp from the RNA polymerase binding site . [22059728]
  • This conﬁrms that the two highest scoring putative CRP binding sites ( located at -41.5 and -81.5 bp from the RNA Pol binding site , from now on named CRP I and CRP II ) are essential for the complete induction of patZ . [22059728]
  • In addition , initial searches with Nucleotide Subsequence Search , MacVector , version 6.0 ( Oxford Molecular , Campbell , Calif. ) , revealed two other potential candidates for CRP binding sites , one located at the 2119-bp region and the other at the 244-bp region of the secB gene ( respective to transcriptional start site 11 ) . [10074084]
  • In contrast to the CRP footprints , which are localized to the 22-bp CRP binding sites , CytR binding protects an extended region from about bp 225 to 2110 bp relative to the start site for transcription ( Fig. 4 ) . [8969182]
  • CRP binding to the gcv control region protected two sites from DNase I digestion , one centered near bp 2313 ( site 1 ) and the other centered at bp 2140 ( site 2 ) relative to the transcriptional start site ( Fig. 4 ) . [10074087]

  • The promoter region contains two CRP sites , one at 60.5 upstream from the promoter and another at +12.5 downstream of transcription initiation site . [24814025]
  • The ansB promoter in Escherichia coil is co-activated in a co-dependent manner by one dimer each of CRP and FNR protein whose binding sites are at around -91 and -41 bp , respectively , from the transcription start site . [8748035]
  • A recent study , which evaluated the distribution of CRP binding sites along the E. coli chromosome , identiﬁed a potential CRP binding site within the fnr promoter region centered at bp 145.5 relative to the transcription start site ( 18 ) . [17293415]
  • However , two CRP-binding sites exist within the pck promoter region : The promoter-distal CRP box ( CRP box-1 ) is located at the position 90.5 bp of transcription start site , while the second CRP box ( CRP box-2 ) is located downstream from the transcription initiation site , centered at +13.5 .   • The Fis protein binds to a site centered 81 bp downstream of the CRP binding site in the proP regulatory region and functions as a positive activator of P2 promoter transcription . [10601034]

  • The CytR-regulated promoters usually contain two DNA sites for CRP , centred at positions 41.5 and 93.5 with respect to the transcription start point , and a DNA site for CytR located between the two CRP-binding sites ( 43 ) . [15520470]
  • The CRP binding site is centered at position -41.5 , and two AraC binding sites , araFGl and araFG2 , are centered at positions -80 and -155 , respectively , from the transcription start site . [1400237]
  • CRP is known to activate transcription by binding to sites located at various positions upstream of the 235 site ( from 241.5 to 2103 ) ( 11 ) . [9852003]
  • A single CRP binding site is located 2115.5 and 2215.5 bp upstream of the divergent transcription start sites for the papI and papB genes , respectively , and CRP positively regulates expression of these genes by inhibiting binding of the repressing H-NS protein ( 8 ) . [10074087]
  • In deoCp2 , the cAMP-CRP binding sites are located around positions -40 ( CRP-1 ) and -93 ( CRP-2 ) preceding the start site for transcription ( Fig. 1 ) . [2170326]
  • At class I promoters , such as lac , CRP binding sites are located near 62 , 72 , 83 or 93 relative to the transcription start site . [17068078]
  • In agreement with the involvement of cAMP and CRP in transcription from P5 , a putative CRP binding sequence ( TGTGGATAAAATCACG ) was found at 38 to 39 bp upstream of the transcription start sites . [2139650]
  • In the case of fur , a proposed cAMP-CRP binding site is situated about 60 bp upstream from the transcriptional start sites ( 11 ) . [2160948]
  • However , unlike the situation in the genes described above , in which the cAMP-CRP complex binds in the region upstream of the promoters , the proposed binding site in cir lies far downstream ( over 100 bp ) from the start sites of transcription for promoters P1 and P2 ( Fig. 3 ) . [2160948]
  • In vitro binding experiments and a mutational analysis suggest that CRP binds to a site centered at bp 2313 relative to the transcriptional start site for gcv . [10074087]
  • One possible example for transcriptional activation at a distance was the araBAD operon because it was postulated that cAMP-CRP binding for the araBAD operon was centered > 90 bp from the transcriptional start site ( 4 , 9 ) . [6377308]
  • With respect to the araC transcriptional initiation site , cAMP-CRP binding is centered 54 bp upstream , a distance that is intermediate to those found in the lacZ and gal P1 promoters ( 32 ) . [6377308]
  • Summary Previous work with semi-synthetic promoters containing a single CRP binding site centred at 41.5 bp from the transcription start site has demonstrated enhanced transcription ( synergism ) when a second binding site , for CRP or FNR , is placed upstream at around -91 bp . [8748035]
  • This places the CRP binding site at 243.5 bp upstream of the transcription start site rather than at 241.5 bp ( Fig. 1 ) , which is the usual location for the activator binding site at class II CRP-dependent promoters ( Busby and Ebright , 1997 ) . [11251844]
  • Concerning the mechanism of the negative autoreguiation , we have shown that CRP-cAMP bound at CRP site I stimulates the binding of RNA poiymerase to the overlapping divergent promoter and then this binding of RNA polymerase interferes with the occupation of RNA poiymerase at the crp promoter ( iHanamura and Aiba , 1991 ) , in this paper , we report a previously unknown aspect of the crp reguiation which is concerned with the role of the second CRP-binding site -LCB- CRP site ii ) iocated about 60 bp upstream from the transcription start site of crp -LCB- Aiba , 1983 ) .   • The negative regulation of crp transcription by CRP-cAMP is mediated by the CRP binding site I located 40 bp downstream from the crp start site . [7518773]
  • In particular , rotP2 , rotP3 and rotP4 eaoh contain a cAMP-CRP-binding site at a distance from the start site of transcription that would allow activation by cAMP-CRP : ihe centre of CRP-1 is located 42.5 bp upstream of the rotP2 siart site . [7715459]

  • The CRP binding site ( T / CC/TTTTTTGAATCCCATCACAAA/T ) is located upstream of the transcriptional start site and is centered at position 61 , which ﬁts the paradigm of class I CRP-dependent promoters ( 30 ) . [20622065]
  • In class I CRP-dependent promoters , CRP is known to activate transcription from a DNA site located upstream of the DNA-binding site for E 70 , with the site for CRP usually centered at position 62.5 , 72.5 , or 92.5 relative to the transcription start site . [15805526]
  • The previous observation that maximum guaB promoter activity can be achieved in the absence of sequences located upstream of position 59 is inconsistent with a mechanism whereby CRP occludes an adjacent or overlapping binding site for a transcription factor that activates PguaB ( 33 ) . [19633076]

  • Examination of the CRP binding site of the tdc promoter revealed that it was located 43.5 bp upstream of the transcription initiation site . [11251844]
  • We monitor these signals in promoter variants that place the CRP binding site at different distances upstream of the start site of transcription . [8952481]
  • However , much less is known about promoters where the CRP binding site is located further upstream of the transcription start site , such as the malT promoter . [8895588]

  • The most intensely studied promoter of this type is the lac promoter with a CRP binding site centered at position -61.5 with respect to the start site of transcription . [8952481]
  • The CRP binding site identified in this promoter region is conserved across 36 E. coli and Shigella strains examined , yet the distance between the CRP binding site and start of mcaS transcription is sub-optimal , falling between that normally found for class I and class II CRP-dependent promoters .   • The second repeat , which overlaps with the first one , is 6 bp long and exhibits a strong similarity to the consensus cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) - binding site ( Berg and von Hippel , 1988 ) . [8709849]
  • CRP exhibits a high degree of speciﬁcity for a G base at position 7 ( corresponding to a C at position 16 ) of the 22-bp consensus CRP site ( aaaTGTGAtctagaTCACAttt ) ( the core binding site is shown in upper case , and positions 7 and 16 are underlined ) . [19633076]

  • CRP -- cAMP binding to the consensus site located at − 37.5 in the galP1D4 promoter ( Bell et al. 1990 ) was assayed by in vivo DMS footprinting after an osmotic upshift . [10601034]
  • No consensus binding site for the CRP protein could be detected in the upstream region of sfm , conﬁrming that CRP probably does not bind to the promoter region of sfm ( Grainger et al. , 2005 ) and does not directly compete with H-NS . [20345943]

  • Indeed , the cAMP/CRP-induced DNA bend at base-pair -62 in the ZacPl promoter region has been shown to be asymmetrical with a larger degree of bending on the 5 ' - side than on the S / - side of the CRP protein binding site ( Wu & Crothers , 1984 ; Lui-Johnson et al. , 1986 ) . [1569580]

  • 34 , No. 20 6001 -- 6014 doi :10.1093 / nar/gkl734 Escherichia coli 's cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , the archetypal bacterial transcription factor , regulates over a hundred promoters by binding 22 bp symmetrical sites with the consensus core half-site TGTGA . [17068078]
  • Introduction Positive transcriptional activation by cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) involves binding of dimeric CRP to a 22 bp sequence at target promoters , with each subunit of the CRP dimer binding to an 11 bp half site . [8748035]
  • In E. coli , the cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) is a global transcription factor that regulates numerous genes by binding to a 22-bp DNA sequence ( 3 ) . [21460078]
  • The 187 bp DNA fragment contains the three CRP binding sequences CRP 3 , CRP 4 and CRP 5 ( see Fig. 1 ) . [7551052]
  • CRP did not bind the identical DNA fragment with substitutions in 4 bp of one of the CRP-binding motifs . [16321939]

  • De Crombrugghe et al. ( 1984 ) and Raibaud and Schwartz ( 1984 ) have noted that , in general , positively controlled promoters , or CRP activated ones , have particularly poor homology with consensus sequences , and also that the - 1 0 and - 3 5 regions are more than 17 bp apart . [2823062]
  • A CRP dimer has been shown to recognize two 5-bp sequences ( consensus , TGTGA and TCACA ) that are related by a twofold rotational symmetry and that have a 6 - or 8-bp spacer region in between ( 2 -- 4 , 12 , 13 ) . [8655515]
  • CRP , which is functional as a homodimer , recognizes 22 bp target sequences , with the consensus 5 ′ - AAATGTGATCTAGATCACATTT-3 ′ . [19843224]
  • Between the coding regions of fucA and fucP , there are five stretches that match to various degrees the consensus cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) - binding sequences ( 15 ) - all with a core TGTGA . [2553671]
  • We therefore scanned the regulatory regions of the remaining operons for sequences with a lower match to the consensus ( 5 as a cut-off score ) and found an additional 70 operons that contain CRP sites with a score between 5 and 10 ( Tables 1 and 2 ) . [15520470]
  • The two targets match the CRP core consensus ( TGTGA-N6-TCACA ) in 8 ( CRP-1 ) and 6 ( CRP-2 ) out of 10 possible positions . [9767576]
  • The FLP consensus retains the same TGA/TCA core motif in each half-site , but differs from the FNR and CRP sequences in having four rather than six intervening nucleotides ( TGA N4 TCA ) . [11407111]
  • The following consensus sequences are indicated by the following symbols : Shine-Dalgarno ( GAAA ) , - 35 ( TTGACC ) and - 10 sequences ( TATTCT ) , CRP ( TGTGCN , CACA ) and pyridoxal phosphate ( w ) consensus sequences , PstI ( CTGCAG ) , Hind111 ( AAGCTT ) , Rho-independent terminator ( - * - ) ; aa determined by sequencing ( * ) , translation stop site of nupG ( I - ) . [7828866]
  • The presence of FNR and CRP consensus sequences upstream of caiF is consistent with the activation of transcription of a caiF-lacZ fusion by these two proteins ( Table 3 ) . [8631699]
  • The five putative CRP consensus sequences are boxed . [8300537]
  • The putative consensus sequences for the CRP , FNR , Fur , and FhlA/HyfR proteins are enclosed by rectangles . [14702328]
  • Boldface letters indicate putative CRP and FNR half consensus sequences in addition to presumptive recognition sequences of the s54 factor of RNA polymerase . [8631699]

[11115104]
  • At that , we gradually increased the number of aligned sequences , starting with closest E. coli relatives and then including more distant ones , in the order given by the phylogenetic tree of the CytR proteins ( Fig. 2 ) , while the OCRP sites could be reliably aligned and the distance between them remained approximately constant . [23028500]
  • It contains OCRP sites flanking direct repeats of OCYTR [ 8,29 ] . [23028500]
  • To identify new candidate CytR regulon members , we used three recognition rules to select regions for construction and manual analysis of alignments , requiring either ( 1 ) two candidate OCRP sites at a distance 10 -- 40 bp , or ( 2 ) two candidate OCYTR sites at a distance not exceeding 20 bp , or ( 3 ) all four sites in the configuration OCRPD -- N ( 210 ) -- 20 -- OCYTRD -- N0 -- 20 -- OCYTRP -- N ( 210 ) -- 20 -- OCRPP , with negative numbers denoting overlapping sites . [23028500]
  • While the distance between the OCRP sites flanking OCytR is mostly conserved for the tsx orthologs in the Enterobacteriales , about 14 bp , the score of the 4-box cassette even in close relatives of E. coli is rather low , due to low scores of the OCRP sites ( about 3 ) . [23028500]
  • coli is preceded by a cassette formed by two OCRP sites at a conserved distance ( 29 -- 31 bp ) and OCYTR sites in the correct arrangement , and this cassette is conserved in 17 related genomes , that is , in almost all Enterobacteriales and Vibrionales . [23028500]
  • The distance between the OCRP sites in the udp promoter is conserved ( 30 or 31 bp ) in almost all Enterobacteriales and Vibrionales ; the only exceptions with non-conserved intersite distances and an overall low score of the cassette are Photobacterium profundum , Photorhabdus luminescens and Vibrio fischeri . [23028500]
  • The SWAS plot has two pronounced peaks corresponding to the OCYTRD and OCYTRP sites with the conserved distance of 9 bp between them and an overlap between the latter and the proximal OCRP site ( Fig. 8 and [ 39 ] ) . [23028500]

  • IHF can thus play an analogous role to that of CRP in facilitating NagC-dependent DNA loop formation at the divergent nagE-BACD operons ( Plumbridge and Kolb , 1998 ) . [17238917]
  • Transcription was reduced in the presence of CRP containing HL159 and this reduction was suppressed by KN52 confirming that AR1 is required at the downstream site ( Table 1A ) . [8748035]
  • S Also , the distal UP-element half-site located downstream of the CRP box seems to have its share in Es S selectivity . [11532138]
  • Although the glpD operators match the consensus verywell , the glpD operon maybe less sensitive to repressor ( relative to theglpFK operon ) because the operator sites are situated downstream of the CRP binding site and the -35 region of the promoter ( -10 to +30 ) . [1372899]
  • CRP was first identified as a transcription activator of the lac operon , where CRP binds at a site located 61.5 bp upstream of the start of transcription . [12881519]
  • CRP activates acs transcription by binding tandem sites located upstream of the major promoter , acsP2 , whereas , both IHF and Fis each act at different times during growth as anti-activators of CRP . [17233826]
  • CRP activates acs transcription by binding tandem DNA sites located upstream of the major promoter , acsP2 . [14651625]
  • CRP activates transcription by binding to speciﬁc sites located upstream of promoters and contacting RNAP ( 11 ) . [19633076]
  • CRP is known to activate transcription by binding to sites located at various positions upstream of the 235 site ( from 241.5 to 2103 ) ( 11 ) . [9852003]
  • This site is located immediately upstream of the RhaR-binding site and in the same relative position as the functional CRP site at rhaBAD . [11073923]
  • When the CRP-binding sequences are located upstream or near promoters of the flanking genes , these genes are predicted to be under the control of CRP . [21673794]
  • When the CRP-binding site is located upstream of a single gene or operon ( and downstream of another neighboring gene ) , we predicted these downstream genes or operons as regulation targets of CRP ( Table 2 , group-A ) . [21673794]
  • When CRP represses at the ompA and cya promoters , it is bound outside of its activation position and within the common zone of repression ( Fig. 2 ) . [1943993]
  • These results are consistent with the cooperation of FIS and CRP in repressing the function of both the fis and divergent promoters observed in vitro ( Figs. 3B and 5 ) . [11279109]
  • Furthermore the in vivo reporter assay indicated that both pgi ( glucosephosphate isomerase ) and gpmM ( phosphoglycero mutase III ) promoters were activated by CRP while the fbaB ( class-I fructose-bisphosphate aldolase ) promoter was repressed by CRP ( Fig. 5 ; for experimental details see Fig. 3 ) even though these genes were not detected by Genomic SELEX screening under the experimental conditions and the cut-off level of SELEX-chip pattern herein employed . [21673794]
  • Prominent examples are the bacterial nitrogen uptake regulating transcription factor , NtrC , which is phosphoryiated in its active form by NtrB ( Austin and Dixon , 1992 ; Sanders etai , 1992 ) , or the catabolite regulatory protein , CRP , which is activated by oAMP ( Botsford and Harman , 1992 ) . [7512187]
  • One-third of operons subject to CRP-dependent glucose repression ( 13/39 ) in Gosset et al. were activated by CRP in ROMA experiment . [15520470]
  • Operons that are still significantly activated by KE101-CRP ( outliers ) are indicated in boldface . [15520470]
  • Therefore only 14 % ( 25/176 ) of operons were activated by HL159-CRP to the same level as by wild-type CRP . [15520470]
  • Operons that are not activated by KE101-CRP or regulated in a reduced level ( outliers ) are indicated by ` # ' , and operons that are activated by KE101-CRP at the same level as by wild-type CRP indicated by ` -- ' . [15520470]
  • Interestingly , a few known FNR-regulated operons , adhE , sdhC , sodA , cyoA and focA , were also activated by CRP in the ROMA experiments . [15520470]
  • Using ROMA , we identified 176 operons that were activated by CRP in vitro and 16 operons that were repressed . [15520470]
  • In the 17 CRP-activated operons , 9 operons are known members of the CRP regulon and 7 operons were activated by CRP in the ROMA experiment . [15520470]
  • Of the 188 operons activated by CRP , the promoter-proximal gene was activated in the vast majority ( 176 operons ) . [15520470]
  • The deoC , nupG and tsx operons that are under CytR regulation were activated by CRP in our study . [15520470]
  • araBAD , araC , araE , and papB promoters are also activated by CRP ; narG is also activated by nitrate . [1943993]
  • Transcription is activated by CRP and repressed by a multi-protein CRPzCytRzCRP complex . [8969182]
  • We found that transcription of the ykgMO operon is repressed by Zur and that azuC and ykgR transcription is repressed and activated by CRP , respectively . [19734316]
  • azuC is repressed by CRP . [19734316]
  • ykgR is activated by CRP . [19734316]
  • Expressionfrom the suc promoter was repressed by IHF and partially activated by d8but it was not regulated by ArcA , FNR , CRP , FruR or Fis , and not repressed by glucose or anaerobiosis , indicating that the well-established catabolite and anaerobic repression of ODH synthesis is imposed elsewhere . [9720032]
  • This showed that the acnB gene is subject to repression by ArcA , Fis and FruR and activation by CRP , whereas the a c n A gene is repressed by ArcA and FNR , activated by FruR , CRP , Fur and SoxRS , and initiated by a38in stationary phase . [9421904]
  • Further studies with acn-lac2 gene fusions and a wider range of transcription regulators indicated that acnA expression is initiated by G ~ ~ from PIacnAa , nd from PZacnA it is activated directly or indirectly by CRP , FruR , Fur and SoxRS , and repressed by ArcA and FNR . [9421904]
  • Regulation of acnB gene transcription Apart from being activated by CRP and repressed by ArcA , the acnB gene exhibited a very different pattern of regulation to that of acnA . [9421904]
  • For example , induction of the CFA/I operon by temperature requires the positive regulator CfaD [ 70 ] expression of the pap operon requires CRP and PapB [ 71 ] , the virB gene of Shi-gella is activated by VirF [ 49 ] and Fis plays a role in activation of the rrnB gene [ 48 ] . [7748941]
  • This contrasts with fumA expression , which has recently been shown to be activated by the cyclic AMP-CRP complex and repressed anaerobically by the arcA ( dye ) - encoded regulator ( J. R. Guest and R. S. Buxton , unpublished observations ) . [2656658]
  • These data suggested that hlyE expression is activated by FNR and CRP , repressed by H-NS , and that H-NS-mediated transcriptional silencing is relieved by SlyA . [17892462]
  • In contrast , acnB expression is activated by CRP and repressed by ArcA , FruR and Fis from PacnBC . [9421904]
  • An additional negative control , CRP and the gadA promoter ( which lacks a CRP binding site ) , did not show CRP binding under the same conditions ( data not shown ) . [17293424]
  • Expression was completely CRP dependent , as expected ( data not shown ) . [8748035]
  • The negative control of speC by CAMP in a cell-free system was shown to be dependent upon CRP . [3021588]
  • The developing model for the control circuit is that , when E. coli is actively growing under conditions where cAMP levels are high ( e.g. , exponential growth in media like LB medium ) , CRP will repress gadX by inhibiting RpoS production . [12446650]
  • The results indicate that CRP repression of gadX occurs primarily , but not completely , through its control over rpoS ( Fig. 7B , compare EF528 and EF678 ) . [12446650]
  • The data , in sum , suggest that the majority of CRP control over gadA and gadBC occurs through its control over RpoS , which , in turn , is needed to maximally express gadX . [12446650]
  • The CRP-McaS-csgD circuit forms an incoherent feedforward loop where CRP and McaS act in opposition ( CRP activates csgD and McaS while McaS represses csgD ) , while the regulatory circuit formed by CRP-McaS - flhD is a coherent feedforward loop ( CRP activates both mcaS and flhD while McaS activates flhD ) . [22289118]

  • The changes induced by binding of CRP to its recognition site map to the boundaries of the CRP binding site ( Figure 2a , lane 2 ) . [8952481]

  • The main conclusions derived from this study are that 1 ) acid and stationary phase induction of gadA and gadB expression occurs at the transcriptional level ; 2 ) a single promoter drives the expression of each gene regardless of the inducing condition ; 3 ) the sigma factor σS is required for stationary phase induction , but not acid induction , of gad expression ; 4 ) CRP is a negative regulator of σS-dependent gad expression ; and 5 ) a conserved 20 bp sequence located between ® 52 and ® 73 bp in the gadA and gadBC promoters is essential for both acid and stationary phase induction .   • KEINOSUKE OKAMOTO AND MARTIN FREUNDLICH Department of Biochemistry , State University of New York , Stony Brook , NY 11794 ABSTRACT Expression of the crp gene is negatively autoregulated by the complex of cyclic AMP and its receptor protein ( cAMP-CRP ) . [2425359]
  • The dadAX operon is expressed by multiple promoters that are repressed by leucine-responsive regulatory protein ( Lrp ) and activated by cyclic AMP-CRP . [10216857]
  • The dcuB gene is strongly activated anaerobically by FNR , repressed in the presence of nitrate by NarL , and subject to cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) - mediated catabolite repression . [9852003]
  • unusual , since only in rare cases does cyclic AMP-CRP both activate and inhibit expression from an individual operon ( 1 , 35 ) . [1310090]
  • Effect of altering the putative upstream promoter on ilvB expression DISCUSSION Transcription of the ilvB operon is positively activated by cyclic AMP and its receptor protein , CRP . [6095192]
  • One operon , araFGH , codes for the well-studied AraC protein and by cyclic AMP ( cAMPt ) receptor protein ( CRP ) ( Englesberg et al. , 1965 ; Greenblatt & Schleif , 1971 ; Wilcox et al. , 1974 ) . [2231717]
  • The data obtained indicate that the expression of gyrA is growth phase dependent and under the positive control of the cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) . [8655515]
  • The operon is also positively controlled by the cyclic AMP-cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) complex and negatively by the catabolite repressor / activator ( Cra ) protein . [11361063]
  • This operon has also been reported to be positively regulated by cyclic AMP-cyclic AMP receptor protein complex ( cyclic AMP-CRP ) ( 6 ) . [8955407]
  • tre operon expression is under the control of the cyclic AMP-cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) complex as well as that of TreR . [11361063]
  • As expected , gut operon expression is under the control of the cyclic AMP-cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) complex . [11361063]
  • ptsG but not crr is subject to positive control by the cyclic AMP-cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) complex . [11361063]
  • The operon is subject to positive control by cyclic AMP and the cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) . [11361063]
  • The manXYZ operon is also subject to positive control by the cyclic AMP-cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) complex . [11361063]
  • In E. coli , the nanATEK-yhcH operon is positively controlled by cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) and negatively regulated by the upstream nanR-encoded transcriptional repressor , NanR ( 6 -- 10 ) . [23935044]
  • Taken together , these data strongly suggest that the ilvB biosynthetic operon is negatively controlled by multivalent transcription termination and is positively regulated ` by cyclic AMP and CRP . [6292893]
  • A number of in vivo experiments suggest that the ilvB operon is positively controlled by cyclic AMP and CRP ( 4 , 6 ) . [6292893]
  • In a previous report on the stringent and growth-rate-dependent control of the gua operon [ 8 ] , the presence was noted of a cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) site centred at position 3117.5 with respect to the guaBA transcription start site and overlapping the translational start site of the divergent xseA gene . [10856643]
  • In vitro transcription from the ilvB promoter was greatly increased by cyclic AMP and CRP . [6292893]
  • Regulation of transcription of the araBAD and araFGH operons depends upon promoter occupancy by cyclic AMP receptor protein ( CRP ) ' and AraC protein ( 6 , 8 , 11 , 12 ) . [1447222]
  • ( b ) In strain S764 , the bgl -- lacZ fusion carries the same activated bgl promoter allele , bgl-CRP + , as is present at the bgl operon . [16207917]
  • It has been reported that even though the main role of the CAMP-CRP complex is to activate transcription , it can also , in some cases repress it , as it does in the case of the P2 promoter in the gal operon , and the ompA and clp promoters . [2465204]
  • These examples with single operators upstream of -45 are the promoters of the CytR regulon , the spf promoter ( see CRP in Tables 1 and 2 ) , and perhaps the gal operon . [1943993]
  • However , in the absence of CRP , transcription of the gal operon can initiate from the upstream galP2 promoter ( 26 ) , which will mask the weak transcription from galP1 . [15520470]

  • Discussion It is well established that transcription of crp is negatively autoreguiated by the CRP-cAMP that binds to downstream CRP site I ( Aiba , 1983 ; Okamoto and Freundlich , 1986 ; Hanamura and Aiba , 1991 ) . [1328816]
  • It was shown conclusively , by using cya-lac fusion strains , that one of the cya promoters , P2 , is negatively regulated by the cAMP-CRP complex and that the decrease in cya transcription under repressing conditions is about fourfold . [8246840]
  • Taking these results together , we conclude that crp transcription is regulated both negatively and positively by CRP-cAMP depending on the concentrations of CRP and cAMP in vivo as well as in vitro . [1328816]
  • The major finding is that transcription of crp is not only negatively but also positively regulated by CRP-cAMP , and upstream CRP site II is responsible for this positive autoreguiation . [1328816]
  • The data also suggest that transcription from this start site is positively regulated by PhoB and negatively regulated by cAMP-CRP . [10986267]
  • At P1 and P2 transcription is repressed by the DeoR repressor and induced by deoxyribo-se-5-P ; at P2 transcription is also repressed by the CytR repressor ( the inducer being cytidine or adenosine ) and depends on cAMP and CRP . [2994018]
  • Three promoter/operator regions have been demonstrated : at P01 and P02 , transcription is repressed by the deoR repressor and induced by deoxyribose-5-P ; at P02 , is also the transcription repressed by cytR repressor , induced by cytidine or adenosine , and depends on cAMP and CRP ; at P03 , transciption is controlled by unknown protein factor ( s ) and induced by inosine or guanosine . [16453417]

  • cAMP-CRP Activates an RNA Transcribed in the Opposite Direction to the crp Gene . [2425359]
  • cAMP-CRP does not block crp expression if the new promoter is altered so that divergent RNA can not be made . [2425359]
  • The divergent RNA requires cAMP-CRP for expression ; it strongly blocks crp transcription ; and , if this RNA is not made , cAMP-CRP inhibition of crp expression is abolished . [2425359]
  • We have shown that this divergent RNA strongly blocks crp transcription and that a functional divergent promoter is necessary for cAMP-CRP inhibition of crp expression . [2425359]
  • The activation of the divergent promoter by cAMP-CRP and its proximity the suggested that the divergent to crp promoter promoter might play a role in crp autoregulation . [2425359]
  • These data suggest that the negative autoregulation of the crp gene is a direct consequence of the activation of the divergent promoter by cAMP-CRP . [2425359]
  • These results indicate that the negative autoregulation of the crp gene is a direct result of the activation of the divergent promoter by cAMP-CRP . [2425359]
  • Taken together , the data suggest that the RNA activated by the presence of cAMP-CRP is not transcribed by the crp promoter but by a different promoter that allows transcription in the opposite direction to the crp gene . [2425359]
  • This altered template retained crp promoter function but crp transcription was no longer inhibited by cAMP-CRP . [2425359]

  • The cAMP/CRP complex is a positive transcriptional regulator of a number of catabolic operons , and as such , plays a role in catabolite repression , whereby secondary carbon sources are not catabolized in the presence of glucose . [21029047]

  • The cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) - cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) complex stimulates the expression of lsrR and the lsr operon , which includes lsrACDBFG , while LsrR represses their expression and is located adjacent to , while being transcribed divergently from , the lsr operon [ 14-16 ] . [18560382]
  • In this report , we show that both AI-2 synthesis and uptake in Escherichia coli are subject to catabolite repression through the cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) - CRP complex , which directly stimulates transcription of the lsr ( for `` luxS regulated '' ) operon and indirectly represses luxS expression . [15743955]
  • In this study , we show that catabolite repression inﬂu-ences AI-2 accumulation through the cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) - cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) complex , which directly stimulates transcription of the lsr operon and indirectly represses luxS expression . [15743955]
  • Regulation by cAMP-CRP Complex The effects of the cAMP-CRP complex on the expression of the GntII genes were examined by using singlecopy lacZ operon fusions of the gntV and idnD genes , which were constructed on the E. coli genome in the cents cya background . [14593252]
  • Expression of lsrR and the lsr operon is inhibited by LsrR and stimulated by the cAMP-CRP complex . [18560382]
  • cAMP-CRP stimulates expression of the lsr operon by directly binding to the upstream region of its promoter . [15743955]
  • In E. coli , the cAMP-CRP complex stimulates the expression of both lsrR and the lsr operon by binding to the promoter regions , while LsrR represses their expression [ 14 , 15 ] . [18560382]
  • The cAMP-CRP complex stimulates the expression of lsrR and the lsr operon , while LsrR represses their expression [ 14 , 15 ] , suggesting that cAMP , the CRP , or both may be affected by sdiA-ydiV double mutation . [18560382]
  • The cAMP-CRP complex stimulates expression of both lsrR and the lsr operon of E. coli , which are divergently transcribed , by directly binding to the two different CRP binding sites in the intergenic region [ 14 , 15 ] . [18560382]
  • The repressing effect of cAMP-CRP may be responsible for the low increase of osmY expression in stationary-phase cells starved for glucose in minimal medium ( which is in pronounced contrast to a more than 30-fold induction in LB medium ) , because the at onset of starvation the synthesis of cAMP is drastically stimulated under these conditions ( 7 ) . [8253679]
  • The ; 30-fold postexponential repression of dctA expression by glucose in L broth observed under aerobic conditions was largely reversed by the addition of cAMP ( from 0.17 to 2.9 mmol/min/mg ) , which provides a strong indication that dctA is activated by the cAMP-CRP complex ( Fig. 8C ) . [10482502]
  • When D-galactose is present , cAMP-CRP can activate P1galE and repress P2galE ( 32 ) . [19541626]
  • We found that transcription of galR is independent of cAMP -- CRP concentrations ; therefore , its input function resembles a TRUE gate with different levels of expression in the presence and absence of D-galactose . [17630975]
  • Expression of the enzymes encoded by the galETKM operon can be described by the sum of the P1galE and P2galE input functions , which results in a ` D-galactose ' gate , with lower level and dis-coordinated expression of the proteins in the absence of cAMP -- CRP . [17630975]
  • Expression of the psiE9-9cat fusions ( pKE135 , pKE136 , and pKE137 ) was reduced in DphoB strain transformants when transformants were grown in the presence of cAMP in both Tris-glucose LP and HP media ( Table 1 ) , suggesting that expression of these constructs is also negatively regulated by cAMP-CRP . [10986267]

  • In the maltose system , the lamB , malK , and malEFG operons encoding the transport system are more dependent for their expression on the cAMP-CRP system than the malPQ operon encoding amylomaltase and maltodextrin phosphorylase ( 36 ) . [2834341]
  • For example , the stationary phase expression of cgsA ( encoding the curlin subunit gene ) is modulated by both a ® and HN-S ( Olsen etai , 1993 ) , and osm / ( encoding a periplasmic protein ) is activated by a ^ and repressed by Lrp , cAMP-CRP and IHF in stationary phase cells ( Lange et ai , 1993 ) . [7984106]
  • Transcription of these genes is activated in response to intracellular cAMP levels by the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) , a transcription factor that activates expression of over 100 E. coli genes . [12667072]
  • Interestingly , expression of both genes is activated by cAMP-CRP and repressed by CsrA . [12867454]
  • Furthermore , the gal regulon genes are differentially regulated by cAMP-CRP and D-galactose , and in the absence of D-galactose the expression of the mglBAC operon can be activated by cAMP-CRP , whereas the transcription of galP gene is strongly repressed [ 38,39 ] . [22513097]
  • These in vitro results conﬁrm the previously reported in vivo observations that expression of these three genes is highly dependent upon cAMP and CRP ( Weickert and Adhya , 1993b ; Geanacopoulos and Adhya , 1997 ) . [17630975]
  • These results indicate that , unlike prpBCDE expression , expression of prpR is not regulated by propionate or its catabolism but is regulated by glucose or glycerol availability , suggesting a classic catabolite repression mechanism mediated by cAMP-CRP . [15805526]
  • Our results suggest that the cAMP-CRP complex acts as a transcriptional factor to repress the expression of hfq . [21840983]
  • These results suggested that the glucose effect on ulaG expression is mediated by a mechanism independent of the cAMP-CRP complex . [14996803]
  • Since it is known that the amount of the cAMP-CRP complex increases under glucose starvation conditions such as Tris-glycerol medium , these results suggested that expression of psiE is negatively regulated by cAMP-CRP independent of the phosphate concentration . [10986267]
  • Our results show that the expression of sxy in E. coli is positively autoregulated via a mechanism dependent on CRP , cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) and a newly identiﬁed CRP-S site . [25491382]
  • On the basis of in vitro and in vivo experimental data , Preiss and co-workers have proposed that expression of E. coli glgCAP genes is positively regulated at the transcriptional level by the cAMP/CRP complex [ 19,21,45 ] ( reviewed in [ 11 ] ) . [21029047]
  • These results and the occurrence of a putative cAMP-CRP binding site suggest that the gntK gene expression is positively regulated by cAMP-CRP at the transcriptional level . [9135111, 9135111]
  • These results indicated that cAMP-CRP positively regulated the expression of gipD and glpE . [1846566]
  • These results suggest that the expression of the luxS gene is negatively regulated by cAMP and CRP . [15743955]
  • These results , together with measurements of the in vivo psiE promoter activity under various conditions , show that expression of the psiE gene is under direct positive and negative control by PhoB and cAMP-CRP , respectively . [10986267]
  • Taken together , these results demonstrate that csiE is under positive control of both as and cAMP-CRP . [8596457]
  • Under these conditions any gene under positive cAMP/CRP control should be at least weakly induced . [7934831]
  • It is well known that the growth-dependent expression of some genes is under the control of the cAMP-CRP complex ( 19 , 25 , 26 , 31 ) . [8655515]
  • It is possible that cAMP-CRP may control another transcriptional regulator ( s ) that modulates luxS expression . [15743955]
  • This negative influence of cAMP can be attributed to the presenceof os , which plays a positive role in csiE expression and which is itself under negative control by cAMP-CRP ( Lange and Hengge-Aronis , 1994a ) . [8596457]
  • This work represents an initial contribution to the elucidation of the role of cobB and yﬁQ gene products in the control of the metabolism of E. coli , describing for the ﬁrst time how their expression is regulated and co-ordinated by central metabolism regulator CRP and the concentration of cAMP . [22059728]
  • Discussion We have shown here that expression of the stationary phase-induced gene csiE is under the control of the os subunit of RNA-polymerase and the cAMP-CRP complex . [8596457]
  • We examined the gene expression of glpD and glpE under the control of cAMP-CRP using glpD-iac and `` glpE-lac fusino genes . [1846566]
  • In addition to regulation by its own protein product , araC gene expression is under positive control of the cAMP receptor protein ( CRP ) ( 3 ) . [6377308]
  • This indicated that arb gene expression is indeed under cAMP-CRP complex-mediated positive control . [11994151]
  • This variation is further extended by the fmding that cAMP/CRP can act not only as a positive effector but also as a negative regulator of gene expression . [6329724]
  • Because Sxy is thought not to bind DNA , we also examined gene expression in cyaA cells to test whether Sxy might act by overriding-CRP 's dependence on its allosteric effector cAMP . [17068078]
  • This could be elucidated by the facts that the trxA-lac fusion of plasmid pJH3 did not contain the cAMP-CRP binding site , indicating that the presumed cAMP-CRP binding site is in vivo functioning negatively in the expression of the trxA gene . [9175752]
  • Although , it is generally believed that CRP is synthesized constitutively and its function is controled by the level of cAMP ( 11 ) , little is known about the expression of the crp gene , which codes for CRP . [6280140]
  • CRP * mutants which can actively affect gene expression without binding cAMP were isolated by many groups ( 3 , 10 , 11 , 13-15 ) . [2013578]
  • In the gal operon , one of two overlapping promoters is activated ; the other is inhibited by the complex ( Adhya and Miller , 1979 ) , and expression of the ompA gene in vitro is likewise inhibited by cAMP/CRP ( Mowa et al. , 1981 ) . [6329724]
  • Thus , if the level of cAMP is high in cells cultured in the presence of 0.04 % glucose , negative regulation by the cAMP-CRP complex probably occurs in the puuR gene expression ( Shimada et al. 2011 ) . [23719730]
  • It was shown that expression of the fumA gene resembles that of the succinate dehydrogenase operon and other ` citric acid cycle ' genes in being repressed by glucose ( i.e. , dependent on the cAMP-CRP complex ) and anaerobiosis . [3282546]
  • It was reported that expression of the pts operon and the ptsG gene increases a few fold during growth on glucose or other PTS substrates ( 1 ) , and the functional cAMP CRP complex is essential for the expression of the ptsG gene ( 1 , 11 ) . [15252051]
  • Glucose is known to affect gene expression through the cAMP-CRP complex , and the presence of glucose in the growth medium results in decreased levels of cAMP and CRP ( 26 , 36 ) . [15743955]
  • Taken together , our data reveal that glucose can destabilize the ompA mRNA by reducing the cAMP-CRP complex-medi-ated activation of hfq gene expression . [21840983]
  • Although Wang et al ( 2005 ) observed a negative regulation of luxS expression by cAMP and CRP , an alternative explanation is MicA involvement as it is up-regulated in a cya-deficient background [ 25 ] . [20976191]
  • As an example , expression of the cts group , which is induced in the stationary phase or under carbon starvation conditions , is dependent on the cAMP-CRP complex ( 19 ) . [8655515]
  • Expression of slp during carbon starvation and stationary phase was dependent on neither cAMP/CRP nor cS . [11094278]
  • Interestingly , although the effect of cAMP was already observed in the exponential phase of the cultures , the highest changes occurred upon entry into stationary phase , suggesting that CRP is not the only factor necessary for gene expression ( Fig. 6A ) . [22059728]
  • In stationary phase wild-type cells , the inhibitory effect of cAMP-CRP on the expression of os and therefore of csiE is overcome by several stimulatory effects . [8596457]
  • While it is obvious that cAMP-CRP is required for full expressionin stationary phase , crp and cya mutantsexhibited increased levels of expression in exponential phase ( Figs 1 , 2 and 5 ) . [8596457]
  • Induction of lrp expression in cells entering stationary phase does not require cAMP and CRP since cya and crp mutants have lrp expression levels that are the same as or higher than those of the wild type . [8955316]
  • These data indicate that cAMP-CRP represses the expression of osmY and that this repression plays a role during an early period of the transition into stationary phase when the growth rate is just beginning to slow down . [8253679]
  • cAMP/CRP can also play a negative role in controlling the expression of stationary phase-induced genes . [7934831]
  • cAMP-CRP thus determines the time of induction of osmY , but it is apparently not involved in determining the final level of osmY expression in stationary phase . [8253679]
  • In summary , expression of yjiY is induced at the transition of the E. coli culture into the stationary-growth phase , and induction requires cAMP and CRP . [22685278]
  • Second , the remainingexpression in the A ( -38 ) construct was entirely dependent on as.Finally , in the Acrp background , expression of the A ( -72 ) and A ( -38 ) constructs was very similar , suggesting that the cis-activatingelement located between position -72 and -38 - mediatesthe activation by cAMP-CRP . [8596457]
  • Shifting the CRP box further upstream or downstream ( up to 276.5 and 262.5 respectively ) reduced csiD expression 20-fold and more ( the basal expression obtained with non-optimal positions was no longer cAMP-CRP dependent ; Table 1 ) . [11532138]
  • The expression of yﬁQ occurs from its own promoter ; it is upregulated in the stationary phase and in the presence of non-PTS carbon sources and is positively regulated by cAMP-CRP . [22059728]
  • Figure S2A in the supplemental material shows that , under high-glucose conditions , the cpxA24 mutation still represses cyaR-lux expression , while the cpxR mutation no longer has an effect , suggesting that the cpxR mutation affects cyaR expression via cAMP/CRP . [25246476]
  • 1981 ) , Four different transcripts originate in its upstream regutatory region , and it has been shown that in vitro expression of gIgC is stimulated by cAMP/CRP and weakly stimulated by ppGpp ( Romeo and Preiss , 1989 ) . [1324388]
  • In the presence of CRP , expression of glpD and glpE increased 5 - and 3-fold upon the addition of cAMP , respectively ( data not shown ) . [1846566]
  • The maximal stimulation of expression by cAMP and CRP observed in the experiment shown in Fig. 2 was 26-fold for glgC and 10-fold for gigA ; ppGpp increased the expression 3.6 - and 1.8-fold , respectively . [2468650]
  • Of particular interest were mutations that resulted in CytR-dependent constitutive udp expression when intracellular cAMP-CRP concentrations were limiting ( glucose medium ) ( del224 , del364 , dup1 , and dup361 ) . [8626289]
  • Since cstA expression is dependent on cAMP-CRP ( 42 , 43 ) , lower expression was observed throughout the growth curve in both the wild-type and csrA mutant strains under this growth condition . [12867454]
  • Thus , the observed expression patterns for pckA , tnaA , aspA and others under conditions of aerobic acetate formation can be explained by cAMP-CRP dependent regulation . [17273855]
  • Altogether , these data suggest that a reduced level of cAMP-CRP in hns and hns-stpA strains may be one of the reasons why malE and lamB expression is reduced in hns and hns-stpA strains . [9829919]
  • This indicated that ulaG is not affected by CRP and further supports the participation of another mechanism independent of cAMP-CRP in the expression of both operons of the ula regulon . [14996803]
  • It has been proposed that the expression of rpoS is not only negatively controlled by cAMP-CRP high levels but also inversely correlated with growth rate . [22513097]
  • The expression of MBP and LamB is also activated by the CRP-cAMP complex ( 31 ) , whereas the expression of OmpA is constitutive and thus affected little by CRP ( 30 ) . [10074084]
  • The ability of both holoenzymes to be activated by cAMP-CRP from the 260.5 position makes it difﬁcult to distinguish how much of the csiD expression in the strain that contains both holoenzymes results from each of them . [11532138]
  • The 235 site is relatively poor , and this would explain why dctA expression is weak in the absence of cAMP-CRP activation . [10482502]
  • The expression of tnaA is under cAMP and CRP regulation ( 78 ) and is also inducible by high pH ( 75 ) . [17293424]
  • csiD expression is also strongly dependent on cAMP-CRP . [9512707]
  • The mel locus is induced by several a-D-galactosides ( 2,3 ) and its expression is controlled by the cAMP-CRP regulatory circuit ( 4 ) . [3031590]
  • The activity of CA8306 ( cya ) harboring these clones was higher in the presence of cAMP , suggesting that gntK expression is controlled by cAMP-CRP . [9135111]
  • The expression of fMet-Gln , the amino-terminal dipeptide of gigA was enhanced 2.4 - to 2.8-fold by cAMP and CRP . [2468650]
  • The expression of the protein acetyltransferase PatZ is regulated by cAMP-CRP . [22059728]
  • In an rpoS mutant , csiE expression is significantly but not totally reduced , and can still be stimulated by cAMP-CRP ( Fig. 2 ) . [8596457]
  • There are at least two regulatory systems involved : rpoS , which controls gIgS ; and cAMP/CRP , which controls the expression of gIgCAP ( Romeo and Preiss . [1324388]
  • DNA helix phase dependency of cAMP-CRP activation of csiD expression mediated by Es or Es . [11532138]
  • Changes in cAMP-CRP levels affected only the expression of the ulaABCDEF operon . [14996803]
  • At least three models can be postulated to describe the mechanism by which cAMP and CRP affect expression ` of cir . [2160948]
  • cAMP and CRP negatively regulate the expression of luxS but not pfs . [15743955]
  • Elimination of the cAMP-CRP site in -180 did not change the pattern of expression under these conditions . [14996803]
  • Both cAMP and CRP are required for expression of glgS and PTS ( phosphotransferase system ) - related genes required for normal glycogen production [ 22,44 ] . [21029047]
  • Both genes are regulated by CRP , which activates their expression in response to the elevation of cAMP levels upon glucose starvation . [25524697]
  • In order to conﬁrm the role of CRP on the expression of cobB , patZ and acs genes , cAMP response experiments were performed . [22059728]
  • cAMP-CRP , a positive regulator , stimulates expression of both operons in the absence of glucose , while LsrR prevents their expression . [16321939]
  • In the absence of glucose , cAMP-CRP is needed to stimulate lsr expression , while LsrR represses its expression in the absence of the inducer phospho -- AI-2 . [15743955]
  • Interestingly , we found that the expression of pfs was reduced by the presence of glucose , but not through the cAMP-CRP complex . [15743955]
  • In the case of Pr , when glucose is not available , the cAMP -- CRP complex induces mhpR expression as occurs in typical class II promoters . [20966094]
  • The roles of additional regulatory proteins ( Lrp , H-NS ) in the control of csiD expression It seems that with the elucidation of the crucial role of cAMP-CRP and a perhaps modulatory role of negative DNA supercoiling , our understanding of the regulation of csiD is not yet complete . [9512707]
  • This result suggested that the putative CRP box does not play a direct role in serC ( pdxF ) - aroA regulation and that the negative regulatory effects of CRP-cAMP are indirect . [9171388]
  • Under aerobic conditions with excess glucose , control of sdhCDAB -- b0725 -- sucABCD transcription by Arc , FNR , FruR and cAMP-CRP will play a minor role and , thus , reduced expression of this operon during glucose overflow metab-olism is likely due to the control by the cAMP-CRP independent catabolite control system . [17273855]
  • cAMP-CRP did not alter the extent of transcription termination within the IlvB leader suggesting that this regulatory system may be independent of the attenuation mechanism involved in the negative control of this operon . [6095192]
  • Regulation of this operon is complex , involving negative control by attenuation ( 2,3 ) and positive control by a number of factors ( 4,5 ) including cAMP-CRP ( 6,2 ) . [6095192]

  • The expression of acs encoding acetyl-coenzyme A synthetase is controlled by the regulator proteins CRP , Fis and IHF ( Browning et al. , 2004 ) . [17233826]
  • For example , the oxidative acid resistance system is regulated by rs and CRP ( Foster 2004 ) , and rs regulates both gene expression for osmotic stress ( Hengge-Aronis 1996 ) and regulates many acid resistance genes including the uncharacterized ygiW and yodD genes ( Weber et al. 2005 ) identiﬁed in this study . [19919618]

  • These results suggest that CRP negatively regulates proP expression and point to the Fis-independent P1 promoter as the target of repression . [9079929]
  • These results suggested that lsrR expression was subject to catabolite repression , and CRP was needed for stimulation of lsrR transcription . [16321939]
